text: The 2V source is just another battery. The circuit analysis methods (Node Voltage, Mesh Current) are intended to be by-the-book algorithms (recipes) for solving any circuit. If you trust the steps you don't have to think about anything else. You don't have to worry that If the 2V source points this way then I have to make sure its mesh current flows a certain direction. We started out curling both mesh currents in the clock-wise direction. When we got to the solution it turned out i2 had a negative value, indicating that the current flows out of the top of the 2V source, just like you would expect. There is no crime if you have a mesh current with a negative value. The reason we curl all the mesh currents in the same direction is to encourage correct writing of mesh equations, especially when two mesh currents flow through one resistor (the 1kohm resistor in this circuit). You get accustomed to writing that terms with a +meshcurrent and a -meshcurrent. This habit helps reduce careless sign errors. That feature is more important than trying to eliminate a negative sign from the final answer. The simplicity of Bohr's model is easy to explain to those who start studying chemistry, and while the model itself may not represent the true nature of an atom, it portrays a rather simple picture of orbits and energy levels, making the concept of those easier to understand.

text: The lungs are functionally like a balloon that fills the thoracic cavity. The diaphragm (which is skeletal muscle) and some other muscles change the volume of the thoracic cavity this changes the pressure and causes inhalation and exhalation. What changes is what it is controlled by for voluntary functions the cerebral cortex is taking over but normally breathing centers of the medulla oblongata and pons control involuntary breathing. X-chromosome inactivation is a random event that occurs during early embryo development - any one of the X chromosomes could be inactivated. In a female who receives the recessive disease allele from BOTH parents, no matter which X chromosome gets inactivated, the other one would still carry the truant gene

text: The area under the velocity/time curve is the total displacement. If you divide that by the change in time, you will get the average velocity. Velocity is the vector form of speed. If velocity is always non-negative, then average velocity and average speed are the same. Since the p orbitals are perpendicular, it would be impossible to get all three in the necessary orientation at the same time to make three pi bonds. A maximum of two p orbitals can form pi bonds to the same atom.

text: Resonance decreases reactivity because it increases the stability of the molecule. The reason why resonance is decreasing the reactivity of the carboxylic acid is because moving the electrons causes the carbonyl carbon to become less partially positive (which makes the carboxylic acid more stable). When you stabilize the carboxylic acid by making the carbonyl carbon less positive, you are decreasing its ability to be an electrophile in a reaction (in other words, you are making the molecule less reactive due to the increase in stability from the resonance). Reactivity and stability are two opposing concepts. The more stable a molecule is, the less it wants to react. A decrease in stability results in an increase in reactivity and an increase in stability causes a decrease in reactivity. Think of it this way: a molecule always wants to be in it's most stable form. If it's not stable, it is going to want to react in order to stabilize itself. If it's already stable, it doesn't need to react. When writing chemical reactions, a base or acid is mentioned. This is because the extra protons(H+) and the hydroxyl ions (OH-) ions have to come from somewhere. They come from the acid/base. (which can be termed as medium of the reaction: acidic medium if an acid is used and similarly, basic medium) Now, an acid provides H+ ions(more appropriately it donates H30+ ions since H+ combines with water to from H30+ ions or hydronium ions). Similarly, a base donates hydroxyl ions. We decide the quantity and concentration of the acid or base used depending on the number of H+ or OH- ions we may need. As long as the reaction is taking place in an acidic medium, there should be enough protons for the reaction to happen.

text: The first is: glycolysis, which will happen with or without oxygen. Glycolysis, splits glucose into two pyruvate molecules. The second is: In the presence of oxygen, these pyruvate molecules are converted to two acetyl-coa molecules. These then go through the Krebs cycle, where they reduce electron carriers. Finally, the electrons from the electron carriers go through an electron transport chain, which creates a proton gradient that drives the production of ATP. Using the D line of sodium, 589 nm, is the most common wavelength used and the only wavelength used in data tables tabulating the specific rotation's of enantiomers. But yes if you were to use a different wavelength of light then the specific rotation would be different than the specific rotations found using 589 nm. Hope that helps.

text: Most vitamins are co-enzymes, which means they assist enzymes in performing their function. There are other types of co-enzymes that are not vitamins. Alkynes generated from vicinal dihalides will be formed between the two halogens. Alkynes formed from germinal dihalides could be formed on either side of the geminal dihalides (unless you had no protons on one side of the geminal dihalides). This means that you would get a mix of products (which is bad) when forming an alkyne from a geminal dihalide. One other exception is if you have a symmetrical molecule, in which case it doesn't matter which side you deprotonate because you'll still form the same alkyne in the end due to symmetry.

text: Resistance not only depends on length, area, and type of the conductor, it also changes with temperature for some devices. In a light bulb, because the temperature increases when it is illuminated, its resistance changes. People then have three variables and the relation between the current and the potential difference no longer gives a straight line (since its gradient, the resistance, is no longer a constant). Devices whose temperature changes affect the resistance are called non-ohmic devices. the first stage would be the 'activation of amino acids'. Basically this step is before the initiation stage. During this activation of amino acids a specific amino acid and an ATP will bind to an enzyme called "aminoacyl-tRNA synthesas". The specific amino acid will bind the aminoacyl-tRNA synthesas where it will be activated by covalently binding with the ATP turning it into AMP during the process (releasing pyrophosphate). Then a tRNA will bind the aminoacyl-tRNA synthesas and it will covalently bind with the activated amino acid (releasing AMP). When the amino acid and the tRNA bind they will be released from the aminoacyl-tRNA synthesas and can then bind with the corresponding mRNA codon. So, when the tRNA leaves the E site is basically starts over the above process.
question: How do non ohmic devices work?
context1: Resistance not only depends on length, area, and type of the conductor, it also changes with temperature for some devices. In a light bulb, because the temperature increases when it is illuminated, its resistance changes. People then have three variables and the relation between the current and the potential difference no longer gives a straight line (since its gradient, the resistance, is no longer a constant). Devices whose temperature changes affect the resistance are called non-ohmic devices.
context2: the first stage would be the 'activation of amino acids'. Basically this step is before the initiation stage. During this activation of amino acids a specific amino acid and an ATP will bind to an enzyme called "aminoacyl-tRNA synthesas". The specific amino acid will bind the aminoacyl-tRNA synthesas where it will be activated by covalently binding with the ATP turning it into AMP during the process (releasing pyrophosphate). Then a tRNA will bind the aminoacyl-tRNA synthesas and it will covalently bind with the activated amino acid (releasing AMP). When the amino acid and the tRNA bind they will be released from the aminoacyl-tRNA synthesas and can then bind with the corresponding mRNA codon. So, when the tRNA leaves the E site is basically starts over the above process.

text: The furthest spot can only go as high as the solvent front of the mobile phase. the spots have to be somewhat soluble in the mobile phase. And the only reason the spots move is because they are dissolved and are pulled along as the mobile phase climbs. So the spots cannot travel faster than the mobile phase. One way people can tell between the redox reaction is when people see charges on the chemical equations. If the charges don't balance, people have to assume this is a redox reaction and go through specific steps to balance the equation. The electron transfer does occur in regular chemical reactions but the charges would balance on both sides.

text: It is possible to determine the probability that a single atomic nucleus will 'survive' during a given interval. This probability amounts to 50% for one half-life. In an interval twice as long (2 T) the nucleus survives only with a 25% probability (half of 50%), in an interval of three half-life periods (3 T) only with 12.5% (half of 25%), and so on. You can't, however, predict the time at which a given atomic nucleus will decay. For example, even if the probability of a decay within the next second is 99%, it is nevertheless possible (but improbable) that the nucleus will decay only after millions of years. It's like flipping a coin. If you flip 'heads' ten times in a row, what are the chances that the next flip will be 'heads'. You might say, 'I've flipped ten heads in a row. The next one is much more likely to come up 'tails'. Nevertheless, your chances of flipping heads are the same as before: 1 out of 2. Some nuclei are much luckier at flipping the coin than others. They keep flipping until they get 'tails'; then they decay. While a polygenic phenotype can occur without epistasis, if you have epistasis you must be dealing with a polygenic phenotype. Polygenic just means that there are multiple genes involved in a phenotype. Epistasis refers to situations where one allele masks the phenotypic effect of one or more alleles of another gene.
question: Why do we press the figurative 'reset' button once the half-life number of years has been achieved?

In an interval twice as long (2 T) the nucleus survives only with a 25% probability (half of 50%), in an interval of three half-life periods (3 T) only with 12.5% (half of 25%), and so on. You can't, however, predict the time at which a given atomic nucleus will decay. For example, even if the probability of a decay within the next second is 99%, it is nevertheless possible (but improbable) that the nucleus will decay only after millions of years. It's like flipping a coin. If you flip 'heads' ten times in a row, what are the chances that the next flip will be 'heads'. You might say, 'I've flipped ten heads in a row. The next one is much more likely to come up 'tails'. Nevertheless, your chances of flipping heads are the same as before: 1 out of 2. Some nuclei are much luckier at flipping the coin than others. They keep flipping until they get 'tails'; then they decay.
context2: While a polygenic phenotype can occur without epistasis, if you have epistasis you must be dealing with a polygenic phenotype. Polygenic just means that there are multiple genes involved in a phenotype. Epistasis refers to situations where one allele masks the phenotypic effect of one or more alleles of another gene.

text: Electricity directly heat things up, the flow of electrons creates heat. However, the power of electricity can also be used to indirectly cool things down by inducing cooling effects. A fridge works in much the way and uses the power of electricity to power machinery that cools the objects inside of it understand that 'species' is a human construct that doesn't have an exact match in nature. What actual exist are breeding populations in a given area. We may or may not classify them as the same species as some other similar breeding population somewhere else. What we usually, but not always, use as a dividing mark between species is whether the members continue to interbreed given the opportunity. If they cannot or will not normally breed, we tend to call them different species. If they are distinctly different but can and do naturally interbreed given the chance, we tend to call them different subspecies.

text: metabolism is more like the whole system which is made of skeleton - anabolic and catabolic reactions. There are many "circuits", dots are connected (intermediates connected by enzymes which make anabolism and catabolism happen). It is so dynamic, as cell itself is dynamic Snow forms when water vapor in the air turns directly into ice because it's so cold. The ice crystals grow from additional water vapor until they fall down as snow. Hail, on the other hand, is created when existing liquid rain is carried into colder areas by updrafts and freezes into a ball of ice. Because the water in many clouds is supercooled (brought past the freezing point but still in liquid form), it is easily frozen and the hail gradually grows. This continues until the hailstone becomes too heavy to stay in the clouds and falls.

text: Waves are disturbances right? So if you consider an example of force: say you're pulling a rope in x direction and your friend is pulling it in -x direction, with equal forces. It doesn't move as the forces cancel out. Same is with a wave. 1 wave disturbance is moving the rope up the other is moving it down so if they're equal they cancel each other out. If not then you use the same principle. In case of EM waves, I think it's the electromagnetic force that causes it. You would have two half reactions; an oxidation half reaction and a reduction half reaction. Remember: oxidation is losing electrons, reduction is gaining electrons. So the half reaction that has some element or compound plus electrons on the REACTANTS side would be the reduction reaction. The half reaction with some element or compound plus electrons on the PRODUCTS side is the oxidation reaction.

text: We are explicitly calculating *bond* enthalpy - to me this suggests that we are focusing on the potential energy. However, when we calculate an enthalpy of a reaction, we are often$ talking about how much 'heat' has been released (or absorbed) and this must be due to changes in the motion of the individual molecules. So, I think we could view these calculations as describing the interconversion between potential and kinetic energies of the molecules. $note: Clearly there are many exceptions such as: Chemiluminescence, where the energy is given off as light; and ATP powering molecular motors such as kinesins. However, in these cases we just replacing heat with other forms of light and (non-heat) kinetic energy, respectively (or more likely a mix of heat and these other forms of energy). Only the H would go down because it gets 'eaten up' by the OH- in order to make water. In response to the H going down, the HA goes down in order to maintain equilibrium by increasing H+. SInce H+ and the A- are on the same side, they both increase. A- doesnt go down at first because OH- only reacts with H+.

text: While the steps vary depending on the problem, the general strategy is to think about what compounds you start with and what you end with overall. All of the other compounds are intermediate states and will be used to cancel one way or another. As to which reactions to reverse, it is fair play to reverse any of the reactions--just to swap the sign for the enthalpy when you do so Carbon 3 is chiral, but people can't determine its stereochemistry because there is not a dash or wedge to denote which group (methyl or hydrogen) is in front of the other.

text: Oxidation originally referred to reactions with oxygen. So compounds like FeO and Fe2O3 were called ferrous and ferric oxides, while SnO and SnO2 were called stannous and stannic oxides. In 1919 Alfred Stock suggested that the names should use Roman numerals in parentheses, to make the names iron(II), iron(III), tin(II), and tin(IV) oxides. In 1940 the IUPAC recommended that the term 'Stock number' (I, II, III, IV, etc.) be replaced by the term 'oxidation number' with Arabic numerals (1, 2, 3, 4, etc.). In 1990 it adopted the current 'rule-based' system (H = +1, O = -2, etc.) for determining oxidation numbers.  Bohr model has been replaced by the modern model of the atom. The Bohr model only worked for Hydrogen atoms, and even for hydrogen it left a lot unexplained. The reason it works somewhat for hydrogen is that even though the electrons are not in orbits there are certain energy concepts for orbits that have more universal applicability

text: Viruses such as COVID-19 are strands of genetic material, they are covered in a protein shell. They are not living, because they cannot reproduce like humans can. Instead, they hijack healthy cells to make more and more viruses, which make the healthy cells burst. A v-shape ('bent') shape occurs when an atom has 3 attached groups, with one of those groups being a lone pair. It also occurs when an atom has 4 attached groups and 2 of those groups are lone pairs. Be careful though, these shapes are called the same name, but they have different bond angles. A general chem class might require that you know 1 lone pair = less than 120 degrees, 2 lone pairs = less than 109.5 degrees. Also, It is possible for an atom to have 5 or even 6 groups attached to it (these cases are called expanded octets), such as Phosphorus pentachloride (PCl5) or sulfur hexafluoride (SF6).

text: Nonpolar molecules that repel the water molecules are said to be hydrophobic; molecules forming ionic or a hydrogen bond with the water molecule is said to be hydrophilic. This property of water was important for the evolution of life. Hydrophobic interaction plays the most critical role in the formation of the lipid bilayer of the cell membrane and the folding of proteins and nucleic acids; therefore, hydrophobic interaction is the foundation for the existence of life. A self-assembled monolayer (SAM) is a layer of organic molecules formed spontaneously on a solid substrate. One end of the organic molecule binds to the solid surface via a covalent bond while the other endpoints outwards. Because the exposed end of the SAM determines the surface properties of the SAM modified substrate, we can alter a hydrophobic surface (a surface that expels water) into a hydrophilic surface (a surface that attracts water) by carefully selecting the SAM forming molecules. It's all in the definition. The energy is defined as zero when the electron is an infinite distance from the nucleus. As the electron comes closer, the energy decreases, so the energy of the system becomes negative. Even for an H atom in an excited state, the energy is negative, but it is less negative than for an atom in the ground state.

One end of the organic molecule binds to the solid surface via a covalent bond while the other endpoints outwards. Because the exposed end of the SAM determines the surface properties of the SAM modified substrate, we can alter a hydrophobic surface (a surface that expels water) into a hydrophilic surface (a surface that attracts water) by carefully selecting the SAM forming molecules.

text: During the production of reproductive cells, chromosomes of the same type (except for X & Y in the case of chromosomally typically males) line up and exchange sections of their genetic code. If the chromosomes are not lined up perfectly during this process the codes may be reversed, or one may end up with two copies of a small section of DNA while the other gets none. Mutations that start here are often called crossing over errors. These mutations are particularly important because they are automatically germline mutations (able to be passed down to future generations). There are other possible sources of mutations, but most of these will be somatic mutations (not able to be passed to future generations). For autosomal recessive where there is no skipped generation, the other parent must be heterozygous for the trait, which would mean the children have a chance of having the recessive trait through inheriting the recessive chromosome from the carrier parent. For X-linked recessive, the same is true, with one parent being a carrier. Ways to prove X-linked recessive are that if the trait is recessive, there will be mother-son and/or daughter-father links. This means that if the mother is affected, the son must be as he must inherit one of her affected X chromosomes. The same is true with daughter-father links. If the daughter is affected then the father must also be as she will inherit one of her X chromosomes from him.
question: Why do genetic mutations still exist in the gene pool?

text: Homology is defined as the property of being descended from a common ancestor. This can apply to structures, DNA sequences, or even behaviors that can be traced back to an ancestor shared by two (or more) species. As one example, the fore limbs of all mammals (including: bat wings, whale flippers, primate arms, and the front legs of quadrupeds) are homologous - they all are variations on the front limbs of the first shrew-like mammals. Relative position within an organism is one very important piece of evidence for a structure being homologous. Another type of evidence is developmental - do the structures develop in the same way. Just rotate the molecule in your head or using a molecule set so that the lowest priority group is behind the carbon. After that, proceed as normal.

text: once the sodium gave up its electron to hydrogen, it has a full shell like a noble gas, meaning it doesn't want to react. The only thing left for that H to react with is another H, forming H2. Sodium is not electronegative. It is electropositive being in group one of the periodic table.  If the 2s orbital bonds with a hydrogen the bond will be shorter than the bonds formed by 3 2p orbitals with hydrogen. If this was the case, ammonia would have 3 long bonds and a short bond. However, when the shape of ammonia was discovered, it was clear that all N-H bond lengths were equal, hence the idea of 2s and 2p orbitals forming individual bonds with the hydrogen was discarded and hybridization was able to explain the shape of ammonia.

For the photon to be absorbed, it has to match the energy change corresponding to a single electron moving from one energy level to another. You really should not think too literally about the Bohr model since it is not a correct view of how atoms actually work. It was a model that worked only for an isolated hydrogen atom (and not even perfectly for that). There's no way to apply it to argon or any other atom. This is what prompted physicists to keep working to find our modern model of the atom. What you can apply is the concept of quantized energy levels. Bohr's model was a first step in that direction.

text: Positive and negative are determined by the direction where current flows - think about the battery in your everyday life. We know oxidation occurs in anode, the current must flow from anode to cathode. By physics convention, we will label anode as negative. We can't 'see' the electrons with our instruments, but we can see the atoms and measure their bond lengths and bond angles. That's why we ignore the lone pair electrons in determining *molecular geometry*. We must, however, consider the lone pairs in determining the *electron geometry* about an atom.

text: Active transport is a process that uses energy from respiration. Diffusion and osmosis don't require the cell to expend any of its own energy, as they are passive processes. Diffusion is the spreading out of particles in a *gas or solution* resulting in the *net* movement of these particles from an area of *higher* concentration to an area of *lower* concentration Osmosis is the movement of *water* particles from a *dilute* solution to a *more* concentrated solution through a *selectively permeable membrane* As we know both are passive processes and yet (in basic, short terms) diffusion is higher to lower and osmosis is lower to higher, so movement to concentration doesn't determine whether it is active or passive. Meta attack occurs is because the first nitro group is electron withdrawing (deactivating) so probably the reaction will occur but much slower.
question: Shouldn't Osmosis technically be classified as a form of active transport?
context1: Active transport is a process that uses energy from respiration. Diffusion and osmosis don't require the cell to expend any of its own energy, as they are passive processes. Diffusion is the spreading out of particles in a *gas or solution* resulting in the *net* movement of these particles from an area of *higher* concentration to an area of *lower* concentration Osmosis is the movement of *water* particles from a *dilute* solution to a *more* concentrated solution through a *selectively permeable membrane* As we know both are passive processes and yet (in basic, short terms) diffusion is higher to lower and osmosis is lower to higher, so movement to concentration doesn't determine whether it is active or passive.
context2: Meta attack occurs is because the first nitro group is electron withdrawing (deactivating) so probably the reaction will occur but much slower.
question2: Would the meta attack still occur?

It is indeed POSSIBLE for matter to return to an ordered state WITHOUT the input of energy, but the probability of such an occurrence is extremely low, just as billiard balls happening to collect back at the center of the pool table is extremely low. Being in an ordered state would likely have HIGHER energy, especially potential energy. If you look at the example of the molecules all crammed into one side of the box rather than being diffused throughout, the probability that they would bounce into each other is much greater, and therefore they exhibit a greater potential for increasing the kinetic energy of each molecule. Usually it TAKES energy to create an ordered state, such as the energy needed by organisms to create ordered systems of life.

text: A small change in the DNA code, e.g. a point mutation , could result in a small or a big change, or no change at all, depending on the changes in the proteins it codes. The change can be good or bad, or both. For example, sickle cell anemia is quite a severe disease, but carrying the mutation protects against malaria. During the production of reproductive cells, chromosomes of the same type (except for X & Y in the case of chromosomally typically males) line up and exchange sections of their genetic code. If the chromosomes are not lined up perfectly during this process the codes may be reversed, or one may end up with two copies of a small section of DNA while the other gets none. Mutations that start here are often called crossing over errors. These mutations are particularly important because they are automatically germline mutations (able to be passed down to future generations). There are other possible sources of mutations, but most of these will be somatic mutations (not able to be passed to future generations).
question: What does this mean in terms of a DNA sequence?
context1: A small change in the DNA code, e.g. a point mutation , could result in a small or a big change, or no change at all, depending on the changes in the proteins it codes. There are other possible sources of mutations, but most of these will be somatic mutations (not able to be passed to future generations).

text: The deprotonation can occur at any of the resonating forms, get a mixture of products. It isn't as important on an unsubstituted benzene ring, the resonance structures become more important with reactions of substituted benzene rings, like Aniline or Toluene. While it is very long, the DNA in our cells is also incredibly thin (~2 nm) and so it can be 'folded' into a relatively small space. The genetic material in eukaryotes is known as chromatin. Chromatin is composed of DNA plus associated proteins and RNAs. These other molecules organize, fold, protect, and control the DNA. The DNA in chromatin is wound around protein complexes called nucleosomes and then further twisted and looped into higher order structures. There are a large number of proteins involved in this packaging (and also in the unpackaging that has to happen for replication and transcription to occur). As a result of all this packaging, the ~2 m of DNA in a typical human cell fits inside the ~6 m diameter nucleus!

There are a large number of proteins involved in this packaging (and also in the unpackaging that has to happen for replication and transcription to occur). As a result of all this packaging, the ~2 m of DNA in a typical human cell fits inside the ~6 m diameter nucleus!

text: The *vapor pressure* is a property of the substance and is constant at a given temperature. It increases when temperature increases. The *boiling point* of a substance is the temperature at which the vapor pressure of the liquid equals the pressure surrounding the liquid. -If you create a vacuum over the liquid you decrease the pressure surrounding the liquid. As soon as it falls below the vapor pressure the liquid will start to boil (you do not have to increase the temperature)! -If you seal the container, the pressure over the liquid will always be the same as the vapor pressure. Thus no matter how much you heat your liquid in order to increase the vapor pressure it will never boil (provided you have a perfect seal and your container can withstand the pressure i.e. it doesn't blow up!). boiling point will increase if you seal the container. The lac operon creates the enzymes required to metabolise the lactose. A presence of lactose would need the production of such enzymes.

text: The same reactions occur if we add very little base and a lot of acid to if we add same amounts of acid and base, but only until the dissociation products of either the acid or the base run out. To neutralize you need to add enough acid to a base to turn all HO- into H2O (when neutralizing a base) or enough base to an acid to turn all H+ into H2O (when neutralizing an acid). Keep in mind that some acids produce more H+ per volume than others, and the same goes with HO- for bases. So, you may want to check that before you start mixing, as a little of a powerful base can neutralize a lot of weak acid. the process will change, though this depends on the acid and the base just as much as the ratio in which you mix them. If there is an imbalance in the H+ and OH-, the neutralization will fail. There are actually several different variations on binary fission including multiple fission where the cells split into more than two daughters. The mechanistic details - for example of how the replicated DNA is separated into the daughter cells also varies among different species.

text: When seeing 'weight' used like this is chemistry, it is not using the meaning of the word that has to do with force due to gravity. Instead, it is using the mathematical sense of the word for WEIGHTed average. To put it another way: the word weight is there to remind you that this is a weighted average. It has nothing to do with the force of gravity on your reactants. In fact, it would make sense to add "Weight" (or even better "Weighted" for weighted average) to the units for everything based off the atomic weight(ed average). So you would have units like "atomic mass (weighted)", "grams (weighted)", "amu (weighted)". While these units may sound funny to say, they make sense -- anything measured in them assume you have the same distribution of isotopes as is on earth. If you don't have that normal distribution of isotopes, than anything measured in those weighted units would be off, because the weighting assumes a normal distrubution of isotopes. the Carbonyl group is how molecules are identified as sugars. The fact that each carbon atom is bonded to Hydroxyl groups except one carbon that is bonded to a Carbonyl group turns it into a sugar. fructose has a carbonyl group. this makes it into a sugar. This means that no matter how many Hydroxyl groups you have on a molecule, if it has a carbonyl group, it can't be an alcohol anymore, instead, it is classified as a sugar. all it takes is one atom for the entire molecule to be radically changed, in this case, the carbonyl group.

context1: When seeing 'weight' used like this is chemistry, it is not using the meaning of the word that has to do with force due to gravity. It has nothing to do with the force of gravity on your reactants. In fact, it would make sense to add "Weight" (or even better "Weighted" for weighted average) to the units for everything based off the atomic weight(ed average). So you would have units like "atomic mass (weighted)", "grams (weighted)", "amu (weighted)". While these units may sound funny to say, they make sense -- anything measured in them assume you have the same distribution of isotopes as is on earth. If you don't have that normal distribution of isotopes, than anything measured in those weighted units would be off, because the weighting assumes a normal distrubution of isotopes.

text: In meiosis 1, they line up as bivalents or tetrads (1 pair of homologous chromosomes) along the metaphase plate, unlike mitosis, where it's just single file. Viruses are kind of the 'zombies' of the cell world - they are only active and able to reproduce if they have infected an organism. Outside of an organism, like in the air, they can do basically nothing. The only resemblance viruses have to cells is a small amount of DNA and the ability to reproduce - they have no other purpose.

text: For autosomal recessive where there is no skipped generation, the other parent must be heterozygous for the trait, which would mean the children have a chance of having the recessive trait through inheriting the recessive chromosome from the carrier parent. For X-linked recessive, the same is true, with one parent being a carrier. Ways to prove X-linked recessive are that if the trait is recessive, there will be mother-son and/or daughter-father links. This means that if the mother is affected, the son must be as he must inherit one of her affected X chromosomes. The same is true with daughter-father links. If the daughter is affected then the father must also be as she will inherit one of her X chromosomes from him. With unsymmetrical ketones, people must take into account which of the two possible enolates is the most stable one. The basic criteria is that the higher the degree of substitution of the double bond, the more stable the enolate will be. The same criteria would indicate that a larger side chain would make for a more stable enolate. The most stable enolate is refereed as the thermodynamic enolate.

text: a subgroup is a group of related species in the same genus. A subspecies is a group of organisms that are in the species but are different in some way (like a bengal tiger vs a siberian tiger). If two populations of the same species were separated by a geographical event (like a canyon), then they would begin different evolutionary paths. After thousands of years they might start to look a bit different but would still be part of the same species - you could call them subspecies! In meiosis 1, they line up as bivalents or tetrads (1 pair of homologous chromosomes) along the metaphase plate, unlike mitosis, where it's just single file. Their centromeres are not directly in the middle, but on either side.

text: The entropy of a macro-system is proportional to the number of micro-states the system can be in that are compatible with the macro-state of the system. To make this notion precise, one has to specify the definition of macro-states and micro-states and how the micro-states will be counted. Sal is not providing those details here, but is speaking more qualitatively. Still, the entropy increase with either volume increase or temperature increase can be understood at this qualitative level. The micro-state of a gas is given by the location and velocity of each molecule in the gas. If the volume increases, the molecules have more locations they can be at, hence more micro-states. If the temperature increases, the molecules have more velocities with which they can move, hence more micro-states. Remember that absolute temperature is proportional to the average kinetic energy of the molecules, so increasing temperature increases the range of velocities the molecules are likely to have. This is an increase in the number of micro-states. First of all, habituations is not the same as imprinting (just be careful not to confuse the terms). Secondly: the interesting thing about imprinting is, that it combines innate parts with learned ones. It is innate for ducks to follow objects that move and make noises. But the ducks can't know how their mother locks exactly and have to learn a picture of her first (13-16 hours after they hatch). So sure, it is inborn for ducks to learn the picture of their mother. But they have to learn it first (it is actually obligatory for them to learn as they have to be able to distinguish between their mother and other adult ducks).
question: How come an increase in temperature increases this combination of states?

Sal is not providing those details here, but is speaking more qualitatively. If the temperature increases, the molecules have more velocities with which they can move, hence more micro-states. Remember that absolute temperature is proportional to the average kinetic energy of the molecules, so increasing temperature increases the range of velocities the molecules are likely to have. This is an increase in the number of micro-states.

text: The Earth is billions of years old. It still has a lot of residual heat left over from its formation, and additional heat is being added from radioactive decay of unstable isotopes. Also, Earth's crust and atmosphere acts as a thermal barrier, holding in heat. Add into that the radiation Earth gets from the Sun, and the net heat loss/gain varies. In some environments HCl does behave like an ionic compound, but as a gas it forms molecules (i.e. shows covalent bonding). Note that it is better to think of covalent and ionic bonding as being on a continuum rather than as distinctly different types of bonding. Most bonds have both ionic and covalent character and in many cases it is actually quite arbitrary to call something one or the other. HCl is a great example of this, it has a polar covalent bond as a gas - this can be expressed as the bond having a mixture of covalent and ionic character. However, when dissolved in water, HCl almost completely dissociates with the protons binding to water molecules - and so the behavior of HCl in water is best described as being ionic. One way of thinking of this is that the nature of bonding in some compounds changes depending on the environment.

text: there has to be a large amount of both the weak acid and its conjugate base (or vice versa) in order to neutralize the incoming acid/base that disturbs the solution. For example, I make a buffer with 1 mole of acetic acid and 1 mole of sodium acetate. If I were to drop a bit of strong base, let's say NaOH, into the solution, it would react with the 1 mole of acetic acid (acid) that is in the buffer. If i were to drop a bit of strong acid, let's say HCl, into the solution, it would react with the 1 mole of sodium acetate (base) that is in the buffer. Acids will react with bases. Now, let's pretend I make a second buffer, let's 0.1 moles of acetic acid and 1 mole of sodium acetate. This new buffer would be able to resist an incoming acid just as well as my first buffer, because it still has the same amount of sodium acetate (base). But it would be ineffective at neutralizing any incoming base because there is now only 0.1 moles of acetic acid to neutralize it. If we add too much base, we will quickly exceed the capacity of the buffer and the pH will skyrocket! Non-buffered solutions do not have any mechanism to resist changes in pH. the thing that determines which element it is, is the number of protons not electrons. It can happen where an element loses a proton because it is unstable, that is what we call radioactive decay.

text: That is an ionic bond because it includes a metal (Sodium). In ionic bonds, instead of sharing electrons, the atoms gain/lose electrons and become ions. In NaCl, Sodium loses one electron to achieve a full shell, and Chlorine sucks that electron in to get a full shell. Now, they both have full shells, but their charges are different. Sodium lost an electron, so it is now a Sodium 1+ ion, and Chlorine gained an electron, so it is now a Chloride 1- ion. The opposite charges attract, so then it becomes NaCl with a charge of zero. text: In the example of the quadriceps, one end is attached to your pelvis whilst the other end attaches to a lower leg bone called the tibia (this is the one you feel at the front of your leg). When the quads contract, they bend the knee - the pelvis stays still and they pull the lower leg towards the pelvis. So they are actually connected to two different bones Active transport is a process that uses energy from respiration. Diffusion and osmosis don't require the cell to expend any of its own energy, as they are passive processes. Diffusion is the spreading out of particles in a *gas or solution* resulting in the *net* movement of these particles from an area of *higher* concentration to an area of *lower* concentration Osmosis is the movement of *water* particles from a *dilute* solution to a *more* concentrated solution through a *selectively permeable membrane* As we know both are passive processes and yet (in basic, short terms) diffusion is higher to lower and osmosis is lower to higher, so movement to concentration doesn't determine whether it is active or passive.

text: all enzymes have an optimal temperature and pH level at which they work best at. If the enzyme is working at high temperatures or out of range pH levels, there is a chance it could become denatured. Also, enzymes are proteins, and proteins are affected by temperature and pH values. When the temperature is too high, or at extreme values of pH, the enzymes undergoes conformational change (ie. change in shape) of the active site, also known as denaturation. The substrates no longer fit into the shape of the active site to form an enzyme-substrate complex, so the rate of the enzymatic reaction decreases. , chlorine is much smaller and has a higher affinity to the electrons it has. Even as an anion, it is less inclined to give up an electron due to its high affinity. The acid is only present at very low concentration compared to the monomer molecules, which make up essentially 100% of the reactants. The acid catalyst (better termed as a promoter here, because it never really regenerates) starts the reaction by protonating one of the monomers, forming the carbocation. From there, based on the population of the reaction mixture, the resulting carbocation is MUCH more likely to find another monomer's pi cloud. It is true that HCl will add across a double bond (a very standard addition reaction), but in that case both molecules (alkene plus HCl) are present in each quantity. Such is not the case here. A tiny amount of acid will trigger the linking of all of the monomers.

text: O2 dissolves in water, but 'dissolving' is a physical property not a chemical one. It just gets trapped there. Some 'non polar' compounds do chemically interact with water, because only a part of their molecule is non polar whilst another part is polar. Noble gases are elements that are at the last period of the periodic table. They are normally found as a gas at STP (273.15K or 0degree Celsius and 1 atm), which explains the gas part. Of course, noble gases can become solids and liquids at low temperatures. But not during normal conditions. For example, Mercury is the only liquid metal in the periodic table at normal conditions, however, other metals can melt and become liquids at higher temperatures. The noble part comes because the noble gases have full outer electron shells of eight electrons each. So they are satisfied with their electron configuration and do not want to share electrons with other elements including other noble gases. Which means that they are extremely nonreactive, hence the noble part of their name. So in short, noble gases are called so as they are extremely nonreactive and are gases at normal temperatures.

text: Albinism is an autosomal recessive condition, meaning that a person must inherit TWO copies of the affected allele from his/her parents in order to display the phenotype. Thus, if one child is albino, you can assume that the parents are either a) both carriers (i.e. heterozygous for the trait) or b) both affected. Considering your question, we can assume that the parents are both carriers (since the chance that two children would inherit the disease if both parents are albino would be 100%). We must also consider the fact that these are independent events, meaning that having one child with albinism does NOT affect the chance of having another child with the condition. By the rules of probability, this means that we must multiply the number of chances of having a child affected by albinism to figure out the total probability of having TWO children with albinism. So, what is the probability of having a child with albinism given both parents are heterozygous? If you do a punned square for Aa x Aa, you get that the chance of having a child with albinism is 25%. This means that the chance of having a normal child is 75%. So, you just multiply 0.25 by 0.75 and get 0.1875. Thus, the chance of having a normal child is 19% The cancer affects the rat in any form of cancer. The place of growth of the tumor and eventually later metastasizing is selected by the cell in which errors are occurring. You know that even one single cell is enough to grow tumor on that part of your body. If that rat was exposed to cancerogenic factors such as X rays, the number of errors would enormously build up and potentially many tumors will grow all over the body.

text: Hydrogen can  be considered a halogen because, like the other halogens (fluorine, chlorine, etc.), it only requires one additional electron to complete its valence shell.  We can't 'see' the electrons with our instruments, but we can see the atoms and measure their bond lengths and bond angles. That's why we ignore the lone pair electrons in determining *molecular geometry*. We must, however, consider the lone pairs in determining the *electron geometry* about an atom.

text: If people put a charged object somewhere in space and people will notice there is a force on it, that force is caused by the electric field at that location. The magnitude of the force is proportional to two things: the size of the charge and the intensity (magnitude) of the electric field. The direction of the force is determined by the direction of the electric field vector. A cross between a female fly that is heterozygous for white eyes and a male that is white-eyed could produce female progeny with white eyes, because the mother makes two kinds of gametes: one X chromosome that encodes red eyes, and one X chromosome that encodes white eyes. If the gamete encoding for white eyes is fertilized by the X chromosome from the father, then female white-eyed flies result.
question: Is electric field just how reactive it is when a charge is placed in it?
context1: If people put a charged object somewhere in space and people will notice there is a force on it, that force is caused by the electric field at that location. The magnitude of the force is proportional to two things: the size of the charge and the intensity (magnitude) of the electric field. The direction of the force is determined by the direction of the electric field vector.
context2: A cross between a female fly that is heterozygous for white eyes and a male that is white-eyed could produce female progeny with white eyes, because the mother makes two kinds of gametes: one X chromosome that encodes red eyes, and one X chromosome that encodes white eyes. If the gamete encoding for white eyes is fertilized by the X chromosome from the father, then female white-eyed flies result.

text: The magnetic field is steady, but the sample is being irradiated with radiofrequency energy (light). The proton absorbs the energy and flips to a higher-energy state, similar to the way an electron absorbs energy and goes to a higher energy state. Intermolecular bonds break easier, but that does not mean first. Statistically, intermolecular bonds will break more often than covalent or ionic bonds. They can both break at the same time, it is just a matter of probability. Water, for example is always evaporating, even if not boiling. But, then, why no hydrogen or oxygen is observed as a product of pure water? Because water decomposes into H+ and OH- when the covalent bond breaks. The concentration of each of these ions in pure water, at 25 degree Celsius, and pressure of 1atm, is 1.010e7mol/L... that is: covalent bonds are breaking all the time (self-ionization), just like intermolecular bonds (evaporation). By the way, that is what makes both pH and pOH of water equal 7. Note that even though H+ and OH- are naturally produced in water, they also recombine back into H2O. The speed of bonds breaking and the speed of recombination fight one another, until they are in chemical equilibrium, that is when both speeds are the same. For instance, this kind of fight also happens with evaporation inside a closed recipient. The equilibrium is reached when the number of molecules escaping from the liquid phase is the same as the number of molecules entering it.

text: NaOH does not have a pH, but an aqueous solution of NaOH does. Water contains both H+ and OH- ions. Adding NaOH increases the concentration of OH- ions and decreases the concentration of H+ ions. But there are *always* some H+ ions present, so aqueous NaOH solutions have a pH, usually between 7 and 14. carbon will almost always follow the octet rule. CO isn't an exception to this. The third bond here comes from a lone pair on O being shared with C. the hybridisation is sp for both O and C. Experimentally we find the bond length in CO is shorter than a C-O double bond and similar to the N-N triple bond length in N2. So a triple bond in CO here does sense.
question: How can NaOH have a pH scale?

text: We cant treat light the same way we treat matter because daily things travel very slowly but when you are travelling at speeds beyond 10^6 ms^-1 the science is different matter and energy are interconvertible (e=mc^2) so it doesn't really store energy it is energy itself. Nonpolar molecules that repel the water molecules are said to be hydrophobic; molecules forming ionic or a hydrogen bond with the water molecule is said to be hydrophilic. This property of water was important for the evolution of life. Hydrophobic interaction plays the most critical role in the formation of the lipid bilayer of the cell membrane and the folding of proteins and nucleic acids; therefore, hydrophobic interaction is the foundation for the existence of life. A self-assembled monolayer (SAM) is a layer of organic molecules formed spontaneously on a solid substrate. One end of the organic molecule binds to the solid surface via a covalent bond while the other endpoints outwards. Because the exposed end of the SAM determines the surface properties of the SAM modified substrate, we can alter a hydrophobic surface (a surface that expels water) into a hydrophilic surface (a surface that attracts water) by carefully selecting the SAM forming molecules.

text: The Calvin cycle is dependent on the Light-dependent reactions, and almost in the same way Light-dependent reactions are dependent on 'The Calvin Cycle'. The 'light-dependent reactions' receive light, and provide energy for the Calvin cycle. After used by the Calvin cycle, the molecules go back to the thylakoids to be reenergized in a way. So it is almost like a constant cycle between the two areas. There are so many electrons in the metal that losing a few trillion from photoelectric effect has a negligible impact. If the metal becomes more positively charged, it will take more energy to free an electron from that potential well.

text: Conductance is the inverse of resistance. The main reason we talk about conductance is the equation for parallel conductance. That equation (sum of conductances) looks just like the formula for computing series resistance (sum of resistances). That is a nice observation to make and understand. In electrical engineering this kind of relationship between two equations is called a "Dual". When the temperature of a gas is increased, the molecules have higher kinetic energies. When the molecules move around faster they can configure themselves in more ways than they could have if they had less kinetic energy. More specifically, molecules in an ideal gas follow Maxwell-Boltzmann statistics which imply that the molecules' velocity distribution broadens as the temperature of the system is increased.

text: Microtubules and their associated proteins are somewhat self-organizing. microtubules can form spindle like structures in vitro without a centrosome. All eukaryotic cells have microtubule organizing centers in animals cells centrosomes are one kind of MTOC, but plant cells have microtubule organizing centers without needing centrioles. Hypertonic solutions contain more solutes than isotonic solutions, which are basically 'neutral' solutions. So in order to even out the solutes (not the solvent), the solvent will move across the semipermeable membrane so that the solutes have more room to spread out. That's what osmosis is all about: spreading the solutes out by moving the solvent. If the water molecules from the hypertonic area flowed into the hypotonic area, it might maintain the balance of the solvent. However, the solutes would be even more concentrated in the hypertonic solution, and even less concentrated in the hypotonic solution, causing this situation to become something other than osmosis because the solutes were not evened out. The solvent was moved, but the solutes were more concentrated (hypertonic solution) or less concentrated (hypotonic solution); if this was really osmosis, the concentration of solutes should have been equal on both sides of the semipermeable membrane.

text: A small change in the DNA code, e.g. a point mutation , could result in a small or a big change, or no change at all, depending on the changes in the proteins it codes. The change can be good or bad, or both. For example, sickle cell anemia is quite a severe disease, but carrying the mutation protects against malaria. Hybridization is known to happen between what are generally accepted to be different species  sometimes this leads to new species, other times some traits from one species become incorporated into another species.

text: C=O has a larger dipole moment than C=C, meaning C=O has a stronger bond strength. This is because of the difference in electronegativity values of C and O. a greater mass of the atoms of a bond means a lower frequency. But C=O has a greater bond strength, which apparently compensates for the difference in mass. Simply, the increase in bond strength is larger than the increase in mass. text: The ability to transform base metals into Gold was one of the main goals of Alchemists in in Middle Ages and Renaissance Europe, and it was called Chrysopoeia. However, the final goal of the Alchemist was not the making of money. It's even been done in nuclear reactors. Sadly, there are two problems: 1) You normally get a radioactive form of gold (a radio-isotope), so it doesn't stay gold for very long. 2) The cost to make the gold (cost for the electricity you need to power a particle accelerator or whatever) is bigger than the price of gold. Transmutation of atoms or changing of one atom to another is possible but involves high costs. You will have to shell out a lot of bucks to transmutate 1 gram of lead to 1 gram of gold but the money you earn from selling the gold, will be insignificant compared the cost of converting lead to gold. We can change atoms into gold or any other element,however the expense of adding or removing nucleons ( protons & neutrons ) would in itself be so much ,so I don't think you could get rich by doing it, plus ,the technology is way too expensive.But maybe it'll be easier in the future. Technically speaking, it could be possible through atomic fusion, but stars, the original source of fusion, only has enough energy to create iron through this process. While a solar fusion engine has been created, it would need several times the power it can give to fuse elements heavier than iron. Also, the energy to run said engine would cost so much that it would be cheaper to try to extract minerals from asteroids in space. Passive transport basically does not require any form of energy compared to active transport. In the case of osmosis,the water moves from areas of HIGH WATER concentration to areas of LOW WATER concentration, which makes it a form of passive transport. It uses no energy to move, it just drifts into lower concentrations of WATER. WATER not other materials, only WATER. Osmosis deals with water.

text: Both electrons are associated with both atoms, before both electrons being associated with only the oxygen atom. When the electrons are shared between the carbon and oxygen atoms so are their charges. Half the time each electron would be smeared around the carbon atom and the other half the time it would be smeared around the oxygen atom. Before each electron would be spending their whole time smeared around the oxygen. For autosomal recessive where there is no skipped generation, the other parent must be heterozygous for the trait, which would mean the children have a chance of having the recessive trait through inheriting the recessive chromosome from the carrier parent. For X-linked recessive, the same is true, with one parent being a carrier. Ways to prove X-linked recessive are that if the trait is recessive, there will be mother-son and/or daughter-father links. This means that if the mother is affected, the son must be as he must inherit one of her affected X chromosomes. The same is true with daughter-father links. If the daughter is affected then the father must also be as she will inherit one of her X chromosomes from him.

text: The molarity you use to measure the equilibrium constant is the molarity at equilibrium. When half the pixels are black and half are white, this is the highest entropy. The reason for this is that, if you consider every different possible arrangement of pixels that would give 50% black and 50% white, there are more possibilities for this 50/50 split than for any other percentage split. This makes the 50/50 split the most probable, and thus it has the highest entropy. some of these possibilities might look 'organized', for example a bunch of black pixels grouped together (though this arrangement is improbable). This would be one of many microstates (i.e. individual possible arrangements of pixels) that contributes to the maximum entropy macrostate (i.e. the big picture that there is a 50/50 split between black and white pixels). If you limited yourself to only having a bunch of black pixels grouped together, however, then the entropy would be lower, since the probability of this happening is lower once you introduce a restriction. In the pixel system, low entropy would be if all of the pixels were black or all of the pixels were white.

The reason for this is that, if you consider every different possible arrangement of pixels that would give 50% black and 50% white, there are more possibilities for this 50/50 split than for any other percentage split. This makes the 50/50 split the most probable, and thus it has the highest entropy. some of these possibilities might look 'organized', for example a bunch of black pixels grouped together (though this arrangement is improbable). This would be one of many microstates (i.e. individual possible arrangements of pixels) that contributes to the maximum entropy macrostate (i.e. the big picture that there is a 50/50 split between black and white pixels). If you limited yourself to only having a bunch of black pixels grouped together, however, then the entropy would be lower, since the probability of this happening is lower once you introduce a restriction. In the pixel system, low entropy would be if all of the pixels were black or all of the pixels were white.
question2: What would low entropy look like in such a system?

text: Atoms in the gas phase (e.g. in outer space or in high vacuum) have line spectra. However, atoms in condensed phases (solids or liquids) can have essentially continuous spectra. For example, the tungsten filaments in incandescent light bulbs give off all colours of the visible spectrum (although most of the electrical energy ends up emitted as infrared (IR) photons, explaining why tungsten filament light bulbs are only 5-10% energy efficient). The explanation comes from the band theory of the solid state: in metallic solids, the electronic energy levels of all the valence electrons form bands of zillions of energy levels packed really closely together, with the electrons essentially free to move from one to any other. All the possible transitions involve all possible frequencies, so the spectrum emitted is continuous. The band theory also explains electronic properties of semiconductors used in all popular electronics nowadays, so it is not BS. Continuous spectra do not exist and it is really a line, i.e. absorption occurs at a very specific frequency. I can explain this further: when an element absorbs light, what happens is that the electron gains this energy from the light and jumps energy levels and is now in an excited state. The reason why it is at a very specific frequency is because the electrons are in a specific electron shell, and even have a different force toward the nucleus (based on the number of protons). Therefore, 1. each atom/element has it's own unique absorption spectrum, 2. because each outer most electron all elements requires a different amount of energy to get to this excited state. Using concentrations in the Nernst equation is a simplification. In reality, what we care about is the activity. For solutions, the activity is equal to the concentration, which is why we can get away with just writing concentrations for these species. Pure solids and liquids have an activity of 1, so we can ignore them (since multiplying by 1 doesn't change the value).

text: Biological molecules are chiral; they can detect the different isomers. If people put the stereoisomers in a reaction mix of (non-biological) chiral molecules, they would react differently too. Light is refracted at a very specific angle. I won't go into the mechanics here, but in a raindrop, light in fact undergoes so much refraction it bounces back in the direction the original ray came from, which is why rainbows always appear on the opposite side of the sky as the sun. This means that if you stand with the sun directly behind you, the rays of light form a triangle between you, the observer, the raindrop the light is refracted from and a point on the ground directly ahead of you. Since raindrops will be scattered all across the sky, and you can only observe light refracted at the specific angle, the line along which the light rays travels describes an arc across the sky, and this arc is the rainbow you see. Incidentally, the angle of refraction is also the reason why you can never catch up with a rainbow. The angle, and hence the bow's apparent distance must remain constant with respect to your position.
question: But how would two stereoisomers not carry out the same biological reactions?

text: In secondary active transport, one species of solute moves along its electrochemical gradient, allowing a different species to move against its own electrochemical gradient. This movement is in contrast to primary active transport, in which all solutes are moved against their concentration gradients (fueled by ATP) The hydrogen bond is a weak attraction between molecules, or parts of larger molecules to each other caused by regional polarization resulting from hydrogen's very small diameter and relatively low electronegativity. The bonds are stronger than Van der Waals interactions, but much weaker than other bonds. They typically require less than 20 kJ/mole to break.

text: There's no hard and fast rule that the definition of ecosystem has to necessarily contain the word 'abiotic factors'; only the word 'environment' is enough. For example: There are bacteria in the gut which help in breaking down food. And there are no abiotic 'factors' present in the gut. Here the gut is the bacteria's environment. So it's absolutely ok if we have an ecosystem without an abiotic factor. Technically, all people do have some amount of cancer in their bodies at any given time. mutations happen quite frequently, and while the damaged cells may not be malignant or available in large numbers, they still possess the qualities and damaged genetic code that many malignant, dangerous cancers have when they first develop. Because the amount of mutated cells in a healthy human is so small, there is no risk to the person's well-being. Oftentimes, these damaged cells will be destroyed or removed by the immune system, or by a built-in cellular system that employs tumor-suppressor genes to result in apoptosis, which is better known as 'cell suicide.' These cells know that they could become dangerous to the body, and thus destroy themselves to keep from spreading and polluting others anatomical structures.

text: There are different types of neurones in the body, with different locations of the axons and dendrites. The neurone that you are most familiar with are *multipolar* neurones. They make up 99% of all neurones and has 3 or more processes projecting out of the soma. They are the classic example of neurones, with axons carrying information away from the soma and dendrites bringing information back in. The other two types are *bipolar* and *unipolar* neurone. Bipolar neurones has only two processes: an axon and a dendrite. They are found in special sensory places, such as the retina of the eye or the olfactory epithelium. Unipolar neurones have only 1 processes, which contains both the axon and dendrite. They are more common, found in the skin, joints, muscles, and internal organs. this is the case with a plant cell that has a rigid cell wall thus in a fixed volume hydrostatic pressure will increase until osmotic pressure is opposed. But with an RBC the volume is not fixed (due to lack of cell wall) so osmotic pressure increases unopposed until the cell lyses.

text: Acids come in different strengths. Stronger acids dissociate more, so there is more H+ when they are dissolved in water. Thus, if you have any two acids in water with the same concentration, the pH will be lower (more H+) for the stronger acid. If you happened to have a diprotic acid that was just a little bit weaker than your monoprotic acid, it might be that the diprotic acid's double dissociation to give H+ just added up to match that of the monoprotic acid's single dissociation and they could have the same pH. the first stage would be the 'activation of amino acids'. Basically this step is before the initiation stage. During this activation of amino acids a specific amino acid and an ATP will bind to an enzyme called "aminoacyl-tRNA synthesas". The specific amino acid will bind the aminoacyl-tRNA synthesas where it will be activated by covalently binding with the ATP turning it into AMP during the process (releasing pyrophosphate). Then a tRNA will bind the aminoacyl-tRNA synthesas and it will covalently bind with the activated amino acid (releasing AMP). When the amino acid and the tRNA bind they will be released from the aminoacyl-tRNA synthesas and can then bind with the corresponding mRNA codon. So, when the tRNA leaves the E site is basically starts over the above process.
question: Does ph of a monoprotic acid and a diprotic acid is same?
context1: Acids come in different strengths. Stronger acids dissociate more, so there is more H+ when they are dissolved in water. text: The word lumen is used a lot in biology for the space inside a tube, such as the inside of blood vessels or intestines. It is also used for the space inside the E.R. The lumen is technically the inside of the E.R.. the ER is a continuation of the outer nuclear membrane. The lumen is basically the inside of the ER. So if you picture a slide, the slide is the ER. The part where you sit and go down is the lumen of the slide, or ER. Tubules and sacs of ER are interconnected and the ER membrane forms a continuous sheet enclosing a single internal space. The ER membrane separates the ER lumen from the cytosol, and it mediates the selective transfer of molecules between these two compartments. Almost all of the proteins that will be secreted to the cell exterior and those for the lumen of the ER, Golgi apparatus, or lysosomes are initially delivered to the ER lumen. understand that 'species' is a human construct that doesn't have an exact match in nature. What actual exist are breeding populations in a given area. We may or may not classify them as the same species as some other similar breeding population somewhere else. What we usually, but not always, use as a dividing mark between species is whether the members continue to interbreed given the opportunity. If they cannot or will not normally breed, we tend to call them different species. If they are distinctly different but can and do naturally interbreed given the chance, we tend to call them different subspecies.

The ER membrane separates the ER lumen from the cytosol, and it mediates the selective transfer of molecules between these two compartments. text: The cytosine (C) in DNA can degrade into uracil (U), which would not be good for the DNA. Since DNA is so important, DNA uses thymine (T) instead of uracil so the cytosine degradation could be detected and fixed. RNA, on the other hand, can have some errors and there will not be any lasting damages to the cell. Also, uracil takes less energy to be produced, making it less costly when used for RNA.  there has to be a large amount of both the weak acid and its conjugate base (or vice versa) in order to neutralize the incoming acid/base that disturbs the solution. For example, I make a buffer with 1 mole of acetic acid and 1 mole of sodium acetate. If I were to drop a bit of strong base, let's say NaOH, into the solution, it would react with the 1 mole of acetic acid (acid) that is in the buffer. If i were to drop a bit of strong acid, let's say HCl, into the solution, it would react with the 1 mole of sodium acetate (base) that is in the buffer. Acids will react with bases. Now, let's pretend I make a second buffer, let's 0.1 moles of acetic acid and 1 mole of sodium acetate. This new buffer would be able to resist an incoming acid just as well as my first buffer, because it still has the same amount of sodium acetate (base). But it would be ineffective at neutralizing any incoming base because there is now only 0.1 moles of acetic acid to neutralize it. If we add too much base, we will quickly exceed the capacity of the buffer and the pH will skyrocket! Non-buffered solutions do not have any mechanism to resist changes in pH.
question: Why is T(Thymine) replaced by (U)Uracil in the RNA?
context1: The cytosine (C) in DNA can degrade into uracil (U), which would not be good for the DNA. Since DNA is so important, DNA uses thymine (T) instead of uracil so the cytosine degradation could be detected and fixed. RNA, on the other hand, can have some errors and there will not be any lasting damages to the cell. Also, uracil takes less energy to be produced, making it less costly when used for RNA.

However, the reason why this doesn't occur is because SN1 reactions require a stable carbocation - a primary carbocation is not stable. On the other hand, if hydride were to nucleophilic attach the carbon via SN2 reaction, this would result in five bonds to the central carbon. Once again, this would not work as carbon cannot have more than four bonds. Also, hydroxyl does not make a good leaving group.

text: The ethane conformations are an example of torsional strain, which is due to electrons in the C-H bonds on opposite ends of the molecule repulsing one another. The repulsion is greater when the molecule is in the eclipsed conformation. Nitrogen has five electrons that are available to form bonds. three of these electrons have formed covalent bonds with hydrogen and carbon, leaving two unbonded electrons that are in a single orbital - these two electrons are called a lone pair. The lone pair electrons can bond with a proton (H+), which is what is shown in the video. When this happens, unlike a usual covalent bond, both the electrons in the bond come from the nitrogen lone pair (a proton, has no electrons that it can share). This leaves the nitrogen atom with a positive charge. In effect, the positive charge that was on the proton is now transferred to the hydrogen atom.

text: The lungs are functionally like a balloon that fills the thoracic cavity. The diaphragm (which is skeletal muscle) and some other muscles change the volume of the thoracic cavity this changes the pressure and causes inhalation and exhalation. What changes is what it is controlled by for voluntary functions the cerebral cortex is taking over but normally breathing centers of the medulla oblongata and pons control involuntary breathing. Light is the same entity whether it be on earth, other planets, the sun, or millions of light years away in distant space. Light itself can be thought of as being composed of massless 'particles' called photons which have both particle and wavelike properties. It has what is known as a wave-particle duality. A good demonstration of this is Thomas Young's double slit experiment. Basically he placed a plate in front of screen with two slits (or holes) in the plate which allowed light to pass through and would be detected on the screen behind. The critical aspect was how wide he made the slits. If you make the slits wide light passes straight through and hits the areas of the screen directly opposite of the slits. This is light behaving as a particle. Now if you made the slits super narrow you observe bands of light with different intensity on the screen separated by dark spaces. The bands corresponding to places where light acting as a wave interacted with itself constructively and the dark spaces where it interacted with itself destructively. This is known as interference and its something only waves can perform. Now since he used the same light and observed both wave and particle phenomenon, we can assume that light has both a wave and particle nature to it depending on the situation. Hope that helps.

text: The efficiency of ligation and transformation tends to decrease with extremely large inserts. For large inserts there are different kinds of vectors (not plasmids) that can be used. For an enormous insert like you are asking about you would need to use a type of vector known as an artificial chromosome. These are specific to the type of organism in which you wish to grow the vector with insert. The direction that energy gets transformed in always happens according to the second law of thermodynamics. This states that energy changes only happen in ways in which that entropy increases (or stays the same), but not decrease. In a small area, entropy may decrease, but overall the entropy of the universe must increase. There are lots of way to describe entropy, but it is closely related to heat. So one example of the second law of thermodynamics is saying that heat can only flow from a hot object to a cold object. If you have a hot and a cold block of metal next to each other, you won't see the cold one get colder and the hot one get hotter. The thermal energy from the hot one will become more spread out and passed on also to the colder one, until they reach the same temperature. As for why this happens, I can't really explain _why_ energy only flows in this direction. But everything follows these patterns. There isn't anything that can break the second law of thermodynamics.

text: The chromatin structure in plants is fundamentally the same as that in animals, but modern clues have been found that may lead to the discovery of other-and perhaps quite significant-differences. understand that 'species' is a human construct that doesn't have an exact match in nature. What actual exist are breeding populations in a given area. We may or may not classify them as the same species as some other similar breeding population somewhere else. What we usually, but not always, use as a dividing mark between species is whether the members continue to interbreed given the opportunity. If they cannot or will not normally breed, we tend to call them different species. If they are distinctly different but can and do naturally interbreed given the chance, we tend to call them different subspecies.

text: The cancer affects the rat in any form of cancer. The place of growth of the tumor and eventually later metastasizing is selected by the cell in which errors are occurring. You know that even one single cell is enough to grow tumor on that part of your body. If that rat was exposed to cancerogenic factors such as X rays, the number of errors would enormously build up and potentially many tumors will grow all over the body. The most common way for the sequence of nucleotides in DNA to affect as trait is by being transcribed into mRNA and then translated into protein. However, DNA also encodes many other types of RNA, some of which will affect traits. In addition, changes in control sequences in the DNA can affect whether and at what rate RNAs get made (sequences that get transcribed within an RNA can also affect its stability and processing). These changes can affect traits indirectly by influencing how much of an RNA is present in cell.
