text: Dead cells' pieces, called 'apoptotic bodies', are eliminated by phagocitosis by nearby cells, such as macrophages. Apoptotic cells show changes in their plasma membrane (e.g., phospholipids flip from the inner to the outer lipidic layer) that mark them to be removed by other cells. Sometimes you can tell the reaction order from stoichiometry, but ONLY if the reaction is _elementary_ - that means that it happens in one step, with no intermediates. In that case, the reaction order with respect to a reactant is equal to its stoichiometric coefficient, and the overall reaction order is the sum of those. For example: A + B -> C The stoichoimetric coefficient of A is 1, so the reaction is 1st order in A. It's also 1 for B, so the reaction is 1st order in B as well. Then you add their orders together and find that the reaction is 2nd order overall. In practice, reaction order is only determined experimentally, and it's actually what helps us determine the reaction mechanism. For example, if reaction orders line up with stoichiometric coefficients in the equation, you know it's a one-step mechanism. If it doesn't, you can tell there are more steps, and you have to devise a mechanism that agrees with the experimentally determined rate.

text: Neurons are the most unique cells in our body. Some are extremely small, while others are very large. In general, neurons do not repair well. If several neurons were damaged, such as in a spinal cord injury, you already know the individual would be paralyzed and it is unlikely the individual would ever walk again. If a portion of a neuron is damaged, it may or may not be able to find and re-connect with itself. If the axon is damaged, the myelin cells such as Schwann cells form a tunnel to help direct the axon to the other portion. Never-the-less, even after several years, if you touch an area of your body that has a scar, you will realize that touch or feeling over that scar has changed and it is not as sensitive as it once was because the receptors and axons were damaged when the skin was damaged. Now, even though the skin is well healed, the nervous tissue has not healed and therefore the sense of touch is poor over that scar. Epithelial tissue and connective tissue heal well, but nervous tissue does not have the ability to divide and replace neurons that have been damaged so it does not heal well. The function of tertiary and quaternary structure varies depending on type of protein, but in enzymes, the specific shape and configuration of the protein allows the formation of active sites.

It has 4 valence electrons, so it can make a 4+ or a 4- charge. But because of its relatively stable half filled orbital, most of the time it takes part in covalent bonding like in organic molecules. The net result is that it doesn't really change in size. Also cells can manufacture membrane phospholipids in the cytosol. This is important for cell growth so that eventually division is possible.

text: Hydrogen does not follow the octet rule, so that is part of why H2 is stable. Note: H2 is stable, but it is quite reactive. The octet rule follows from the energetic favorability of having both the s and p subshells either completely empty or completely full. There is no p subshell in shell number 1, so that is part of why the lightest elements do not follow the octet rule (there are other reasons). There are many considerations as to what does or does not make an atom with a particular electron configuration reactive or nonreactive. So, while the octet rule is a convenient rule of thumb, the reality of chemistry is much, much more complicated. So, with chemistry, there are many competing factors that affect how elements behave, so you cannot just take a single rule and insist or suspect that every element must necessarily follow that rule. It doesn't work that way. You have to take all of the factors into consideration to predict how an element might behave. NOTE: The Pauli exclusion principle is one of the few laws that all of the elements always obey. But the octet rule is not always followed. Meisosi II is a restorer. Why? Because the final product of meiosis * gametes * is_ Haploid cells. Remember, eggs and sperm are haploid, which makes sense. Why are they haploid? Otherwise, in each meiotic cycle, the number of chromosomes will double, resulting in polyploid and polyploid fertilized eggs (incompatible with life). To avoid all this, meiosis II is a reduction.

text: Whether a bond is perfectly non-polar or polar depends on the electronegativity differences between the two bonded atoms. There is a spectrum that ranges from the two extremes of non-polar covalent to ionic, with covalent polar in between. Even though two bonded atoms may be different, their differences in electronegativity might be slight and thus may still be bonding with a relatively equal sharing of electrons, such is the case of carbon bonded to hydrogen. The greater the electronegativity difference, the more the bond approaches the extreme of being ionic. About NaCl, there is a huge difference in electronegativity between the two atoms and it makes sense that this bond is ionic. Looking at C-O bonds, this electronegativity difference lies somewhere between the two extremes (non-polar covalent and ionic), a midpoint where bonds are considered polar covalent. All eukaryotic cells have microtubule organizing centers in animals cells centrosomes are one kind of MTOC, but plant cells have microtubule organizing centers without needing centrioles.

The greater the electronegativity difference, the more the bond approaches the extreme of being ionic. text: once the sodium gave up its electron to hydrogen, it has a full shell like a noble gas, meaning it doesn't want to react. The only thing left for that H to react with is another H, forming H2. Sodium is not electronegative. It is electropositive being in group one of the periodic table.  You wouldn't know for sure, but there are a couple of factors to consider. The carbons on the end (i.e. the CH3 groups) have more H's than the middle CH2 group(s), so statistically there is a higher chance of one of these H's reacting just based on numbers. Also, the CH3 groups are more accessible, so we might expect that these would react more quickly and thus dominate in kinetically controlled reactions. In terms of thermodynamics, radicals are missing an electron (compared to a full octet) so are electron poor. Thus, their order of stability mirrors that of carbocations: more highly substituted carbon radicals are more stable than primary carbon radicals.

text: Two positive charges repel, pushing each other apart. The _magnitude_ of the repelling force is proportional to the product of the two charges. The forces don't cancel each other. Each charge feels the same force, but in opposite directions. Suppose you hold the two positive charges in either hand. If you push them closer together your hands will feel the repelling force. As long as you hold them still your muscles have to provide a corresponding force make them stay put. In that sense you are providing a balancing or cancelling force to the charges. If you let the charges go your balancing muscle force goes away and they fly off in opposite directions. Through transpiration water forms droplets on the surface of the leaves. Those droplets transform into water vapor and leave the plant surface and become part of humidity in the atmosphere. That way water is back to the water cycle.

text: sexual reproduction evolved via natural selection. Some very primitive form of sexual reproduction (probably just sharing DNA randomly between single cells) led to greater variation in one population vs another. On a population scale, sexual reproduction clearly offers a selective advantage. The new-found variation means that the population as a whole can thrive in a wider variety of conditions because individuals are less similar to each other and the population as a whole can therefore survive in a wider variety of conditions. For example, let's say there is a population of cells that normally can survive in only dry, hot conditions. Let's say that through random mutation (which is pretty rare), one member of that population develops an allele of a gene that allows it to survive in humid conditions, and another member develops an allele of a different gene that allows it to survive in cold conditions. If the population can only reproduce asexually (i.e. by budding off clones), you would never find an individual that could survive both humidity AND cold. So, if the desert where this population of cells lives cooled AND humidified (maybe there's an ice age), none of the individuals of that asexually reproducing population would survive. BUT, if they did reproduce sexually, there could be an individual with BOTH new alleles who could survive both cold AND humidity. So in this scenario, sexual reproduction is a selective advantage over asexual reproduction. However, the original version of sexual reproduction was probably very, very simple compared to how it works in humans - remember, our version of sexual reproduction has had a ton of time to evolve its complexities. The order is not random. It is determined by the structure of the sulfonyl chloride. In methanesulfonyl chloride, the S atom enhances the acidity of the a-hydrogen. So the pyridine can remove it in the first step. In p-toluenesulfonyl chloride, there is no a hydrogen, so the only useful choice is for the alcohol to attack the S.

text: New genetic traits occurring that are not the result of novel gene combinations happen by mutations. These mutations happen as the gametes are forming. This is not all that unusual, most gametes have a few mutations. Most of the time the mutation has little or no effect on the phenotype. When there is an effect that matters, it is usually harmful. But, once in a while, the mutation is beneficial. There are many kinds of mutations. This is gene duplication. In gene duplication the offspring gets an extra copy of a gene, perhaps even on a completely different chromosome. Sometimes this is catastrophic, but a lot of times it can enhance an existing trait or simply just provide a backup copy of an existing gene. Gene duplication is a very common mutation and there are many genes we have extra copies of. Now, if we have a spare copy of a gene, then some of the time that allows a major mutation to occur in one of the copies without causing a catastrophic problem. Now, in particular, if one of the copies undergoes what is called a frameshift mutation, then that gene will now code for a completely different protein. This might do very little, might be harmful, or might actually cause a new trait to appear rather suddenly. There are documented cases of this kind of mutation. When the temperature of a gas is increased, the molecules have higher kinetic energies. When the molecules move around faster they can configure themselves in more ways than they could have if they had less kinetic energy. More specifically, molecules in an ideal gas follow Maxwell-Boltzmann statistics which imply that the molecules' velocity distribution broadens as the temperature of the system is increased.

text: In Uniform Circular Motion, Magnitude of velocity doesn't vary with time, but direction does. It is only possible when Force applied is perpendicular to the displacement vector (or velocity vector). A centripetal force is required to move a particle in such circular motion, which will be provided by magnetic force in this case. If there is no gravity then it will do exactly what the sugar particles did in the video (this is because in the video there was no gravity). But if there is gravity then... The containers are like scales: it always has to equal up (number of sand and water molecules added together) but because there is gravity, the sand would float down to the bottom of the containers, and because there gazillions of these sand molecules there is an extremely small change that both tanks will have the same amount of sand resting at the bottom of it. That means that the scales have got their first weights (the sand molecules). Now the water molecules flow around until the side with less sand molecules (the lighter side) has enough water molecules added to its weight that it eventually evens out with the side with more sand molecules (the heavier side).

text: With evolution especially, it's important to remember that there are likely many more species in the history of our planet Earth that never made it into the currently observable fossil record. Even when they do make it, they are subject to a study biased by the culture of the people who dig them up. Entire interpretations can be made or broken with the discovery of a new bone or piece of stone tool. We (humans) make memorials out of stone and wood and glass to mark our graves, but do these materials really stand the test of time? Erosion due to weather and chemicals takes it toll, and within the span of a generation, a boulder is reduced to sand. Consider this: how many people in the history of mankind tried to leave their mark on the soil before us? If we can't remember every man, woman, and child who lived and died, how much more so for every insect, reptile, mammal, and fish who came before our time? Fossils are a beautiful thing, but they provide only a glimpse into the past, never the complete picture. Of course, the chances of being remembered by the Earth's rocks increase the more populous your species becomes, or the longer it lasts. 'Strong' and 'weak' acids shouldn't be confused with higher or lower pH. What defines a strong acid is that it disassociates completely in water. What defines a weak acid is that it doesn't disassociate completely in water. For example: If a strong acid is in really low concentration(0,00001M) in one solution, and a weak acid is in relatively high concentration(1M) in another, the H+ concentration would probably be higher in the weak acid solution, and it would therefore have lower pH(despite being the weaker acid.)

text: The currently accepted definition of species says that only individuals of the same species may leave fertile offspring. While interspecies breeding is possible (liger, zebroid, etc) they cannot further reproduce and pass down 'new traits'. From the evolutionary point of view, that way of speciation is not possible (that fast, and dramatic change overnight). It _can_ affect biodiversity, but again on the shorter scale and just temporarily (following the lifetime of that individual). However, that is not likely to happen, because different species have a variety of mechanisms to stop and prevent cross-breeding or pollinating (either they reproduce at different parts of the year, or are physically incompatible, etc). Researchers may do the experiment and force starfishes in an aquarium to breed but that would not make much sense and effect on whole biodiversity oxalic acid is an aldaric acid (a molecule with 2 carboxylic acids) it is easily deprotonated on one end,the other one is harder to remove. it results in a charged compound called a dianion oxalate.

text: Albinism is an autosomal recessive condition, meaning that a person must inherit TWO copies of the affected allele from his/her parents in order to display the phenotype. Thus, if one child is albino, you can assume that the parents are either a) both carriers (i.e. heterozygous for the trait) or b) both affected. Considering your question, we can assume that the parents are both carriers (since the chance that two children would inherit the disease if both parents are albino would be 100%). We must also consider the fact that these are independent events, meaning that having one child with albinism does NOT affect the chance of having another child with the condition. By the rules of probability, this means that we must multiply the number of chances of having a child affected by albinism to figure out the total probability of having TWO children with albinism. So, what is the probability of having a child with albinism given both parents are heterozygous? If you do a punned square for Aa x Aa, you get that the chance of having a child with albinism is 25%. This means that the chance of having a normal child is 75%. So, you just multiply 0.25 by 0.75 and get 0.1875. Thus, the chance of having a normal child is 19% Sulfur doesn't have to follow the octet rule, lots of elements in the third period and below don't have to follow it.

text: the Carbonyl group is how molecules are identified as sugars. The fact that each carbon atom is bonded to Hydroxyl groups except one carbon that is bonded to a Carbonyl group turns it into a sugar. fructose has a carbonyl group. this makes it into a sugar. This means that no matter how many Hydroxyl groups you have on a molecule, if it has a carbonyl group, it can't be an alcohol anymore, instead, it is classified as a sugar. all it takes is one atom for the entire molecule to be radically changed, in this case, the carbonyl group. At the scale of the individual molecule having a positive charge at one end and a negative charge at the other end of a molecule is very different from having no charges at all. The isoelectric point is the pH at which a molecule has a net neutral charge  while this is related to zwitterions, they are not the same thing! Zwitterions are neutral molecules that have at least one group carrying a full positive charge and another carrying a full negative charge. How charged those groups are depends on the pH

text: Using concentrations in the Nernst equation is a simplification. In reality, what we care about is the activity. For solutions, the activity is equal to the concentration, which is why we can get away with just writing concentrations for these species. Pure solids and liquids have an activity of 1, so we can ignore them (since multiplying by 1 doesn't change the value). Most eukaryotic cells only divide in the presence of _mitogens_. Mitogens stimulate cell division by increasing the amount of _G1 cyclins_, which trigger cells to enter _Start_ (i.e., the point in G1 which cells commit to divide). G1 cyclins regulate entry into _Start_ by turning on expression of G1/S and S cyclins. Thus, G1 cyclin concentrations are elevated during the phases that require G1/S and S cyclins. This explains why the levels of G1 cyclin span a large portion of the cyclin expression cycle. At what point in the cell cycle would cells no longer require mitogens for division? As mentioned above, at _start_, cyclin G1/S is activated by G1 cyclin and through a positive feedback loop, G1/S cyclin is able to maintain its own activity and G1 cyclin and mitogens are no longer needed to drive the cell cycle. This explains why the levels of G1 begin to plateau. Yet, G1 cyclin is still needed for S cyclin activation, so G1 cyclin concentrations does not rapidly fall after the activation of G1/S cyclin.

context1: Using concentrations in the Nernst equation is a simplification. In reality, what we care about is the activity. For solutions, the activity is equal to the concentration, which is why we can get away with just writing concentrations for these species. Pure solids and liquids have an activity of 1, so we can ignore them (since multiplying by 1 doesn't change the value).

Mitogens stimulate cell division by increasing the amount of _G1 cyclins_, which trigger cells to enter _Start_ (i.e., the point in G1 which cells commit to divide). This explains why the levels of G1 cyclin span a large portion of the cyclin expression cycle. At what point in the cell cycle would cells no longer require mitogens for division? As mentioned above, at _start_, cyclin G1/S is activated by G1 cyclin and through a positive feedback loop, G1/S cyclin is able to maintain its own activity and G1 cyclin and mitogens are no longer needed to drive the cell cycle. This explains why the levels of G1 begin to plateau. Yet, G1 cyclin is still needed for S cyclin activation, so G1 cyclin concentrations does not rapidly fall after the activation of G1/S cyclin.

text: Different DNA molecules (and even regions within DNA molecules) can have different ratios of GC to AT base pairs. This is known as the GC content (and reportedly varies from 75% to 13.5%). GC content affects the physical properties of DNA - the most important being the ''melting temperature' (Tm) - the temperature around which two strands of DNA will separate. The GC content of an organisms genome does affect how abundant different codons can be and this will influence the abundance of the various amino acids within the proteins in that organism. the waves get reflected when they hit a fixed point because of newtons third law, so the pulse tries to move the wall up like it did to the string but since wall is denser than the string it hits the string back with a pulse in the opposite direction with equal magnitude which is why you get a inverted pulse.

text: Bear in mind that the aforementioned molecules are in a hectic state, frequently colliding and interacting. The possibilities you theorized in your questions do indeed occur; this is precisely why organic reactions almost never have 100% yields of the desired products. Mechanisms presented in lectures are not telling you exactly how each type of molecule in a solution interacts with the others, but rather highlights a certain pathway that produces the product of interest. Furthermore, these mechanisms are often simplified, and side reactions can also eventually give rise to the major products via more complicated pathways. Extending this concept to this particular reaction, remember that the steps are in equilibrium, meaning that although other products (such as the ones you mentioned) do form, they are less stable and easily revert back to their previous forms; given enough time, the reaction will favor the most stable product(s). The Fischer esterification is actually a good example of this: the reaction takes anywhere from 1-10 hours to go to completion! Current is related to the number of electron flowing past a point per second. So its actually possible to be in a situation in which the energy of the photons will increase but for the current to decrease.

text: Neither mitosis nor meiosis are cycles. They are both processes involved in two different types of cell division and both are parts of cycles. Mitotic divisions can happen repeatedly as part of the mitotic cell cycle. Meiotic divisions happen as part of a more complex cycle that includes fertilization (fusion of two gametes) to form a zygote. That zygote has the potential to become a new organism that will then have some cells that undergo meiosis to produce new gametes. Multicellular organisms contain many cells and the germ line cells$ in animals undergo both mitosis and meiosis. The mitotic divisions maintain the population of germ cells and the excess cells undergo meiosis to produce gametes. Does that help? $Note: The cells that can undergo meiosis. You would have two half reactions; an oxidation half reaction and a reduction half reaction. Remember: oxidation is losing electrons, reduction is gaining electrons. So the half reaction that has some element or compound plus electrons on the REACTANTS side would be the reduction reaction. The half reaction with some element or compound plus electrons on the PRODUCTS side is the oxidation reaction.

That zygote has the potential to become a new organism that will then have some cells that undergo meiosis to produce new gametes. Multicellular organisms contain many cells and the germ line cells$ in animals undergo both mitosis and meiosis. The mitotic divisions maintain the population of germ cells and the excess cells undergo meiosis to produce gametes. Does that help? $Note: The cells that can undergo meiosis.

text: Whenever you swallow something, the muscle contractions pull up on the hyoid bone, which draws the larynx up and tips the epiglottis backwards to cover the opening of the trachea. You can feel part of this process happen if you lightly press on the top of your thyroid cartilage. When you breathe you don't need to swallow the air, so the muscles don't contract and the trachea stays open. All the force driving the air comes from a partial vacuum in the lungs, so it travels through the lower pressure of the trachea rather than the oesophagus. That's a good question and I don't think there is a clear cut answer. As you recognise, there are degrees of solubility and many substances are essentially insoluble yet still have a little bit of solubility. In fact, if a reaction is taking place in water, then that is because some ions have come away from the solid to engage in the reaction. But to answer your question, I think most of the time you would say that the substance was a solid if it was practically insoluble or only slightly soluble in water. Also, if a product precipitates out from a reaction then that would always be given a state symbol of solid. In some ways, it becomes clearer in ionic equations such as: AgCl (s) <---> Ag^+ (aq) + Cl^- (aq) This recognises that some of the silver chloride has dissolved, despite silver chloride being insoluble (the equilibrium will be well over to the left in this equation). Ions are always given the aqueous state symbol. At a professional level, chemists seldom include the state symbol when writing chemical equations so this question doesn't arise.
question: How does the body know what to send down the esophagus and what to send down the trachea?
context1: Whenever you swallow something, the muscle contractions pull up on the hyoid bone, which draws the larynx up and tips the epiglottis backwards to cover the opening of the trachea. You can feel part of this process happen if you lightly press on the top of your thyroid cartilage. When you breathe you don't need to swallow the air, so the muscles don't contract and the trachea stays open. All the force driving the air comes from a partial vacuum in the lungs, so it travels through the lower pressure of the trachea rather than the oesophagus.

Also, if a product precipitates out from a reaction then that would always be given a state symbol of solid. In some ways, it becomes clearer in ionic equations such as: AgCl (s) <---> Ag^+ (aq) + Cl^- (aq) This recognises that some of the silver chloride has dissolved, despite silver chloride being insoluble (the equilibrium will be well over to the left in this equation). text: A photon is a particle of light. light is energy. Sometimes we think of light as being a wave in the form of an electro-magnetic wave but other times it can be described as a particle. A photon in this case, is 1 unit of light with a variable amount of energy which depends on its frequency. In classical mechanics, the position and momentum variables of a particle CAN vary continuously, the number of possible microstates is actually infinite.

text: Sodium potassium pump is very essential in maintaining the ionic concentratins of the sodium and potassium ions inside and outside cells. There are certain leaking channels which continuously leak potassium outwards, and many other processes which bring sodium in and potassium out. All of these processes are important for the functioning of the cell. The Na-K pump keeps pumping the K and Na appropriately, and maintaining the concentrations overall, and hence the osmolarity of the cell. Osmolarity determines the amount of water inside the cell, which remains well-balanced because of the constant work of the Na-K pump Light is the same entity whether it be on earth, other planets, the sun, or millions of light years away in distant space. Light itself can be thought of as being composed of massless 'particles' called photons which have both particle and wavelike properties. It has what is known as a wave-particle duality. A good demonstration of this is Thomas Young's double slit experiment. Basically he placed a plate in front of screen with two slits (or holes) in the plate which allowed light to pass through and would be detected on the screen behind. The critical aspect was how wide he made the slits. If you make the slits wide light passes straight through and hits the areas of the screen directly opposite of the slits. This is light behaving as a particle. Now if you made the slits super narrow you observe bands of light with different intensity on the screen separated by dark spaces. The bands corresponding to places where light acting as a wave interacted with itself constructively and the dark spaces where it interacted with itself destructively. This is known as interference and its something only waves can perform. Now since he used the same light and observed both wave and particle phenomenon, we can assume that light has both a wave and particle nature to it depending on the situation. Hope that helps.
question: How does the sodium potassium pump help cells prevent losing or gaining too much water?
context1: Sodium potassium pump is very essential in maintaining the ionic concentratins of the sodium and potassium ions inside and outside cells. There are certain leaking channels which continuously leak potassium outwards, and many other processes which bring sodium in and potassium out. All of these processes are important for the functioning of the cell. The Na-K pump keeps pumping the K and Na appropriately, and maintaining the concentrations overall, and hence the osmolarity of the cell. Osmolarity determines the amount of water inside the cell, which remains well-balanced because of the constant work of the Na-K pump

This is known as interference and its something only waves can perform. text: Hydrogen bonds and London dispersion forces are both examples of van der Waals forces, a general term for intermolecular interactions that do not involve covalent bonds or ions. In a water molecule, the bond connecting the oxygen to each hydrogen is a polar bond. In a polar covalent bond containing hydrogen (e.g., an O-H bond in a water molecule). The hydrogen-oxygen bond in water is not a hydrogen bond, but only a polar covalent bond. However, after hydrogen and oxygen have formed a water molecule and hydrogen has become partially positive, then the hydrogen atoms become attracted to nearby negative charges and are 'available' for hydrogen bonding. The hydrogen bond between these hydrogen atoms and the nearby negatively charged atoms is weak and doesn't involve the covalent bond between hydrogen and oxygen. Thus, hydrogen bonding is a van der Waals force.  Every water molecule dissociates into OH and H+ atoms, same goes vice versa ion condensation. H+ comes from another sugar molecule, attached to oxygen in the OH- group. In condensation reaction you got water molecule from 2 0H groups: but one H+ has to stay within C and create a glycosidic bond. The other H+ and OH- create H2O.
question: How does the hydrogen bond in it conform to their definition of van dear Waals forces, which don't involve covalent bonds?

The hydrogen-oxygen bond in water is not a hydrogen bond, but only a polar covalent bond. However, after hydrogen and oxygen have formed a water molecule and hydrogen has become partially positive, then the hydrogen atoms become attracted to nearby negative charges and are 'available' for hydrogen bonding. The hydrogen bond between these hydrogen atoms and the nearby negatively charged atoms is weak and doesn't involve the covalent bond between hydrogen and oxygen. Thus, hydrogen bonding is a van der Waals force.

text: as the molecular speed increases past a certain threshold, the probability that a certain molecule will oxidize spontaneously through a collision with an oxygen molecule increases greatly. This threshold is called the ignition point. In all substances we call 'flammable' this oxidation is exothermic, bringing the neighbouring molecules past ignition point in a chain reaction. When the sodium ions move down their concentration gradient, the antiporter uses the energy transferred to it to change its shape so that it can accept the other molecules and push them in the opposite direction, against their concentration gradient. You can sort of think of the sodium ions going through the antiporter like taking your hand out of a glove and turning it inside out (and stretching it out), it is then ready to accept a hand going into it (the opposite direction) and help it in by using the stored energy from when your hand stretched it.

text: There are several forces at work inside the nuclei of atoms. The electromagnetic force of the protons wants to push them away from each other. Fusion allows these protons to get close enough together for the stronger, yet short ranged, nuclear force to overpower the electromagnetic force. Neutrons will help add to this nuclear force, but they tend to become unstable when they get into too great of concentration and the weak force will cause them to decay into protons. With all of that to consider, as you get larger and larger nuclei with more protons, the electromagnetic forces increase, as well as the distances in the nuclei, putting more strain on the nuclear forces holding it all together. The ratio of neutrons to protons gradually increases to try to compensate, but this results in the neutrons getting more unstable themselves, resulting in more opportunity for weak forces to destabilize them. Hence, larger atoms become more unstable. There are believed to be certain numbers/ratios that are inherently more stable. These are called magic numbers. Carbon will be in the middle to that 3 oxygen will be attached and to one of the oxygen a hydrogen grp will be attached .between carbon and oxygen their will be a partial double bond present(a single bond present for the one attached to hydrogen) 2.Carbon will be in the middle to that 3 oxygen will be attached and to 2 of the oxygen a hydrogen grp will be attached . there will be a double bond between one of the oxygen and carbon atom.
question: Why are the elements made in laboratories unstable?
context1: There are several forces at work inside the nuclei of atoms. The electromagnetic force of the protons wants to push them away from each other. Fusion allows these protons to get close enough together for the stronger, yet short ranged, nuclear force to overpower the electromagnetic force. Neutrons will help add to this nuclear force, but they tend to become unstable when they get into too great of concentration and the weak force will cause them to decay into protons. With all of that to consider, as you get larger and larger nuclei with more protons, the electromagnetic forces increase, as well as the distances in the nuclei, putting more strain on the nuclear forces holding it all together. The ratio of neutrons to protons gradually increases to try to compensate, but this results in the neutrons getting more unstable themselves, resulting in more opportunity for weak forces to destabilize them. Hence, larger atoms become more unstable. There are believed to be certain numbers/ratios that are inherently more stable. These are called magic numbers.

text: the changing concentrations have nothing to do with the order, and in fact, the way in which they change *is* in fact the order. So, if they were not changing, then we cannot determine the order. cancelling out the effect of all but one reactant is the standard method of finding the order. The method used is called flooding. In this, all but one are taken in very high concentrations (excess) such that even if the entire reaction were to take place and our reactant (in small amount) were to be entirely consumed, the net change in the concentrations of the remaining would be negligible, and hence can be taken as zero (constant concentration). Hence all their concentration along with the actual rate constant now form a new constant which can be computed while measuring the rate with respect to one reactant only. By doing this for every reactant, the original constant can be determined. To note, although we are taking the concentrations to be constant, it is just a mathematical step (the change being closed to zero) and not in reality, since their concentrations need to change for the reaction to occur (or at least, they need to be used up) The 1,3-dipolar part is referring to the ozone (O3). A dipole is a compound that is neutral overall, but carries a positive and a negative charge (like O3). The 1,3 part is because, if you number the oxygens in ozone, it is oxygens 1 and 3 that react in the cycloaddition.
question: Is there anyway to cancel out the effect of other reactant?
context1: the changing concentrations have nothing to do with the order, and in fact, the way in which they change *is* in fact the order. So, if they were not changing, then we cannot determine the order. cancelling out the effect of all but one reactant is the standard method of finding the order. The method used is called flooding. In this, all but one are taken in very high concentrations (excess) such that even if the entire reaction were to take place and our reactant (in small amount) were to be entirely consumed, the net change in the concentrations of the remaining would be negligible, and hence can be taken as zero (constant concentration). Hence all their concentration along with the actual rate constant now form a new constant which can be computed while measuring the rate with respect to one reactant only. By doing this for every reactant, the original constant can be determined. To note, although we are taking the concentrations to be constant, it is just a mathematical step (the change being closed to zero) and not in reality, since their concentrations need to change for the reaction to occur (or at least, they need to be used up)

text: The nucleophile is not reacting with the solvent. It is being surrounded by a shell of solvent molecules. The F- ion is small, so it has a high charge density, and the water molecules are held tightly to it. The I- ion is large, so it has a low charge density, and the water molecules are held loosely to it. A nucleophile has to push the solvent molecules out of the way in order to attack the substrate, so F- is a poorer nucleophile in a polar protic solvent.  There is two type force inside atom. Repulsive force between protons and attractive force between electron and nucleus. If atom is stable than atom should overcome the repulsive force in other way talk about this more attractive force than repulsive force.
question: Why is I- a better nucleophile in a polar protic solvent?
context1: The nucleophile is not reacting with the solvent. It is being surrounded by a shell of solvent molecules. The F- ion is small, so it has a high charge density, and the water molecules are held tightly to it. The I- ion is large, so it has a low charge density, and the water molecules are held loosely to it. A nucleophile has to push the solvent molecules out of the way in order to attack the substrate, so F- is a poorer nucleophile in a polar protic solvent.

text: Facilitated delineates that something is required for diffusion to take place, that is, the small transmembrane protein that allows the movement of the water molecules across the plasma membranes. Generally speaking, the movement of water via osmosis is through simple diffusion of the water molecules across a semi-permeable membrane, from a more dilute to a more concentrated region. Since this diffusion process does not require the additional 'help' of an embedded integral protein, the diffusion is not 'facilitated.' Fluids exert pressure in all directions. So the parts of the fluid on the left (P1) of the highlighted region are exerting a pressure on the highlighted region _from the left_. They still exert a pressure in all directions, but the only part of this pressure that is relevant is the part that is pushing the highlighted region. So when the fluid flows from right to left, the parts of the fluid on the left (P1) still exert a pressure on the highlighted region from the left. Similarly, P2 always exerts a pressure from the right because it is on the right side of the highlighted region (the section we are interested in). Whether work done is negative or positive depends on which direction the fluid is flowing and whether the work done is helping the movement or hindering it. When the fluid is moving from left to right, work done to the right is positive (as it is in the same direction as the flow) and work done to the left is negative (as it hinders the flow). When the fluid is moving from right to left, work done to the left is positive and work done to the right is negative

text: We can't 'see' the electrons with our instruments, but we can see the atoms and measure their bond lengths and bond angles. That's why we ignore the lone pair electrons in determining *molecular geometry*. We must, however, consider the lone pairs in determining the *electron geometry* about an atom. Like the reason we are made up of many different cells versus one big cell. Absorption by little cells is much more efficient than large cells. So you have the two smaller lungs and they are divided into even smaller bronchioles and they are covered in villi to maximize surface area. One big lung wouldn't be as efficient at maximizing surface area. Plus, there is always an advantage to redundancy. You can lose one lung to damage or disease and continue to live but one big lung would be at risk.

text: around half of the nitrogen in a plant is incorporated into proteins. These will be broken down to amino acids (or small peptides) during digestion and absorbed. A significant amount will also be incorporated into nucleic acids (RNA and DNA), which will also be broken down and absorbed The reason why N-14 doesn't decay is that the neutrons to protons ratio is 1, and the nucleus is quite small. In general, wondering whether an element/isotope is stable we have to consider two factors - ratio of neutrons to protons and 'size'. The first should be approx. 1 for small nucleuses (let's say to Ca) and for bigger max. 1.6, because than there won't be too much neutrons (what would cause beta- decay) or too much protons (beta+ decay). The second factor is also important - the bigger the nucleus is the less stable it is. The biggest known stable isotope is Bi-209, and all above naturally divide in alpha decay.

context2: The reason why N-14 doesn't decay is that the neutrons to protons ratio is 1, and the nucleus is quite small. In general, wondering whether an element/isotope is stable we have to consider two factors - ratio of neutrons to protons and 'size'. The first should be approx. 1 for small nucleuses (let's say to Ca) and for bigger max. 1.6, because than there won't be too much neutrons (what would cause beta- decay) or too much protons (beta+ decay). The second factor is also important - the bigger the nucleus is the less stable it is. The biggest known stable isotope is Bi-209, and all above naturally divide in alpha decay.

text: Sound waves never reach your brain. They reach your eardrums, where they are converted to electrical signals, which then go to your brain. Whenever you are trying to figure out 'where did the energy go' and you can't seem to find it, the answer is usually 'heat'. Light is the same entity whether it be on earth, other planets, the sun, or millions of light years away in distant space. Light itself can be thought of as being composed of massless 'particles' called photons which have both particle and wavelike properties. It has what is known as a wave-particle duality. A good demonstration of this is Thomas Young's double slit experiment. Basically he placed a plate in front of screen with two slits (or holes) in the plate which allowed light to pass through and would be detected on the screen behind. The critical aspect was how wide he made the slits. If you make the slits wide light passes straight through and hits the areas of the screen directly opposite of the slits. This is light behaving as a particle. Now if you made the slits super narrow you observe bands of light with different intensity on the screen separated by dark spaces. The bands corresponding to places where light acting as a wave interacted with itself constructively and the dark spaces where it interacted with itself destructively. This is known as interference and its something only waves can perform. Now since he used the same light and observed both wave and particle phenomenon, we can assume that light has both a wave and particle nature to it depending on the situation. Hope that helps.
question: Where does the energy specifically transfers after the sound waves reaches our brain?
context1: Sound waves never reach your brain. They reach your eardrums, where they are converted to electrical signals, which then go to your brain. Whenever you are trying to figure out 'where did the energy go' and you can't seem to find it, the answer is usually 'heat'.
context2: Light is the same entity whether it be on earth, other planets, the sun, or millions of light years away in distant space. The bands corresponding to places where light acting as a wave interacted with itself constructively and the dark spaces where it interacted with itself destructively. This is known as interference and its something only waves can perform. Now since he used the same light and observed both wave and particle phenomenon, we can assume that light has both a wave and particle nature to it depending on the situation. Hope that helps.

text: What position humans really hold in the food chain is a topic that has recently come under debate. we don't really have natural predators, and we can easily hunt and eat even the largest of animals. However, studies concerning the trophic level of humans have shown that humans are similar to pigs and anchovies when it comes to overall diet, and are nowhere near the meat-only diets of the apex predators (this rank may change in the near future, as veganism and vegetarianism are gaining popularity). As for trophic levels, because of the fact that humans are omnivorous, they do not fall under a set, 'clear' trophic level. They can fall under level 2 (a human eats seaweed), level 3 (a human eats a lobster), or level 4 (a human eats an octopus). This can also happen if a human eats an omnivorous animal, who also does not have a set trophic level (a human eats bear meat). Rest of organelles are around the nucleus and the mitotic spindle. Kinetochore makes sure chromosomes attach to the mitotic spindle. regardless of the nucleus, centrosome and centriole make sure that mitosis proceeds as expected.

text: The deprotonation can occur at any of the resonating forms, get a mixture of products. It isn't as important on an unsubstituted benzene ring, the resonance structures become more important with reactions of substituted benzene rings, like Aniline or Toluene. The reason sodium and chlorine are so volatile is because they are extremely unstable. Chlorine's last shell has one too few electrons, and is therefore searching anywhere it can for that last electron. Sodium, on the other hand, has only one electron in its last shell, ergo it searches everywhere for something to give up that extra electron to. When sodium meets chlorine, the sodium gives its extra electron to chlorine (which has the one missing electron), which effectively creates a stable compound, NaCl, or halite (common table salt)

text: If you look at the periodic table, you can see Cadmium (Cd) belongs to the 12th group. The periodic table is organized so that the 2 in '12' is equivalent to the amount of electrons the element has in its valence shell. That means Cadmium has 2 electrons in its valence shell. An atom of Cadmium has an oxidation of 2+ because it tends to lose those 2 electrons in its valence shell in order to stabilize, therefore having a positive charge of 2 Electric potential would increase when resistance increases given a constant current. Voltage would have to be higher to maintain the same current when resistance is higher. When people attach a battery in a conducting wire the negative terminal starts repelling all the electrons and positive terminal starts attracting them, this make the electron (which were sitting idly in the wire) moves, but what happens when electrons reach positive terminal, here the role of cells comes in, what actually a cell do is it carries out some chemicals reaction and make those charges move up again to negative terminal, once more those charges (electrons) got repelled by negative terminal and attracted by positive terminal, same process goes on until all the chemicals inside the cell gets exhausted (this is what an electric current actually is). So the cell is doing some work on charges to make them move up against the electric force (that is what we call voltage) and so our charges when they move up they have some store energies in them, people say they have high electrical potential energy, when they pass across a resistance (e.g. wire) they lose some of these energy to them (touch a bulb ,you will find it hot). Now our charges (electrons) have less energy stored in them, when these low energy electrons reach to our cell, it has done more work to make electrons gain same energy, so people say it must provide high potential.

So the cell is doing some work on charges to make them move up against the electric force (that is what we call voltage) and so our charges when they move up they have some store energies in them, people say they have high electrical potential energy, when they pass across a resistance (e.g. wire) they lose some of these energy to them (touch a bulb ,you will find it hot). text: Light slows down when it goes from air to glass, and then it speeds up when it goes from glass to air. When it speeds up or slows down like this and it hits the air/glass boundary at an angle, the path of the light gets bent. This is called refraction, and sal has a video that explains it. The angle of refraction is governed by Snell's Law. A prism is shaped so that it bends the light twice, in the same direction both times. The amount that the light gets bent depends a little bit on the frequency of the light. So when you put white light into the prism, the light doesn't all get bent the same amount, which means that it comes out spread out into a spectrum. chlorophyll doesn't reflect green light, the natural shade of the whole plant is green, the true color, absorbing red and blue light from the sun's uv rays, then making the overall shade of the plant green because of the thylakoid
question: How does light travel so fast?
context1: Light slows down when it goes from air to glass, and then it speeds up when it goes from glass to air. When it speeds up or slows down like this and it hits the air/glass boundary at an angle, the path of the light gets bent. This is called refraction, and sal has a video that explains it. The angle of refraction is governed by Snell's Law. A prism is shaped so that it bends the light twice, in the same direction both times. The amount that the light gets bent depends a little bit on the frequency of the light. So when you put white light into the prism, the light doesn't all get bent the same amount, which means that it comes out spread out into a spectrum.

text: both alleles will be transcribed and translated - generally a gene will be transcribed multiple times resulting in a pool (population) of mRNA molecules$. These mRNAs will then be translated (again often multiple times) into proteins he O does act as a nucleophile in competition with N, but it's a dead-end process. Reaction with O gives the reversible formation of a hemiketal. Reaction with N forms the oxime in an essentially irreversible process as the adduct dehydrates. text: New genetic traits occurring that are not the result of novel gene combinations happen by mutations. These mutations happen as the gametes are forming. This is not all that unusual, most gametes have a few mutations. Most of the time the mutation has little or no effect on the phenotype. When there is an effect that matters, it is usually harmful. But, once in a while, the mutation is beneficial. There are many kinds of mutations. This is gene duplication. In gene duplication the offspring gets an extra copy of a gene, perhaps even on a completely different chromosome. Sometimes this is catastrophic, but a lot of times it can enhance an existing trait or simply just provide a backup copy of an existing gene. Gene duplication is a very common mutation and there are many genes we have extra copies of. Now, if we have a spare copy of a gene, then some of the time that allows a major mutation to occur in one of the copies without causing a catastrophic problem. Now, in particular, if one of the copies undergoes what is called a frameshift mutation, then that gene will now code for a completely different protein. This might do very little, might be harmful, or might actually cause a new trait to appear rather suddenly. There are documented cases of this kind of mutation. The main principle is that when you neutralise an acid and base, moles acid = moles base You should also have the volume of base that was titrated because that will have been in the burette so was measured. concentration = moles / volume Or rearranged: moles = concentration x volume So calculate moles of base If the stoichiometry from the balanced equation is 1:1 then this is equal to the moles of acid. If it isn't then you'll need to account for that. Now you have moles of acid, and the initial volume so just use the previous equation: concentration = moles / volume Now I've explained the method, there is a shortcut you can use here. C1V1/n1 = C2V2/n2 where n1 and n2 are the coefficients of the acid and base in the balanced equation. You will always know 5/6 of the values in that.

text: Being allosteric lets people know that the inhibitor binds somewhere other than the active site, where the substrate binds. The location that the allosteric inhibitor binds is called the allosteric site. Because it isn't competing for the same binding site as the substrate, people can tell that it is non-competitive as the substrate will still be able to bond at the active site. Smooth Muscle Skeletal is voluntary, while cardiac muscle is involuntary (appears striated under the microscope; controls the heart). Smooth Muscle is involuntary as well-smooth muscle is responsible for involuntary movement such as breathing, digestion, peristalsis, and blinking. The diaphragm is responsible for breathing. When it contracts, the lungs are filled with air, and when the diaphragm relaxes, the air is forced from your lungs.

text: Microtubules and their associated proteins are somewhat self-organizing. microtubules can form spindle like structures in vitro without a centrosome. All eukaryotic cells have microtubule organizing centers in animals cells centrosomes are one kind of MTOC, but plant cells have microtubule organizing centers without needing centrioles. Natural selection is based upon the premise that the most fit organism for an environment (so the organism which has the best traits for a given set of circumstances) will inevitably produce the most offspring due to it being the most fit. As such it will pass on more of its genetic information to the next generation. Those organisms who are less fit for an environment, will not produce as many offspring, and their genetic information won't be as prevalent in the next generation of their species. As time progresses, the most fit organism's preferred genetic traits (the traits that made the organism fit) will become more and more prevalent in the species. That is nature selecting for the most fit organism's traits, hence the name Natural Selection.

text: The law of conservation of mass by Antoine Lavoisier states that mass can neither by created or destroyed. Suppose you burn a piece of paper. Ash is created and some fumes are generated. Now, if we add the mass of the ash and the fumes, we will see that the mass of the original paper and the the end product (ash and fumes) is the same. We can see some other examples also. Similarly, if We have one oxygen atom on one side and two oxygen atoms on the other side due to the reaction, this wouldn't be reasonable with the experiment we made by burning the paper. Hence, we balance the equation. through cellular respiration one can make around 30-34 ATP. Which is a lot. 2 - 3 ATP is nothing for a multicellular organism like a plant. this only works for unicellular/extremely simple organisms, like yeast. In fact, humans undergo anaerobic respiration if unable to get oxygen. anaerobic respiration provides around 2 - 3 ATP.

text: When the C-C bond breaks, the right hand carbon gets a positive charge. The lone pair from the O moves in to make a pi bond and neutralize the charge, but the O atom still has eight electrons in its valence shell. If complex 2 got the electrons first then moving the electrons to complex 1 would 'uphill' (endergonic)! the point of these reactions is to create as large a "proton" gradient (PMF) as possible (by pumping as many H+ across the membrane as possible). complex 2 is designed to ignore NADH and thus more of the energy associated with the electrons in NADH is converted into energy stored in the PMF.

text: Vector plasmids are generally small enough that it's uptake is negligible to the overall size of DNA in the host. In cases where the host nucleus is smaller, bacteriaphage viruses with individual strands are used as vectors, and only inject small amounts of genetic material.  Oxidation originally referred to reactions with oxygen. So compounds like FeO and Fe2O3 were called ferrous and ferric oxides, while SnO and SnO2 were called stannous and stannic oxides. In 1919 Alfred Stock suggested that the names should use Roman numerals in parentheses, to make the names iron(II), iron(III), tin(II), and tin(IV) oxides. In 1940 the IUPAC recommended that the term 'Stock number' (I, II, III, IV, etc.) be replaced by the term 'oxidation number' with Arabic numerals (1, 2, 3, 4, etc.). In 1990 it adopted the current 'rule-based' system (H = +1, O = -2, etc.) for determining oxidation numbers.

text: A membrane bound nucleus is basically the control center of a eukaryotic cell. It houses the genetic information (DNA and RNA). It is called membrane boundbecause the nucleus is surrounded by membranes. These membranes are in the nuclear envelope, which lets RNA as well as other things go outside the nucleus and into the cell. Prokaryotic cells can survive without membrane bound nuclei because their genetic information is in the cytoplasm. The cytoplasm is the part of the cell outside the nucleus. from both a technical and practical point of view: Technically, lets say that maybe once upon a time, there were only brown-eyed humans. Then, one day, while a baby was being created in the mother's body, the genetics made a mistake while creating the baby, creating a little oopsie in the genetic material. We usually think of mutants as horrible half-humans with disfigurations, but originally, things like blue eyes were mutations in the human genome reflected in their phenotype (appearance). Practically, variation is really great for all living things. Say there's a whole field of purple and white flowers, and one day a disease comes along that, because the two flower colors are slightly genetically different, can only kill the purple flowers. If the species had no variation, they would have all died, but the white flowers were saved due to their differences.
question: How can prokaryotes survive without the membrane bound nucleus?
context1: A membrane bound nucleus is basically the control center of a eukaryotic cell. It houses the genetic information (DNA and RNA). It is called membrane boundbecause the nucleus is surrounded by membranes. These membranes are in the nuclear envelope, which lets RNA as well as other things go outside the nucleus and into the cell. Prokaryotic cells can survive without membrane bound nuclei because their genetic information is in the cytoplasm. The cytoplasm is the part of the cell outside the nucleus.

text: Parallel conductance is simply a different viewpoint of parallel resistors. It's the same circuit configuration, but uses a different equation. The "conductance" viewpoint looks at a parallel resistor and instead of seeing a 1/R term in the parallel resistor formula, it sees a G = 1/R term. When you use the conductance viewpoint, the formula (G1 + G2 + G3... = Gequiv) strongly resembles the formula for series resistors. That doesn't mean its the same, its just a strong resemblance. Relationships like the one between parallel conductance and series resistance are common in electrical engineering. They are called "Duals" of each other. all aqueous solutions contain a small amount of hydronium (H3O+) and hydroxide (OH-) due to autoionization. This means that processes in cells can use water to get rid of or grab 'protons' (H+) as needed. This could have a small local effect on the pH, but cells are well buffered. Also, in the end the various processes that create and use H+ end up balancing each other out. The only situations where we really need to keep an account of H+ are processes involving membranes (e.g. oxidative phosphorylation) where H+ gradients are created and used.

When you use the conductance viewpoint, the formula (G1 + G2 + G3... = Gequiv) strongly resembles the formula for series resistors. That doesn't mean its the same, its just a strong resemblance. text: There are some enzymes, which work in many pathways. They have relatively poor substrate specificity and this is important, because it's function requires it to do transform so many chemically different substrates into metabolites. Eg: The cytochrome p450 in liver, alcohol dehydrogenase. The former is a very important enzyme system, which plays a role in metabolising (a fancy term for acting upon) a wide variety of foreign substances, which include drugs and toxins. These reactions are the main mechanism of our body to fight drugs, and competitive inhibition is important here when we want to design drug therapies, because if we give two drugs both of which are acted upon by this enzyme, then they shall compete for its binding, and a result both will be metabolised slowly (in relation to if each was given independently). Alcohol dehydrogenase metabolises alcohols, and hence is the reason why methanol is poisonous. IT converts it into the more poisonous methanoic acid. For a patient of methanol poisoning, the main therapy includes giving ethanol, so that it acts as a competitive inhibitor, preventing methanol from forming the harmful metabolite. The more substrate-specific enzymes, do not usually have complications pertaining to competitive inhibitors. Oxygen is more electronegative than carbon and hydrogen. It does attract the bonding electrons significantly more than those two.
question: Would be there to compete with the substrate or only limited amount of reactions suffer through this phenomenon?
context1: There are some enzymes, which work in many pathways. They have relatively poor substrate specificity and this is important, because it's function requires it to do transform so many chemically different substrates into metabolites. Eg: The cytochrome p450 in liver, alcohol dehydrogenase. The former is a very important enzyme system, which plays a role in metabolising (a fancy term for acting upon) a wide variety of foreign substances, which include drugs and toxins. These reactions are the main mechanism of our body to fight drugs, and competitive inhibition is important here when we want to design drug therapies, because if we give two drugs both of which are acted upon by this enzyme, then they shall compete for its binding, and a result both will be metabolised slowly (in relation to if each was given independently). Alcohol dehydrogenase metabolises alcohols, and hence is the reason why methanol is poisonous. IT converts it into the more poisonous methanoic acid. For a patient of methanol poisoning, the main therapy includes giving ethanol, so that it acts as a competitive inhibitor, preventing methanol from forming the harmful metabolite. The more substrate-specific enzymes, do not usually have complications pertaining to competitive inhibitors.
context2: Oxygen is more electronegative than carbon and hydrogen. It does attract the bonding electrons significantly more than those two.

text: Oxygen is more electronegative, and therefore will consume more of the electrons. Sulfur, being less electronegative, cannot have more electrons around it than the more electronegative oxygen. The two extra electrons get added to the central atom. Therefor it only needs one double bond to complete the octet. The charge between the O(-1) and S(+1) balance each other. Krypton is a noble gas, so it's outer most electron shell is full, and therefore it also has a valency of zero. Its outer most shell has 8 electrons and fulfils the octet rule.

text: theories always remain theories, whether they are valid or not. A law is just a precise, usually mathematical, description of some observed phenomena. Laws can be proven false, or rather confined to only be valid under specific circumstances, such as Newton's laws of motion. from both a technical and practical point of view: Technically, lets say that maybe once upon a time, there were only brown-eyed humans. Then, one day, while a baby was being created in the mother's body, the genetics made a mistake while creating the baby, creating a little oopsie in the genetic material. We usually think of mutants as horrible half-humans with disfigurations, but originally, things like blue eyes were mutations in the human genome reflected in their phenotype (appearance). Practically, variation is really great for all living things. Say there's a whole field of purple and white flowers, and one day a disease comes along that, because the two flower colors are slightly genetically different, can only kill the purple flowers. If the species had no variation, they would have all died, but the white flowers were saved due to their differences.

text: There are four so called fundamental forces in the universe. Two nuclear forces that are only relevant in the nucleuses of atoms, the electromagnetic force, and gravity. We can measure these forces, and we have made really good theories that describe the effect they have on the world, but we don't know why they are the way they are. We can only observe the fact that they exist, not explain why they exist. This is why they are called fundamental. A lot of physicists today are working on proving that the four fundamental forces are not actually fundamental, but just different aspects of one truly fundamental force. If this can be done, you could say that gravity is caused by this super-fundamental thing, but you would only have moved the problem back one step, since you still couldn't explain why this thing produced gravity and the other forces. You could just observe that it did. Ultimately it becomes a philosophical question. Why are things the way they are? I don't really know much about how people have answered this question, but I suspect that it might be a meaningless question to ask. Since ultrabithorax is inactivated, no halteres are present. Fly apart from being unable to fly also cannot balance off. That mutation is lethal.

text: Benzoic acid is a common name.numbering the ring because the substituent was on the benzene base, thus you start numbering the 1 carbon where the carboxylic acid functional group is attached to that benzene ring. In the commonly-named form, that carbonyl carbon is considered to be a part of the substituent and thus doesn't add to the ring numbering. You would have two half reactions; an oxidation half reaction and a reduction half reaction. Remember: oxidation is losing electrons, reduction is gaining electrons. So the half reaction that has some element or compound plus electrons on the REACTANTS side would be the reduction reaction. The half reaction with some element or compound plus electrons on the PRODUCTS side is the oxidation reaction.

text: Light is refracted at a very specific angle. I won't go into the mechanics here, but in a raindrop, light in fact undergoes so much refraction it bounces back in the direction the original ray came from, which is why rainbows always appear on the opposite side of the sky as the sun. This means that if you stand with the sun directly behind you, the rays of light form a triangle between you, the observer, the raindrop the light is refracted from and a point on the ground directly ahead of you. Since raindrops will be scattered all across the sky, and you can only observe light refracted at the specific angle, the line along which the light rays travels describes an arc across the sky, and this arc is the rainbow you see. Incidentally, the angle of refraction is also the reason why you can never catch up with a rainbow. The angle, and hence the bow's apparent distance must remain constant with respect to your position. Further apart orbitals are associated with higher energy levels. If an element is more electronegative than it attracts other atoms and makes electrons scroll down to the lower energy states. More electronegative element hogs electrons stronger than a less electronegative element.

The angle, and hence the bow's apparent distance must remain constant with respect to your position.

text: Light does not care that we would like to be able to describe it in terms of things we are familiar with like waves and particles. Light is just light, it behaves how it does. In some situations it behaves in ways that seem particle-like to us, and in other situations it behaves in ways that seem wave-like. But it is neither of those things, it is its own thing, and our intuition that it must behave like the waves or particles we are used to does not apply, so we have to just deal with that and understand it as it is. Waves that we are familiar with need a medium. Light does not. Particles that we are familiar with do not diffract and refract and get polarized. Light does. For hundreds of years the the seeming dual nature of light puzzled physicists, and now finally we have learned that we just have to accept it on its own terms. Most strong acids readily donate a proton to even weak bases like water. Do not just think of electronegativity. Any acid stronger than water will create hydronium. This is the leveling effect of water.

text: The more the substrate, the more the enzymatic activity because an enzyme cannot exhibit catalytic activity on the thin air. When we talk about acid and base reactions, reactivity (and acidity and basicity) is all relative. In this particular case, acetic acid usually acts as the acid (the proton donor) because it is much better acid than water. Part of this has to do with the products of this acid-base reaction: the acetate ion, CH3COO-, is pretty good at stabilizing the negative charge using resonance. You are right that the lone pairs on the oxygens in acetic acid could technically grab a proton from water instead of donating it.Since OH- is a strong base (much stronger than acetic acid), it would grab a proton back and hang onto it very tightly. So that is not a super likely scenario due to acetic acid being a much stronger acid than water, or another way to think about it is that water is a better base than acetic acid.

text: In basic solution, fructose undergoes tautomeric isomerization to form a small amount of aldehyde. If we use R to represent the last four carbons of fructose, we have R-C(=O)CH2OH = R-C(OH)=CHOH = R-CH(OH)CH(=O) or fructose = an enediol = an aldehyde The Tollens reagent oxidizes the aldehyde as fast as it is formed, so the equilibrium keeps getting pulled to the right (Le Chtelier's Principle) until eventually all the fructose is oxidized. It is possible to determine the probability that a single atomic nucleus will 'survive' during a given interval. This probability amounts to 50% for one half-life. In an interval twice as long (2 T) the nucleus survives only with a 25% probability (half of 50%), in an interval of three half-life periods (3 T) only with 12.5% (half of 25%), and so on. You can't, however, predict the time at which a given atomic nucleus will decay. For example, even if the probability of a decay within the next second is 99%, it is nevertheless possible (but improbable) that the nucleus will decay only after millions of years. It's like flipping a coin. If you flip 'heads' ten times in a row, what are the chances that the next flip will be 'heads'. You might say, 'I've flipped ten heads in a row. The next one is much more likely to come up 'tails'. Nevertheless, your chances of flipping heads are the same as before: 1 out of 2. Some nuclei are much luckier at flipping the coin than others. They keep flipping until they get 'tails'; then they decay.
question: How does that happen?
context1: In basic solution, fructose undergoes tautomeric isomerization to form a small amount of aldehyde. If we use R to represent the last four carbons of fructose, we have R-C(=O)CH2OH = R-C(OH)=CHOH = R-CH(OH)CH(=O) or fructose = an enediol = an aldehyde The Tollens reagent oxidizes the aldehyde as fast as it is formed, so the equilibrium keeps getting pulled to the right (Le Chtelier's Principle) until eventually all the fructose is oxidized.
context2: It is possible to determine the probability that a single atomic nucleus will 'survive' during a given interval. This probability amounts to 50% for one half-life. In an interval twice as long (2 T) the nucleus survives only with a 25% probability (half of 50%), in an interval of three half-life periods (3 T) only with 12.5% (half of 25%), and so on. You can't, however, predict the time at which a given atomic nucleus will decay. For example, even if the probability of a decay within the next second is 99%, it is nevertheless possible (but improbable) that the nucleus will decay only after millions of years. It's like flipping a coin. If you flip 'heads' ten times in a row, what are the chances that the next flip will be 'heads'. You might say, 'I've flipped ten heads in a row. The next one is much more likely to come up 'tails'. Nevertheless, your chances of flipping heads are the same as before: 1 out of 2. Some nuclei are much luckier at flipping the coin than others. They keep flipping until they get 'tails'; then they decay.

text: The blood circulates, so that blood will go back, but it won't just stay going back up to the upper part of the body again. It will mix with all the blood from the rest of the body in the heart.  The difference between 'log' and 'ln' is: If you just have 'log' (without a base underneath) it means it is base 10, it is implied. On the other hand if you have 'ln', it is implied that you have a base of 'e' (Euler's constant). Logarithms are largely used in a lot of different fields of study, and their base depends on the phenomenon that you are referring to (basically, you use the one that helps you the best to explain that certain phenomenon), that's why sometimes you might even find bases even different than e or 10, although these are the ones that are used the most.

text: Water is very common in the universe. At this time, we do not know how common liquid water might be in the universe but it is more likely that we would find it in either the solid or vapor form. This situation is nothing special about water, because the liquid phase of any chemical requires just the right ranges of both pressure and temperature. So, the liquid phase of mater is not all that common, relatively speaking. Just think about it, apart from liquid water, how many other naturally-occurring liquids do you encounter in your daily life? However, water does have a fairly wide range of temperatures and pressures it can be a liquid in, so it does have a better chance of being a liquid than many other substances. Hydrogen itself exists as a liquid in only the most extreme conditions, so it is extremely rare. Solid hydrogen is even more rare. Pure hydrogen mostly exists as a plasma in stars or elsewhere as a gas. Light is the same entity whether it be on earth, other planets, the sun, or millions of light years away in distant space. Light itself can be thought of as being composed of massless 'particles' called photons which have both particle and wavelike properties. It has what is known as a wave-particle duality. A good demonstration of this is Thomas Young's double slit experiment. Basically he placed a plate in front of screen with two slits (or holes) in the plate which allowed light to pass through and would be detected on the screen behind. The critical aspect was how wide he made the slits. If you make the slits wide light passes straight through and hits the areas of the screen directly opposite of the slits. This is light behaving as a particle. Now if you made the slits super narrow you observe bands of light with different intensity on the screen separated by dark spaces. The bands corresponding to places where light acting as a wave interacted with itself constructively and the dark spaces where it interacted with itself destructively. This is known as interference and its something only waves can perform. Now since he used the same light and observed both wave and particle phenomenon, we can assume that light has both a wave and particle nature to it depending on the situation. Hope that helps.

Logarithms are largely used in a lot of different fields of study, and their base depends on the phenomenon that you are referring to (basically, you use the one that helps you the best to explain that certain phenomenon), that's why sometimes you might even find bases even different than e or 10, although these are the ones that are used the most. Every water molecule dissociates into OH and H+ atoms, same goes vice versa ion condensation. H+ comes from another sugar molecule, attached to oxygen in the OH- group. In condensation reaction you got water molecule from 2 0H groups: but one H+ has to stay within C and create a glycosidic bond. The other H+ and OH- create H2O.

text: Hybridization is known to happen between what are generally accepted to be different species  sometimes this leads to new species, other times some traits from one species become incorporated into another species.  The way to identify nucleophiles and electrophiles is by differences in electronegativity. Often, when an electronegative atom is bonded to a less electronegative one, the less electronegative atom becomes an electrophile as it has a partial positive charge. Lone pairs of electrons on some atoms can sometimes act as nucleophiles.
