text: We can't 'see' the electrons with our instruments, but we can see the atoms and measure their bond lengths and bond angles. That's why we ignore the lone pair electrons in determining *molecular geometry*. We must, however, consider the lone pairs in determining the *electron geometry* about an atom. paleontologists look first to see whether the fossil in questions has any teeth. this is a big help in determining the foods a dinosaur ate. In general, a meat-eating dinosaur will have long, serrated teeth like steak knives, or small but sharper teeth. Basically, the canines and other teeth used for cutting are more prominent. In omnivores, the canines and back teeth (molars) will both show wear, as both are being used. Plant-eaters would have less canines and more molars; several hadrosaurs had hundreds of molars in the backs of their mouths, to better grind of the tons of plant matter they ate every day (I think most of a brachiosaur's life was spent eating). If there are no teeth available, I believe paleontologists look for other signs, like rocks in the stomach, usually found in plant-eaters (these stones help to grind up plant material) , or other things in the stomach, like that dinosaur's last meal. Claws, teeth, girth size, and other such characteristics can help determine whether a dinosaur was a carnivore/herbivore.
question: Why aren't electrons on the terminal atoms considered?
context1: We can't 'see' the electrons with our instruments, but we can see the atoms and measure their bond lengths and bond angles. If there are no teeth available, I believe paleontologists look for other signs, like rocks in the stomach, usually found in plant-eaters (these stones help to grind up plant material) , or other things in the stomach, like that dinosaur's last meal. text: ATP becomes ADP since ATP stands for Adenosine triphosphate (meaning adenosine with 3 phosphate groups) ADP stands for Adenosine diphosphate with 2 phosphate groups and if it happens to lose one more phosphate group it becomes AMP (Adenosine monophosphate) with 1 phosphate group. Lithium is a stronger reducing agent than all other alkali metals. This is because Lithium (do note that all this is happening in water) has a large hydration energy (because of its small size and high charge density), and this favours the formation of the Li+ cation significantly, making Li the best reducing agent in the periodic table (and amongst alkali metals).

text: When you divide both sides by 20 mL, the units cancel out so it does not matter what you choose. All that matters is that the unit you choose is the same throughout the equation. Dividing 27.4mL by 20mL is the same as dividing 0.0274L by 0.02L. You will get the same number and there will be no units! So, we can say that mL were used simply because the information was given in mL and it would have been unecessary to change. The reaction with water is explosive. However, in the LAH reduction of a carboxylic acid, a solution of the acid in an ether solvent is slowly added to a solution or stirred suspension of LAH in the same solvent. The solutions can be cooled and the rate of addition controlled to keep the reaction slow enough that the hydrogen does not explode.

text: Using concentrations in the Nernst equation is a simplification. In reality, what we care about is the activity. For solutions, the activity is equal to the concentration, which is why we can get away with just writing concentrations for these species. Pure solids and liquids have an activity of 1, so we can ignore them (since multiplying by 1 doesn't change the value). It has to do with symmetry. The C-O bond is indeed quite polarised, but because the CO2 molecule has a linear shape the dipoles from both the C-O bonds cancel out and this results in CO2 being non polar.

text: :Possibly by a large change in temperature or pH, the enzyme would most likely not be able to catalyze the same reactions. It would lose its ability to work properly. AFAiK it covers all forms of desaturation including carbonyls - it definitely is not limited to carbon-carbon bonds. For carbonyls you can see this by looking at the HDI for formaldehyde (methanal). The fully saturated single carbon hydrocarbon (methane) has 4 hydrogens and formaldehyde has 2 - so the HDI is 2, which is due to the pi bond in the carbonyl.

text: Atom have 4 electrons in the outermost shell can actually choose either or even stay neutral. One interesting thing about these types of subshells, is that they are actually somewhat stable. Because of the relative stability, these atoms often form covalent bonds rather than ionic bonds that need a charge. One example is Carbon. It has 4 valence electrons, so it can make a 4+ or a 4- charge. But because of its relatively stable half filled orbital, most of the time it takes part in covalent bonding like in organic molecules. On occasion, Carbon can ionize, most commonly 4+. Both H atoms will have the same electronegativity, which is a long word with the simple meaning of the ability of an atom to attract electrons to itself. Since both H atoms will have same electronegativity, they will pull each other's electrons with the same force. For an ionic bond to occur, the H atom which will accept the electron must pull the other atom's electrons more strongly than the other atom pulls its electrons. In other words, ionic H-H bond is possible only if the two hydrogen atoms have different electronegativity, which is absurd, as they are exactly the same atoms.
question: Will atom need to gain 4 electrons or lose 4 electrons to achieve an octet?

Because of the relative stability, these atoms often form covalent bonds rather than ionic bonds that need a charge. One example is Carbon. It has 4 valence electrons, so it can make a 4+ or a 4- charge. But because of its relatively stable half filled orbital, most of the time it takes part in covalent bonding like in organic molecules. On occasion, Carbon can ionize, most commonly 4+.
context2: Both H atoms will have the same electronegativity, which is a long word with the simple meaning of the ability of an atom to attract electrons to itself. Since both H atoms will have same electronegativity, they will pull each other's electrons with the same force. In other words, ionic H-H bond is possible only if the two hydrogen atoms have different electronegativity, which is absurd, as they are exactly the same atoms.

text: Smooth Muscle Skeletal is voluntary, while cardiac muscle is involuntary (appears striated under the microscope; controls the heart). Smooth Muscle is involuntary as well-smooth muscle is responsible for involuntary movement such as breathing, digestion, peristalsis, and blinking. The diaphragm is responsible for breathing. When it contracts, the lungs are filled with air, and when the diaphragm relaxes, the air is forced from your lungs. you cannot heat steam 'forever'. Like all molecules, when sufficiently hot it will decompose. There is not a set temperature at which it decomposes, it is more of a gradual process as the temperature increases. You start getting significant quantities of water decomposing at around 2500 K. At about 3000 K you get around 50% of water molecules decomposing. Of course, this is a rather hot temperature and it is rather impractical to generate, much less create a container to house the reaction.

When it contracts, the lungs are filled with air, and when the diaphragm relaxes, the air is forced from your lungs.

text: The order is not random. It is determined by the structure of the sulfonyl chloride. In methanesulfonyl chloride, the S atom enhances the acidity of the a-hydrogen. So the pyridine can remove it in the first step. In p-toluenesulfonyl chloride, there is no a hydrogen, so the only useful choice is for the alcohol to attack the S. Randomly occurring mutations in genes keep adding potential new variations in a specie's population. If there is no selection pressure that strongly disfavors the variation, it will get added to the gene pool. Also, If subgroups of that population are separated and exposed to differing environmental pressures, the subgroups can accumulate enough differences such as skin or hair color to be easily seen, but not such substantial differences that a male and female from the two populations can't produce viable offspring.
question: Are these orders fixed or random?
context1: The order is not random. It is determined by the structure of the sulfonyl chloride. In methanesulfonyl chloride, the S atom enhances the acidity of the a-hydrogen. So the pyridine can remove it in the first step. In p-toluenesulfonyl chloride, there is no a hydrogen, so the only useful choice is for the alcohol to attack the S.

text: there has to be a large amount of both the weak acid and its conjugate base (or vice versa) in order to neutralize the incoming acid/base that disturbs the solution. For example, I make a buffer with 1 mole of acetic acid and 1 mole of sodium acetate. If I were to drop a bit of strong base, let's say NaOH, into the solution, it would react with the 1 mole of acetic acid (acid) that is in the buffer. If i were to drop a bit of strong acid, let's say HCl, into the solution, it would react with the 1 mole of sodium acetate (base) that is in the buffer. Acids will react with bases. Now, let's pretend I make a second buffer, let's 0.1 moles of acetic acid and 1 mole of sodium acetate. This new buffer would be able to resist an incoming acid just as well as my first buffer, because it still has the same amount of sodium acetate (base). But it would be ineffective at neutralizing any incoming base because there is now only 0.1 moles of acetic acid to neutralize it. If we add too much base, we will quickly exceed the capacity of the buffer and the pH will skyrocket! Non-buffered solutions do not have any mechanism to resist changes in pH. At the same time that vesicles pinch off of the ER, there are vesicles arriving at the ER, restoring its share of membrane. The net result is that it doesn't really change in size. Also cells can manufacture membrane phospholipids in the cytosol. This is important for cell growth so that eventually division is possible.
question: What is the specific difference for a non-buffered solution that causes the pH to fluctuate?

For example, I make a buffer with 1 mole of acetic acid and 1 mole of sodium acetate. If I were to drop a bit of strong base, let's say NaOH, into the solution, it would react with the 1 mole of acetic acid (acid) that is in the buffer. If i were to drop a bit of strong acid, let's say HCl, into the solution, it would react with the 1 mole of sodium acetate (base) that is in the buffer. Acids will react with bases. Now, let's pretend I make a second buffer, let's 0.1 moles of acetic acid and 1 mole of sodium acetate. This new buffer would be able to resist an incoming acid just as well as my first buffer, because it still has the same amount of sodium acetate (base). But it would be ineffective at neutralizing any incoming base because there is now only 0.1 moles of acetic acid to neutralize it. If we add too much base, we will quickly exceed the capacity of the buffer and the pH will skyrocket! Non-buffered solutions do not have any mechanism to resist changes in pH.

text: The entropy of a macro-system is proportional to the number of micro-states the system can be in that are compatible with the macro-state of the system. To make this notion precise, one has to specify the definition of macro-states and micro-states and how the micro-states will be counted. Sal is not providing those details here, but is speaking more qualitatively. Still, the entropy increase with either volume increase or temperature increase can be understood at this qualitative level. The micro-state of a gas is given by the location and velocity of each molecule in the gas. If the volume increases, the molecules have more locations they can be at, hence more micro-states. If the temperature increases, the molecules have more velocities with which they can move, hence more micro-states. Remember that absolute temperature is proportional to the average kinetic energy of the molecules, so increasing temperature increases the range of velocities the molecules are likely to have. This is an increase in the number of micro-states. The mechanical energy does not equal zero. The conservation of energy formula goes Ki+Ui=Kf+Uf. U is potential energy and K is kinetic energy. In this case the golf ball at the start has zero potential energy. We are considering the surface of the moon to be the height h. The height is zero therefore, we have no initial potential energy(mgh). We are left with Ki=Kf+Uf=>1/2m(vi)^2=1/2m(vf)^2+mgh. Also Em is a measure of energy at a certain time. We can rewrite the conservation of energy formula as Em(i)=Em(f). If Em equals zero that means U+K=0
question: How come an increase in temperature increases this combination of states?
context1: The entropy of a macro-system is proportional to the number of micro-states the system can be in that are compatible with the macro-state of the system. To make this notion precise, one has to specify the definition of macro-states and micro-states and how the micro-states will be counted. Sal is not providing those details here, but is speaking more qualitatively. Still, the entropy increase with either volume increase or temperature increase can be understood at this qualitative level. The micro-state of a gas is given by the location and velocity of each molecule in the gas. If the volume increases, the molecules have more locations they can be at, hence more micro-states. If the temperature increases, the molecules have more velocities with which they can move, hence more micro-states. Remember that absolute temperature is proportional to the average kinetic energy of the molecules, so increasing temperature increases the range of velocities the molecules are likely to have. This is an increase in the number of micro-states.
context2: The mechanical energy does not equal zero. The conservation of energy formula goes Ki+Ui=Kf+Uf. U is potential energy and K is kinetic energy. In this case the golf ball at the start has zero potential energy. We are considering the surface of the moon to be the height h. The height is zero therefore, we have no initial potential energy(mgh). We are left with Ki=Kf+Uf=>1/2m(vi)^2=1/2m(vf)^2+mgh. Also Em is a measure of energy at a certain time. We can rewrite the conservation of energy formula as Em(i)=Em(f). If Em equals zero that means U+K=0

text: Light does not care that we would like to be able to describe it in terms of things we are familiar with like waves and particles. Light is just light, it behaves how it does. In some situations it behaves in ways that seem particle-like to us, and in other situations it behaves in ways that seem wave-like. But it is neither of those things, it is its own thing, and our intuition that it must behave like the waves or particles we are used to does not apply, so we have to just deal with that and understand it as it is. Waves that we are familiar with need a medium. Light does not. Particles that we are familiar with do not diffract and refract and get polarized. Light does. For hundreds of years the the seeming dual nature of light puzzled physicists, and now finally we have learned that we just have to accept it on its own terms. Using the D line of sodium, 589 nm, is the most common wavelength used and the only wavelength used in data tables tabulating the specific rotation's of enantiomers. But yes if you were to use a different wavelength of light then the specific rotation would be different than the specific rotations found using 589 nm. Hope that helps.

text: Symporters and antiporters use the energy stored in the electrochemical gradient. Depending on which membrane is being discussed, the electrochemical gradient may created by either metabolic processes (e.g. the electron transport chain in mitochondria) and/or by using ATP to pump ions "uphill" (against their electrochemical gradient). Secondary active transport means that, rather than directly using ATP to power the movement of compounds across the membrane, proteins like symporters and antiporters use the energy stored in the electrochemical gradient. The electrochemical gradient is the combined "push" due to concentration and charge differences across the membrane. It is actually the hydrogen(partial positive charge) in one glucose molecule that bonds with the carbon in the other, h2o is released and removed in the process. This process is called dehydration synthesis. The covalent bonds of carbon are strong so it can stay a large molecule.

text: understand that 'species' is a human construct that doesn't have an exact match in nature. What actual exist are breeding populations in a given area. We may or may not classify them as the same species as some other similar breeding population somewhere else. What we usually, but not always, use as a dividing mark between species is whether the members continue to interbreed given the opportunity. If they cannot or will not normally breed, we tend to call them different species. If they are distinctly different but can and do naturally interbreed given the chance, we tend to call them different subspecies. A nitrogen atom with three bonds and a lone pair is technically a chiral center, but typically it can convert back and forth between conformations so quickly that in practice, you wouldn't be able to isolate the enantiomers.

text: photon frequency are exact. The precision must be extremely high - within the bounds of the Heisenberg uncertainty principle. You might as well just say it has to be exact. If there's not a precise match, the photon will not be absorbed. The Heisenberg Uncertainty Principle says that the energy levels are not exact unless the uncertainty in the time (lifetime of the excited state) is infinite. Of greater practical importance are two factors which give rise to non-zero line widths (the widths at half-height of the line profiles): (1) the Doppler effect, since atoms moving toward you will appear to emit light of slightly higher frequencies (a blue shift) whereas atoms moving away from you will appear to emit light of slightly lower frequencies (a red shift), and this effect becomes more pronounced at higher temperatures, since the average speeds of the molecules becomes greater, and (2) pressure broadening, since atoms or molecules colliding with each other have electrons with motions perturbed from their state in isolated atoms or molecules. In Molecular Orbital theory, the LUMO of benzyne is much closer to the HOMO than it is in normal alkynes. This makes the LUMO of benzyne a much better match for the HOMO of nucleophiles. Hence, benzyne behaves as an electrophile and undergoes reactions with nucleophiles.

If there's not a precise match, the photon will not be absorbed. The Heisenberg Uncertainty Principle says that the energy levels are not exact unless the uncertainty in the time (lifetime of the excited state) is infinite. Of greater practical importance are two factors which give rise to non-zero line widths (the widths at half-height of the line profiles): (1) the Doppler effect, since atoms moving toward you will appear to emit light of slightly higher frequencies (a blue shift) whereas atoms moving away from you will appear to emit light of slightly lower frequencies (a red shift), and this effect becomes more pronounced at higher temperatures, since the average speeds of the molecules becomes greater, and (2) pressure broadening, since atoms or molecules colliding with each other have electrons with motions perturbed from their state in isolated atoms or molecules.
context2: In Molecular Orbital theory, the LUMO of benzyne is much closer to the HOMO than it is in normal alkynes. This makes the LUMO of benzyne a much better match for the HOMO of nucleophiles. Hence, benzyne behaves as an electrophile and undergoes reactions with nucleophiles.

text: The two strands don't encode the same information - they have different sequences! Within a gene *usually* only one strand is transcribed, but there are many examples where transcription happens from the both strands. This is especially common in viruses. RNA polymerase recognizes specific sequences (promoters) that direct it to bind in the appropriate place on the correct strand. I think you got a bit confused here - ribosomes translate mRNA to make protein. DNA polymerases are the enzymes that duplicate DNA molecules.  strong acid and bases giving 100% ionization in water has to do with equilibrium and reversible reactions. When an acid or base dissociates (or ionizes) in water, there's always the possibility of the reverse reaction, were the ions react to reform the not-dissociated acid or base. The amount an acid or base dissociates in water has to do with how much more one of these reactions is favored the forward reaction (the dissociation into ions), or the backward reaction (the ions reacting to form the original acid or base). Strong acids and bases almost overwhelmingly favor the forward reaction, because the resulting ions are relatively unreactive in aqueous solution.

text: The law of conservation of mass by Antoine Lavoisier states that mass can neither by created or destroyed. Suppose you burn a piece of paper. Ash is created and some fumes are generated. Similarly, if We have one oxygen atom on one side and two oxygen atoms on the other side due to the reaction, this wouldn't be reasonable with the experiment we made by burning the paper. text: Each species takes up an ecological niche. They perform certain roles, they have their own set of predators and prey, and they each perform their roles at different times. Remove a niche, and the ecosystem is disturbed. Predators may begin to starve, prey may begin to overpopulate, dead bodies may begin to pile up, populations cannot be controlled, species cannot benefit from each other, etc. While it may be possible for a niche to be completely removed and be beneficial to the ecosystem, this is very unlikely. Besides: another organism may just re-make the niche and any benefits an extinction may have had will be gone. As for humans going extinct, while it may result in more nature, less carbon, and less species being threatened to death, consider the other systems humans manage. For instance, how about the hundreds of running nuclear power plants all over the world? Nuclear plants have to be constantly monitored and be controlled with precision. Nobody is going to do that if humans just suddenly disappeared from Earth. Sure, the animals recovered from Chernobyl and Fukushima, but how about if all of them detonated for weeks on end? What about all of the urban land and desertification? Where are the animals going to go now? Plus, animals like foxes and dolphins are being domesticated more thanks to interactions with humans. What about them? What about animals in captivity? I have no idea if such a planet would be better or worse for animals, but our disappearance would change it drastically. plants also do cellular respiration - taking in oxygen and giving out CO2. Cellular respiration occurs in the mitochondria. Now since photosynthesis creates glucose, why do we need mitochondria? the biological 'currency' is ATP. So we need to convert the glucose into ATP. This is done in the mitochondria and is called cellular respiration. We humans only do cellular respiration since we are heterotrophs - we don't make our own glucose.

text: The high energy bonds in ATP are (by definition) unstable, so for long term storage of energy ATP is not a good choice. In many situations phosphate is a limiting nutrient, so needing to make more ATP could severely limit the plants' ability to store energy. Fixed carbon (e.g. glucose) can be converted into other molecules the plant needs. When the C-C bond breaks, the right hand carbon gets a positive charge. The lone pair from the O moves in to make a pi bond and neutralize the charge, but the O atom still has eight electrons in its valence shell.

text: Hydrogen does not follow the octet rule, so that is part of why H2 is stable. Note: H2 is stable, but it is quite reactive. The octet rule follows from the energetic favorability of having both the s and p subshells either completely empty or completely full. There is no p subshell in shell number 1, so that is part of why the lightest elements do not follow the octet rule (there are other reasons). There are many considerations as to what does or does not make an atom with a particular electron configuration reactive or nonreactive. So, while the octet rule is a convenient rule of thumb, the reality of chemistry is much, much more complicated. So, with chemistry, there are many competing factors that affect how elements behave, so you cannot just take a single rule and insist or suspect that every element must necessarily follow that rule. It doesn't work that way. You have to take all of the factors into consideration to predict how an element might behave. NOTE: The Pauli exclusion principle is one of the few laws that all of the elements always obey. But the octet rule is not always followed. The states of matter depend on two things, pressure, and temperature. If the temperate increases than the general energy increases and the molecules break away from each other thus causing the element to change to a higher state of matter, such as from liquid to gas. But the same is true with pressure except in a different way. If the pressure exerted on water is increased the molecules are squished together and it changes to a solid, but if the pressure is decreased the molecules are "pulled apart" and the state changes to a gas without the temperature having to change at all.
question: Why are the elements in group 2 not stable with 2 valence electrons?
context1: Hydrogen does not follow the octet rule, so that is part of why H2 is stable. Note: H2 is stable, but it is quite reactive. The octet rule follows from the energetic favorability of having both the s and p subshells either completely empty or completely full. There is no p subshell in shell number 1, so that is part of why the lightest elements do not follow the octet rule (there are other reasons). There are many considerations as to what does or does not make an atom with a particular electron configuration reactive or nonreactive. So, while the octet rule is a convenient rule of thumb, the reality of chemistry is much, much more complicated. So, with chemistry, there are many competing factors that affect how elements behave, so you cannot just take a single rule and insist or suspect that every element must necessarily follow that rule. It doesn't work that way. You have to take all of the factors into consideration to predict how an element might behave. NOTE: The Pauli exclusion principle is one of the few laws that all of the elements always obey. But the octet rule is not always followed.
context2: The states of matter depend on two things, pressure, and temperature. If the temperate increases than the general energy increases and the molecules break away from each other thus causing the element to change to a higher state of matter, such as from liquid to gas. But the same is true with pressure except in a different way. If the pressure exerted on water is increased the molecules are squished together and it changes to a solid, but if the pressure is decreased the molecules are "pulled apart" and the state changes to a gas without the temperature having to change at all.

text: The reaction with water is explosive. The circuit analysis methods (Node Voltage, Mesh Current) are intended to be by-the-book algorithms (recipes) for solving any circuit. If you trust the steps you don't have to think about anything else. You don't have to worry that If the 2V source points this way then I have to make sure its mesh current flows a certain direction. We started out curling both mesh currents in the clock-wise direction. When we got to the solution it turned out i2 had a negative value, indicating that the current flows out of the top of the 2V source, just like you would expect. There is no crime if you have a mesh current with a negative value. The reason we curl all the mesh currents in the same direction is to encourage correct writing of mesh equations, especially when two mesh currents flow through one resistor (the 1kohm resistor in this circuit). You get accustomed to writing that terms with a +meshcurrent and a -meshcurrent. This habit helps reduce careless sign errors. That feature is more important than trying to eliminate a negative sign from the final answer.

text: There are several definitions to acids and bases, all of which were created relatively at the same time. The Arrhenius theory states an acid donates a hydronium ion/proton(H+) and a base donates a hydroxide (OH-) subsequently increasing the concentration of each in a solution. The Bronstead-Lowry definition states an acid and base react to form their conjugate base and conjugate acid conterparts with the exchange of a proton (H+). Finally, the most emcompassing definition comes from Lewis theory. It states an acid is one that accepts electron pair (i.e. an electrophile) and a base is one that donates an electron pair (i.e. a nucleophile). The Earth is billions of years old. It still has a lot of residual heat left over from its formation, and additional heat is being added from radioactive decay of unstable isotopes. Also, Earth's crust and atmosphere acts as a thermal barrier, holding in heat. Add into that the radiation Earth gets from the Sun, and the net heat loss/gain varies.

text: If people put a charged object somewhere in space and people will notice there is a force on it, that force is caused by the electric field at that location. The magnitude of the force is proportional to two things: the size of the charge and the intensity (magnitude) of the electric field. The direction of the force is determined by the direction of the electric field vector. The simplicity of Bohr's model is easy to explain to those who start studying chemistry, and while the model itself may not represent the true nature of an atom, it portrays a rather simple picture of orbits and energy levels, making the concept of those easier to understand.

text: In an acidic medium, H+ will be present (as H3O+, hydronium, in water; the H+ joins H2O to create H3O+, an equivalent form) in solution; this is the definition of an acid. The acid will release H+, leaving behind its conjugate base (the anion of the acid); how much H+ released depends on the acid's dissociation constant- strong acids will effectively dissociate completely and not be present as combined ions afterwards, but weak acids will mostly remain non-dissociated, and little H+ will be produced. For bases, the Arrhenius and Bronsted-Lowry definitions are different; Arrhenius bases release OH-, while Bronsted-Lowry bases remove H+ from water (or another solvent, as the Bronsted-Lowry model works in non-aqueous solutions) to leave OH-, along with the base's conjugate acid (the base with an added H+ ion). Most common Arrhenius bases are strong bases which dissociate completely; many Bronsted-Lowry bases are weak bases, in which much of the base remains whole in solution. The end result is that an acidic solution will have remaining H+ (or H3O+) in solution (concentration determines pH), and a basic solution will have remaining OH- in solution (concentration determines pOH) Interestingly enough, so-called idiot savants, do not have a greater capacity for computation, music, or art. Instead, the parts of their brains responsible for such tasks dominate the rest of their brain because the parts that would normally compete for attention are either damaged or unable to communicate effectively with the rest of the brain. Researchers have used something called TMS (trans-cranial magnetic stimulation) to induce small currents in parts of the brain, either shutting down or activating specific regions of the brain temporarily. Their research has shown that it is possible to temporarily induce a savant-like state in normally functioning brains. And, of course, some forms of brain damage can induce temporary or permanent savant-like states as well.

context1: In an acidic medium, H+ will be present (as H3O+, hydronium, in water; the H+ joins H2O to create H3O+, an equivalent form) in solution; this is the definition of an acid. The acid will release H+, leaving behind its conjugate base (the anion of the acid); how much H+ released depends on the acid's dissociation constant- strong acids will effectively dissociate completely and not be present as combined ions afterwards, but weak acids will mostly remain non-dissociated, and little H+ will be produced. For bases, the Arrhenius and Bronsted-Lowry definitions are different; Arrhenius bases release OH-, while Bronsted-Lowry bases remove H+ from water (or another solvent, as the Bronsted-Lowry model works in non-aqueous solutions) to leave OH-, along with the base's conjugate acid (the base with an added H+ ion). Most common Arrhenius bases are strong bases which dissociate completely; many Bronsted-Lowry bases are weak bases, in which much of the base remains whole in solution. The end result is that an acidic solution will have remaining H+ (or H3O+) in solution (concentration determines pH), and a basic solution will have remaining OH- in solution (concentration determines pOH)

text: speed and temperature aren't the same thing. they are related in such way that increase in temperature increases the *average* speed of molecules. real speed can be changed with collisions between two molecules or collisions between molecules and the wall of the container The atoms in the mirror absorb the photons that come in and re-emit identical photons. In a way, this question is almost philosophical - how can we really tell the difference between absorbing and re-emitting an identical thing, versus if the thing just bounced off? The answer really just depends on the theory that we are using to describe what happened. In this case, quantum mechanics mathematics describing an absorption/re-emission mechanism match empirical results. And since that same theory has such wide application, we say that's what really happened. But classical physics can also describe the reflection in a way that equally matches empirical results, and classical physics says the light just bounced. If not for the fact that we know that quantum physics is more accurate across a wider range of reality than classical physics is, we could just as well say that the light bounced.

text: the geometry of the molecule is important as well, perhaps more important in certain cases. In the case of SiF4, the dipole moment of each Si-F bond will cancel each other out, as it is of tetrahedral geometry. A good example is carbon dioxide (non-polar) vs formaldehyde (polar). The dipole moment along each C=O bond in CO2 will cancel each other out since the molecule is linear. However, the dipole moment of the C=O bond and each C-H bond in CH2O will reinforce each other (trigonal planar geometry about the carbon center, with smaller H-C-H angle and larger O-C-H angles). Different texts will give different numbers. A difference in electronegativity of 1.7 means there is 50% ionic character in the bond, that's the most common number I've seen. I've also seen 2.0 given. That said it isn't foolproof, in SiF4 there is a difference in electronegativity of 2.08 and it behaves like a non polar covalent molecule would. Structural isomers are those that have atoms binded to different atoms, altogether. In the bromo-chloro-fluoro-methane molecule, the bromine is binded to carbon, the chlorine is binded to the carbon, the fluorine is binded to a carbon and the hydrogen is bonded to carbon. Its enantiomers has the same configuration. With ethers and alcohols, the oxygen actually moves locations and is bind to different things. If you were to draw the dot structure, you would see that ether and alcohol structures would look different. If you were to draw a dot structure for the molecule mentioned above, both of them would be the same despite having stereochemistry.

text: The tree of life is a metaphor for the fact that all life on earth is evolutionarily related, somewhat like a huge version of a human family tree. The tree really has nothing to do with physical characteristics such as fur or number of legs. Because evolution allows lineages to change physiologically and anatomically, many pairs of species on earth are quite different. When we look at two species whose members outwardly appear somewhat similar, this is a clue that they share a recent common ancestor. For example, dogs and horses are biologically separate lineages, however they are similar enough (four legs, fur) that it is highly likely that the two lineages split more recently, such as two first cousins who's most recent common ancestor was a grandparent. When we talk about a biological common ancestor, we really mean an ancestral species consisting of many individuals. A "grandparent population" that split and became two separate populations, which persisted into becoming modern day dogs and horses. On the other hand, dogs and mosquitoes are very different, which is a clue that their common ancestor diverged into the two lineages a very long time ago, like two distant cousins sharing a great great great great great great grandparent. This ancestral species probably outwardly looked nothing like either a dog or a mosquito. So the whole idea of the tree of life is to convey the idea that all living species, including dogs, horses, and mosquitoes are related, even though some are more closely related than others. Lithium is a stronger reducing agent than all other alkali metals. This is because Lithium (do note that all this is happening in water) has a large hydration energy (because of its small size and high charge density), and this favours the formation of the Li+ cation significantly, making Li the best reducing agent in the periodic table (and amongst alkali metals).

A virus reproduces by hijacking a cell, taking over its machinery, and forcing it to make new viruses. text: pH 7 was chosen as neutral because it's in the center of the pH scale- there are 7 levels above and below it. The meaning of pH is disputed, but the most widely used one is '*p*ower of *H*ydrogen' because pH measures the power, or concentration, of H+ ions in the substance. *Oncogene* are mutated genes that switch from G1 to S phase, (even when there is no need for cell division). So, they are accelerators of the process. You know that is a checkpoint of a cell. However, there are also *tumor suppressor* genes and they act a brake. So, whilst the tumor suppressor is sitting there in the cell, it's stopping the cell from going around the cell cycle. If we, again, trigger the cell cycle or attempt to by instructing the cell with a signal initiating the relay, one of the jobs of that relay is to remove that block, that brake. As long as a tumor suppressor is _working_, cancer will not arise. If you remove tumor suppressor (mutation) the cell is free to move from G1 to S phase. If they are both in mutant form, cancer arises.

text: The compound may be be optically inactive if the mirror image can be superimposed on the original molecule. If the image is non-superimposable, then the compound will become optically active and the pair of mirror images will be called enantiomers. For further details look up chiral centers and racemic mixtures. Males still do get these since they have one X chromosome, having no X chromosome is lethal. text: *Sulfur cycle* is a biogeochemical system of biotic and abiotic transformations of inorganic and organic sulfur-bearing components, in and between, the lithosphere, hydrosphere, atmosphere, and biosphere. Sulfur initially enters the biogeochemical cycle via _volcanic activity_ and _continental erosion_. *Steps of the sulfur cycle*: 1. Mineralization of organic sulfur into inorganic forms, such as hydrogen sulfide (H2S), elemental sulfur, 2. and elemental sulfur (S) to sulfate (SO42). 3. Reduction of sulfate to sulfide. 4. Incorporation of sulfide into organic compounds (including metal-containing derivatives) There are no many organisms relying primarily on Sulphur and utilizing it as a source of energy so it is not that relevant and mentioned here. Mineralization of organic sulfur into inorganic forms, such as hydrogen sulfide (H2S), elemental sulfur, 2. and elemental sulfur (S) to sulfate (SO42). 3. Reduction of sulfate to sulfide. 4. It's this carbon that is involved in the opening and closure of the cyclic structure. This is illustrated here - https://biochemjm.files.wordpress.com/2013/02/slide14.jpg. The alpha anomer can convert into the beta anomer via the open chain form. All three of the structures shown in this diagram are forms of glucose. text: The entropy of a macro-system is proportional to the number of micro-states the system can be in that are compatible with the macro-state of the system. To make this notion precise, one has to specify the definition of macro-states and micro-states and how the micro-states will be counted. Sal is not providing those details here, but is speaking more qualitatively. Still, the entropy increase with either volume increase or temperature increase can be understood at this qualitative level. The micro-state of a gas is given by the location and velocity of each molecule in the gas. If the volume increases, the molecules have more locations they can be at, hence more micro-states. If the temperature increases, the molecules have more velocities with which they can move, hence more micro-states. Remember that absolute temperature is proportional to the average kinetic energy of the molecules, so increasing temperature increases the range of velocities the molecules are likely to have. This is an increase in the number of micro-states. The clouds keep our temperature regulated. If we didn't have clouds, it would be extremely hot at night and extremely cold at night. It would be both hot and cold (bit like the moon). When the planet faces the sun, It would be really hot and when it faces away from the sun, It would be really cold
question: How come an increase in temperature increases this combination of states?

Sal is not providing those details here, but is speaking more qualitatively. text: The population might die out, but even if people find a new home, they will still die, and if all of the population moves away, then the population size and the allele freq. So, it would not be founder's effect. if the population mates with a slightly different population, or they mutate spontaneously in some way that allows them to have offspring, then they would live. Typically new cells are generated as they are needed - i.e. cells are not being killed to make room for new cells - instead cells are being made to replace cells that die for other reasons. Cells can be irreparably damaged by injury and disease, they also can wear out due to their highly demanding environment - e.g. the stomach lining, which regularly experiences extremely acidic pH (as low as 1.5) - or are unable to maintain themselves like mammalian red blood cells$. These cells must be regularly replaced for an organism to continue to live. In fact, there is some evidence that failure to remove senescent (old and relatively inactive) cells contributes to aging! $These cells lack nuclei and so can't repair themselves.

Other introns have functions after they are spliced out from the transcript and can act as signaling or regulatory molecules. Some relatively rare types of introns appear to be parasitic DNA molecules - they insert copies of themselves into genes and then splice themselves out from the RNA presumably to keep the host cell alive. It is possible that the more typical introns originated from such parasitic DNA elements. This is still an area of active research and it is quite likely that more functions for introns will be uncovered in the future.

text: A neopentane molecule is the most spherical of all the pentane isomers. That means there is only one point on its surface that can contact with its neighbours. n-Hexane can snuggle up to its neighbours at many points along its length. n-Hexane will have stronger intermolecular forces than neohexane, There are no ionic bonds in these. There is a charge due to having 1 more electron than it has protons, but every bond in these molecules is covalent. The reason the charge is that if you draw the structures you will end up with one oxygen only having 7 electrons and not following the octet rule, unless you add an extra electron to the molecule. Hence why the chlorine polyatomic ions have a -1 charge. You could also think of them all being protonated as acids: HClO, HClO2, HClO3 and HClO4. Once they lose the H+ a -1 charge is left.

text: The hydrogen bond is a weak attraction between molecules, or parts of larger molecules to each other caused by regional polarization resulting from hydrogen's very small diameter and relatively low electronegativity. The bonds are stronger than Van der Waals interactions, but much weaker than other bonds. They typically require less than 20 kJ/mole to break. It is indeed POSSIBLE for matter to return to an ordered state WITHOUT the input of energy, but the probability of such an occurrence is extremely low, just as billiard balls happening to collect back at the center of the pool table is extremely low. Being in an ordered state would likely have HIGHER energy, especially potential energy. If you look at the example of the molecules all crammed into one side of the box rather than being diffused throughout, the probability that they would bounce into each other is much greater, and therefore they exhibit a greater potential for increasing the kinetic energy of each molecule. Usually it TAKES energy to create an ordered state, such as the energy needed by organisms to create ordered systems of life.
question: Why does it take so much KE to break?

text: Dead cells' pieces, called 'apoptotic bodies', are eliminated by phagocitosis by nearby cells, such as macrophages. Apoptotic cells show changes in their plasma membrane (e.g., phospholipids flip from the inner to the outer lipidic layer) that mark them to be removed by other cells. Total energy decreases, but energy density tends to increase. The difference is because organisms in lower trophic are typically much more numerous.

text: The word lumen is used a lot in biology for the space inside a tube, such as the inside of blood vessels or intestines. It is also used for the space inside the E.R. The lumen is technically the inside of the E.R.. the ER is a continuation of the outer nuclear membrane. The lumen is basically the inside of the ER. So if you picture a slide, the slide is the ER. The part where you sit and go down is the lumen of the slide, or ER. Tubules and sacs of ER are interconnected and the ER membrane forms a continuous sheet enclosing a single internal space. The ER membrane separates the ER lumen from the cytosol, and it mediates the selective transfer of molecules between these two compartments. Almost all of the proteins that will be secreted to the cell exterior and those for the lumen of the ER, Golgi apparatus, or lysosomes are initially delivered to the ER lumen. CNS is the brain and spinal cord. PNS includes the cranial nerves and spinal nerves. We like to categorize and define things, but they are connected. Afferent means sensory information going to the brain, Efferent means motor information from the CNS. Efferent, or motor commands includes somatic n.s., or skeletal muscle system , sympathetic n.s. and parasympathetic n.s.

text: Eyes are complex organs that require energy to use and maintain. In addition, they can be a source for infections and diseases that can spread to other parts of the body. So, if eyes are not needed or useful, an organism without eyes can use that energy for other parts of its body that are useful and remove a catalyst for disease/infection. Also, during embryo formation, if there is a non-useful organ to be created, it is an unnecessary waste of energy. Therefore it is practically much more energy efficient to not create that particular organ. Smooth Muscle Skeletal is voluntary, while cardiac muscle is involuntary (appears striated under the microscope; controls the heart). Smooth Muscle is involuntary as well-smooth muscle is responsible for involuntary movement such as breathing, digestion, peristalsis, and blinking. The diaphragm is responsible for breathing. When it contracts, the lungs are filled with air, and when the diaphragm relaxes, the air is forced from your lungs.

Therefore it is practically much more energy efficient to not create that particular organ.

text: Genes are found on strands of DNA, they are not themselves a strand of DNA. A gene is a sequence of base pairs that code for a specific protein, not a specific phenotypic trait as such. The various proteins interact in very complex ways to form traits. So, genes do not, strictly speaking, code for phenotypic traits. However, a specific trait might be reliant on the protein produced by one gene for some key aspect of its nature. So, while we might often say the gene for this or that trait, what is more accurate is saying the gene for the protein is involved in this or that trait. Genes, in fact, tend to be involved in multiple phenotypic traits because the protein they code for can be used in a variety of ways. Alleles are variations of genes, but they may or may not produce observable differences in some phenotypic trait. The reason is that proteins tend to be very large molecules and so a few minor changes here or there in their structure may or may not have much of an effect on their functions. So, some alleles produce proteins that produce pretty much identical phenotypic traits. Also, remember that some amino acids can be coded for by more than one codon, so some alleles merely contain different ways of coding for the same protein. But, obviously, some alleles, even with minor changes, can produce proteins that lead to significantly different traits. Eye color is not a good example because there are many genes involved in that (perhaps as many as 16 genes) Hormones either interact with their receptors on the surface of cells, or can move across the membrane and act on receptors directly in the nucleus of the cell. Either way, the end result is typically an expression of some gene to either increase or decrease production of a certain protein.

However, a specific trait might be reliant on the protein produced by one gene for some key aspect of its nature. So, while we might often say the gene for this or that trait, what is more accurate is saying the gene for the protein is involved in this or that trait. Genes, in fact, tend to be involved in multiple phenotypic traits because the protein they code for can be used in a variety of ways. Since both amounts of work you have given are positive I don't see a way to solve this. If the amounts of work are only the magnitude of the work then we can work with that. text: Whenever you swallow something, the muscle contractions pull up on the hyoid bone, which draws the larynx up and tips the epiglottis backwards to cover the opening of the trachea. You can feel part of this process happen if you lightly press on the top of your thyroid cartilage. When you breathe you don't need to swallow the air, so the muscles don't contract and the trachea stays open. All the force driving the air comes from a partial vacuum in the lungs, so it travels through the lower pressure of the trachea rather than the oesophagus. If you look at the periodic table, you can see Cadmium (Cd) belongs to the 12th group. The periodic table is organized so that the 2 in '12' is equivalent to the amount of electrons the element has in its valence shell. That means Cadmium has 2 electrons in its valence shell. An atom of Cadmium has an oxidation of 2+ because it tends to lose those 2 electrons in its valence shell in order to stabilize, therefore having a positive charge of 2

text: Alkynes generated from vicinal dihalides will be formed between the two halogens. Alkynes formed from germinal dihalides could be formed on either side of the geminal dihalides (unless you had no protons on one side of the geminal dihalides). This means that you would get a mix of products (which is bad) when forming an alkyne from a geminal dihalide. One other exception is if you have a symmetrical molecule, in which case it doesn't matter which side you deprotonate because you'll still form the same alkyne in the end due to symmetry. text: During the production of reproductive cells, chromosomes of the same type (except for X & Y in the case of chromosomally typically males) line up and exchange sections of their genetic code. If the chromosomes are not lined up perfectly during this process the codes may be reversed, or one may end up with two copies of a small section of DNA while the other gets none. Mutations that start here are often called crossing over errors. These mutations are particularly important because they are automatically germline mutations (able to be passed down to future generations). There are other possible sources of mutations, but most of these will be somatic mutations (not able to be passed to future generations). Usually, the best leaving groups are very weak bases. Methanesulfonic acid and p-toluenesulfonic acid are extremely strong acids, Their conjugate bases are extremely weak, so the conjugate bases are excellent leaving groups.
question: Why do genetic mutations still exist in the gene pool?
context1: During the production of reproductive cells, chromosomes of the same type (except for X & Y in the case of chromosomally typically males) line up and exchange sections of their genetic code. Mutations that start here are often called crossing over errors. There are other possible sources of mutations, but most of these will be somatic mutations (not able to be passed to future generations).

text: Intermolecular bonds break easier, but that does not mean first. Statistically, intermolecular bonds will break more often than covalent or ionic bonds. They can both break at the same time, it is just a matter of probability. Water, for example is always evaporating, even if not boiling. But, then, why no hydrogen or oxygen is observed as a product of pure water? Because water decomposes into H+ and OH- when the covalent bond breaks. The concentration of each of these ions in pure water, at 25 degree Celsius, and pressure of 1atm, is 1.010e7mol/L... that is: covalent bonds are breaking all the time (self-ionization), just like intermolecular bonds (evaporation). By the way, that is what makes both pH and pOH of water equal 7. Note that even though H+ and OH- are naturally produced in water, they also recombine back into H2O. The speed of bonds breaking and the speed of recombination fight one another, until they are in chemical equilibrium, that is when both speeds are the same. For instance, this kind of fight also happens with evaporation inside a closed recipient. The equilibrium is reached when the number of molecules escaping from the liquid phase is the same as the number of molecules entering it. Yes the molecular geometry is linear. When an atom is bonded to only one other atom the molecular geometry is always linear. The electron pair geometry of the oxygen is trigonal planar. The electron pair geometry is the shape of a molecule when bonded and non-bonded electron pairs are considered equal.
question: Is there ever an instance where both the intermolecular bonds and intramolecular bonds break simultaneously?
context1: Intermolecular bonds break easier, but that does not mean first. Statistically, intermolecular bonds will break more often than covalent or ionic bonds. They can both break at the same time, it is just a matter of probability. Water, for example is always evaporating, even if not boiling. But, then, why no hydrogen or oxygen is observed as a product of pure water? Because water decomposes into H+ and OH- when the covalent bond breaks. The concentration of each of these ions in pure water, at 25 degree Celsius, and pressure of 1atm, is 1.010e7mol/L... that is: covalent bonds are breaking all the time (self-ionization), just like intermolecular bonds (evaporation). By the way, that is what makes both pH and pOH of water equal 7. Note that even though H+ and OH- are naturally produced in water, they also recombine back into H2O. The speed of bonds breaking and the speed of recombination fight one another, until they are in chemical equilibrium, that is when both speeds are the same. For instance, this kind of fight also happens with evaporation inside a closed recipient. The equilibrium is reached when the number of molecules escaping from the liquid phase is the same as the number of molecules entering it.

The electron pair geometry is the shape of a molecule when bonded and non-bonded electron pairs are considered equal.

It is so dynamic, as cell itself is dynamic That's a good question and I don't think there is a clear cut answer. As you recognise, there are degrees of solubility and many substances are essentially insoluble yet still have a little bit of solubility. In fact, if a reaction is taking place in water, then that is because some ions have come away from the solid to engage in the reaction. But to answer your question, I think most of the time you would say that the substance was a solid if it was practically insoluble or only slightly soluble in water. Also, if a product precipitates out from a reaction then that would always be given a state symbol of solid. In some ways, it becomes clearer in ionic equations such as: AgCl (s) <---> Ag^+ (aq) + Cl^- (aq) This recognises that some of the silver chloride has dissolved, despite silver chloride being insoluble (the equilibrium will be well over to the left in this equation). Ions are always given the aqueous state symbol. At a professional level, chemists seldom include the state symbol when writing chemical equations so this question doesn't arise.

text: The high energy bonds in ATP are (by definition) unstable, so for long term storage of energy ATP is not a good choice. In many situations phosphate is a limiting nutrient, so needing to make more ATP could severely limit the plants' ability to store energy. Fixed carbon (e.g. glucose) can be converted into other molecules the plant needs. In gene therapy we typically don't transfer plasmids into human cells. The details depend on the specific type of gene therapy, but the techniques that have been used so far integrate new DNA sequences into one of the linear chromosome.

text: It was the sequence which told the polymerase to bind to the DNA. The polymerase starts at any point of the DNA and slides alongside it until it comes to a sequence which tells it to bind more to the DNA. Such sequences are called promotors. At -10 there is usually an other promotor, which causes the polymerase to bind very firm to the DNA, so that it can start its work. If it weren't there, the area of the DNA downstream the -35 DNA sequence wouldn't be transcripted. But the transcription is a requirement for the translation, which in its turn is important for the production of polypeptides It is possible to determine the probability that a single atomic nucleus will 'survive' during a given interval. This probability amounts to 50% for one half-life. In an interval twice as long (2 T) the nucleus survives only with a 25% probability (half of 50%), in an interval of three half-life periods (3 T) only with 12.5% (half of 25%), and so on. You can't, however, predict the time at which a given atomic nucleus will decay. For example, even if the probability of a decay within the next second is 99%, it is nevertheless possible (but improbable) that the nucleus will decay only after millions of years. It's like flipping a coin. If you flip 'heads' ten times in a row, what are the chances that the next flip will be 'heads'. You might say, 'I've flipped ten heads in a row. The next one is much more likely to come up 'tails'. Nevertheless, your chances of flipping heads are the same as before: 1 out of 2. Some nuclei are much luckier at flipping the coin than others. They keep flipping until they get 'tails'; then they decay.

text: Homologous chromosomes come from both parents, but represent the same chromosome. For example, chromosome 1 from mom and chrsomosome 1 from dad. They cross breed and have crossing over. _Homozygous_ chromosomes are same type of alleles for the one chromosome (coming from the same person). For example both dominant or bpth recessive _alleles_. When you titrate HCl against Na2CO3, the reaction proceeds in two steps. The first step involves the production of NaHCO3 and this step has an equivalence point of about pH 8.3, in the range covered by phenolphthalein. Hence, the phenolphthalein changes colour at this first equivalence point. As more acid is dripped in, the NaHCO3 reacts to liberate CO2. The equivalence point for this second step is pH 3.7. However, the phenolphthalein has already changed colour so you will not detect this second equivalence point when using phenolphthalein. The way around this is to use a different indicator, such as methyl orange, that doesn't change colour until the second equivalence point is reached, at which point the reaction has gone to completion.

text: The pressure exerted by cell contents on cell wall is called turgor pressure .. The pressure exerted by cell wall on cell contents is called wall pressure . Water enters the cell as long as there is a concentration gradient between surrounding medium and cell . If the surrounding solution is hypotonic , water enters the cell . When water enters the cell , cell swells up , becomes turgid and exerts turgor pressure on cell wall . cell wall also exerts wall pressure on cell contents . so in plant cells , due to the presence of cell walls , bursting of cell is prevented to some extent . while in case of animal cells , as there is no cell wall , there is no pressure on cell contents and so after a certain extent , plasma membrane bursts . There are around 80 ribosomal proteins in eukaryotes and they don't all have the same functions. They provide a structural scaffold, stabilize, and regulate the rRNAs

text: the oxygen atom is only being bound to a hydrogen ion (proton), not a hydrogen atom (so the electron, the negative charge, is not included). Since a typical hydrogen atom has one proton and one electron, a hydrogen ion is just the same as one proton. Therefore, the oxygen has picked up an extra proton,which means it has a positive charge. Helium is not truly a member of Group 18 (or Group VIII in the older system). We just place it there because it is unique and does not really fit into any group. It is placed there because it is practically inert, like the other noble gases. Not all elements follow the octet rule. H, He, Li, and Be never follow the Octet Rule. Boron usually does not follow the octet rule, though it sometimes does. Other elements, such as S and P, sometimes do not follow the octet rule. So, the octet rule is not a strict law of science that is always followed.

text: An allele is a version of a gene. Like it can be either dominant, recessive or *co-dominant*. If we speak about classic dominance patterns, a gene could be either dominant or recessive. You just observe phenotype and occurrence at which gene is displayed. If an allele is *visible* in phenotype in most cases (homozygous and heterozygous) then it is dominant. If an allele is masked by another one (dominant) and is visible only in homozygous situation, then it is recessive. During the flat bit of the phase transition diagram, where temperature doesn't change despite the addition of more heat, the ice is melting and there is a mixture of ice and liquid water. Only when the last bit of ice has melted, and all the water is liquid, does the temperature start to rise.

text: Most bacteria are harmless and many are useful or even necessary for humans. Many bacteria help us digest our food - one example are a group of bacteria known as the Lactobacilli. There is no difference between acting as an enzyme and being an enzyme. Ribosomes are a complexes that contain multiple proteins (~60 in prokaryotes, ~80 in eukaryotes) and several RNAs. Many of these rRNAs have enzymatic activity, but the proteins are primarily there to support and regulate the rRNAs. So, you could call a ribosome an enzyme, but really it is a complex containing several enzymes .

context1: Most bacteria are harmless and many are useful or even necessary for humans. Many bacteria help us digest our food - one example are a group of bacteria known as the Lactobacilli.

Many of these rRNAs have enzymatic activity, but the proteins are primarily there to support and regulate the rRNAs. So, you could call a ribosome an enzyme, but really it is a complex containing several enzymes .

text: mRNAs typically have a fairly short lifetime, but mRNAs can be (and usually are) translated multiple times. Sometimes an mRNA is even translated by multiple ribosomes simultaneously! (The structure formed when this happens is called a polysome.) One of many types of regulation that happens within cells is at the level of mRNA stability. Whether a bond is perfectly non-polar or polar depends on the electronegativity differences between the two bonded atoms. There is a spectrum that ranges from the two extremes of non-polar covalent to ionic, with covalent polar in between. Even though two bonded atoms may be different, their differences in electronegativity might be slight and thus may still be bonding with a relatively equal sharing of electrons, such is the case of carbon bonded to hydrogen. The greater the electronegativity difference, the more the bond approaches the extreme of being ionic. About NaCl, there is a huge difference in electronegativity between the two atoms and it makes sense that this bond is ionic. Looking at C-O bonds, this electronegativity difference lies somewhere between the two extremes (non-polar covalent and ionic), a midpoint where bonds are considered polar covalent.

text: When the C-C bond breaks, the right hand carbon gets a positive charge. The lone pair from the O moves in to make a pi bond and neutralize the charge, but the O atom still has eight electrons in its valence shell. Oxidation implies an increase in oxidation number. Oxygen has an oxidation number of -2, and usually goes up to 0, making it oxidized (an element always has an oxidation number of 0, therefore O2 has an oxidation number of 0, thus increasing its oxidation number since 0 > -2 --> oxygen is oxidized). And by the way, Oxygen doesn't gain electrons, it loses them. Oxygen is a nonmetal with a charge of -2 in its ionic state. So in order to satisfy the octet rule, it loses its two valence electrons in the valence shell!

So in order to satisfy the octet rule, it loses its two valence electrons in the valence shell!

text: Zeroth law is not really relevant because it's about things that are in thermal equilibrium and we don't have thermal equilibrium here First law says energy of a closed system is conserved. The fridge is surrounded by air and plugged into an electrical socket, so it's not a closed system. Second law says entropy of a closed system won't decrease. Again, we don't have a closed system, but it's also easy to see (assuming you understand what entropy is) that as the soup cools, entropy of the soup/fridge system is increasing, not decreasing, so there's no issue. Third law says there's no fridge that can ever get the soup to absolute zero this is the case with a plant cell that has a rigid cell wall thus in a fixed volume hydrostatic pressure will increase until osmotic pressure is opposed. But with an RBC the volume is not fixed (due to lack of cell wall) so osmotic pressure increases unopposed until the cell lyses.

text: Passive transport basically does not require any form of energy compared to active transport. In the case of osmosis,the water moves from areas of HIGH WATER concentration to areas of LOW WATER concentration, which makes it a form of passive transport. It uses no energy to move, it just drifts into lower concentrations of WATER. WATER not other materials, only WATER. Osmosis deals with water. The electrons kicked back to the oxygen because when you protonated the molecule, the oxygen picked up a hydrogen, giving it a +1 charge. While silicon is okay with five bonds, oxygen is very electronegative, so it wants its electrons back. That's also why it wouldn't be the tertbutyl bond that leaves, because the bonds to silicon aren't the issue, the bonds to oxygen are. With the F added to the Si, the Si has a negative charge. It can return to neutral by kicking off bonding electrons. It happens to be the Si-O bond because oxygen is more electronegative than t-butyl.

text: Neurons are the most unique cells in our body. Some are extremely small, while others are very large. In general, neurons do not repair well. If several neurons were damaged, such as in a spinal cord injury, you already know the individual would be paralyzed and it is unlikely the individual would ever walk again. If a portion of a neuron is damaged, it may or may not be able to find and re-connect with itself. If the axon is damaged, the myelin cells such as Schwann cells form a tunnel to help direct the axon to the other portion. Never-the-less, even after several years, if you touch an area of your body that has a scar, you will realize that touch or feeling over that scar has changed and it is not as sensitive as it once was because the receptors and axons were damaged when the skin was damaged. Now, even though the skin is well healed, the nervous tissue has not healed and therefore the sense of touch is poor over that scar. Epithelial tissue and connective tissue heal well, but nervous tissue does not have the ability to divide and replace neurons that have been damaged so it does not heal well. carbon will almost always follow the octet rule. CO isn't an exception to this. The third bond here comes from a lone pair on O being shared with C. the hybridisation is sp for both O and C. Experimentally we find the bond length in CO is shorter than a C-O double bond and similar to the N-N triple bond length in N2. So a triple bond in CO here does sense.

If a portion of a neuron is damaged, it may or may not be able to find and re-connect with itself. If the axon is damaged, the myelin cells such as Schwann cells form a tunnel to help direct the axon to the other portion. Never-the-less, even after several years, if you touch an area of your body that has a scar, you will realize that touch or feeling over that scar has changed and it is not as sensitive as it once was because the receptors and axons were damaged when the skin was damaged. Now, even though the skin is well healed, the nervous tissue has not healed and therefore the sense of touch is poor over that scar. Epithelial tissue and connective tissue heal well, but nervous tissue does not have the ability to divide and replace neurons that have been damaged so it does not heal well.

text: There are some enzymes, which work in many pathways. They have relatively poor substrate specificity and this is important, because it's function requires it to do transform so many chemically different substrates into metabolites. Eg: The cytochrome p450 in liver, alcohol dehydrogenase. The former is a very important enzyme system, which plays a role in metabolising (a fancy term for acting upon) a wide variety of foreign substances, which include drugs and toxins. These reactions are the main mechanism of our body to fight drugs, and competitive inhibition is important here when we want to design drug therapies, because if we give two drugs both of which are acted upon by this enzyme, then they shall compete for its binding, and a result both will be metabolised slowly (in relation to if each was given independently). Alcohol dehydrogenase metabolises alcohols, and hence is the reason why methanol is poisonous. IT converts it into the more poisonous methanoic acid. For a patient of methanol poisoning, the main therapy includes giving ethanol, so that it acts as a competitive inhibitor, preventing methanol from forming the harmful metabolite. The more substrate-specific enzymes, do not usually have complications pertaining to competitive inhibitors. When there are more than one electrons, then there is repulsion between those electrons due to their same negative charge. The formula then breaks down. Also note, the Bohr model is not what actually happens. The current quantum model is believed to be the most correct.

The more substrate-specific enzymes, do not usually have complications pertaining to competitive inhibitors.

text: The nucleolus is a region in the nucleus where the genes encoding rRNA (for ribosomes) are found. In fact, the structure of the nucleolus relies on transcription of these genes. The rRNA genes are found on several chromosomes. During mitosis, the chromosomes each condense and separate, so clearly the nucleolus can't stay around the whole time during mitosis. I would guess that there is more control to its disassembly though than just the surrounding DNA being pulled away during condensation. all enzymes have an optimal temperature and pH level at which they work best at. If the enzyme is working at high temperatures or out of range pH levels, there is a chance it could become denatured. Also, enzymes are proteins, and proteins are affected by temperature and pH values. When the temperature is too high, or at extreme values of pH, the enzymes undergoes conformational change (ie. change in shape) of the active site, also known as denaturation. The substrates no longer fit into the shape of the active site to form an enzyme-substrate complex, so the rate of the enzymatic reaction decreases.
question: Why does nucleolus disappear and then reappear again?
context1: The nucleolus is a region in the nucleus where the genes encoding rRNA (for ribosomes) are found. In fact, the structure of the nucleolus relies on transcription of these genes. The rRNA genes are found on several chromosomes. During mitosis, the chromosomes each condense and separate, so clearly the nucleolus can't stay around the whole time during mitosis. I would guess that there is more control to its disassembly though than just the surrounding DNA being pulled away during condensation.
context2: all enzymes have an optimal temperature and pH level at which they work best at. If the enzyme is working at high temperatures or out of range pH levels, there is a chance it could become denatured. Also, enzymes are proteins, and proteins are affected by temperature and pH values. When the temperature is too high, or at extreme values of pH, the enzymes undergoes conformational change (ie. change in shape) of the active site, also known as denaturation. The substrates no longer fit into the shape of the active site to form an enzyme-substrate complex, so the rate of the enzymatic reaction decreases.

text: The charge on the ion is the sum of all the + and - charges on all the atoms in the ion. Usually only one atom has the charge and the other atoms have no charge. Lysosomes to do not excrete its contents out of the cell. Since they function as cell digestors, they literally do that - digest all the bad and unwanted engulfed material. After digesting viruses and bacteria they break them down into smaller molecules which cannot harm the cell and keep it inside of them. Usually, lysosomes have their life and collect the garbage inside of their bodies by keeping the cells clean. However, if the 'garbage' cannot be recycled via proteosomes or digested via lysosomes, the cell uses exocytosis to dispose of it _outside_ of the cell.

text: A methylated cytosine can be deaminated to change it to thymine (deamination can happen spontaneously in cells). This change of a whole base is not recognized by the DNA repair system, so the problem caused is a point mutation. This is why we have evolved to have very few CG sequences outside of the CpG 'islands' which are usually in the very actively transcribed (and therefore unlikely to ever be methylated) areas around housekeeping genes (the default ON genes for the cell). The germ cells are the simply the cells whose role it is to produce the sex cells. They are differentiated from somatic cells in the early embryo but they need to migrate and expand via mitosis before some of them form the sex cells.

text: HCl in its pure form is a gas and unable to act as a solvent. HCl as a solution will react with the sodium and prevent the reduction from occurring. Yes, you would need a molecule with a steric number of 3, but is bonded to only two atoms. An example of that would be sulfur dioxide or ozone. So if the molecule is bent then it will be so in two scenarios. Either with a steric number of 3 giving the central atom sp2 hybridization making it electronically trigonal planar, but physically bent (like in the above examples). Or with a steric number of 4 giving the central atom sp3 hybridization making it electronically tetrahedral, but physically bent (like with water). In the trigonal planar one, the electron groups are ideally 120 degrees apart from each other. But because of the lone pair making it bent, the bond angle will be slightly less for the two atoms bonded to the central carbon. Maybe around 119 degrees. In the tetrahedral one, the electrons groups are ideally 109.5 degrees apart from each other. The lone pairs will decrease that making it somewhere between 107-109 degrees between the two atoms bonded to the central atom.
question: Are the products formed be same in both cases?

So if the molecule is bent then it will be so in two scenarios. Either with a steric number of 3 giving the central atom sp2 hybridization making it electronically trigonal planar, but physically bent (like in the above examples). Or with a steric number of 4 giving the central atom sp3 hybridization making it electronically tetrahedral, but physically bent (like with water). In the trigonal planar one, the electron groups are ideally 120 degrees apart from each other. But because of the lone pair making it bent, the bond angle will be slightly less for the two atoms bonded to the central carbon. Maybe around 119 degrees. In the tetrahedral one, the electrons groups are ideally 109.5 degrees apart from each other. text: A cross between a female fly that is heterozygous for white eyes and a male that is white-eyed could produce female progeny with white eyes, because the mother makes two kinds of gametes: one X chromosome that encodes red eyes, and one X chromosome that encodes white eyes. If the gamete encoding for white eyes is fertilized by the X chromosome from the father, then female white-eyed flies result. That extra ring DNA is plasmid, not normal bacterial DNA. Plasmids replicate independently. RNA polymerase binds only to promoters. Promoters are stimulating sequences which allow RNAP to bind and start replication.
