text: This type of virus depends on components in the envelope (e.g. glycoproteins) to interact with and infect new cells. The envelope looks like the outside of a host cell and so they would probably be easier for the immune system to recognize and destroy. The envelope may also protect the rest of the virus from non-immune destruction (e.g. attack by proteases). In basic solution, fructose undergoes tautomeric isomerization to form a small amount of aldehyde. If we use R to represent the last four carbons of fructose, we have R-C(=O)CH2OH = R-C(OH)=CHOH = R-CH(OH)CH(=O) or fructose = an enediol = an aldehyde The Tollens reagent oxidizes the aldehyde as fast as it is formed, so the equilibrium keeps getting pulled to the right (Le Chtelier's Principle) until eventually all the fructose is oxidized.

text: Hydrogen bonds do not take very much energy to break. The hydrogen bond is a weak attraction between molecules, or parts of larger molecules to each other caused by regional polarization resulting from hydrogen's very small diameter and relatively low electronegativity.  The efficiency of the respiratory system is very very efficient. Imagine a system of pipes; one pulls the air, another transfers it. Since pipes are rounded and therefore 'closed' air cannot escape through the piping. Take for example your hand. Curl it, and blow through it. Almost none or if any air escapes, except through the other side. Because of this, the only path for the air to take is to the lungs. In which the lungs work/use the air and the entire cycle happens again. When a biological system is working many other dependent systems are working too.

text: The half-life of a radioactive element is the time it takes before half of the atoms in a sample of the element have decayed. If you know how many atoms you have in a sample, and you measure how many of them decay per second, it is easy to figure out how long you would have to wait before half of all the atoms have decayed. You do not have to measure until half the atoms actually have decayed, but the tradition is that we use the half-life as a measure of how quickly a radioactive element decays. Snow forms when water vapor in the air turns directly into ice because it's so cold. The ice crystals grow from additional water vapor until they fall down as snow. Hail, on the other hand, is created when existing liquid rain is carried into colder areas by updrafts and freezes into a ball of ice. Because the water in many clouds is supercooled (brought past the freezing point but still in liquid form), it is easily frozen and the hail gradually grows. This continues until the hailstone becomes too heavy to stay in the clouds and falls.

You do not have to measure until half the atoms actually have decayed, but the tradition is that we use the half-life as a measure of how quickly a radioactive element decays.
context2: Snow forms when water vapor in the air turns directly into ice because it's so cold. The ice crystals grow from additional water vapor until they fall down as snow. Hail, on the other hand, is created when existing liquid rain is carried into colder areas by updrafts and freezes into a ball of ice. Because the water in many clouds is supercooled (brought past the freezing point but still in liquid form), it is easily frozen and the hail gradually grows. This continues until the hailstone becomes too heavy to stay in the clouds and falls.

text: Oxygen atom in ethanol DONATES its lone pair to proton, it is a Lewis Base. When ethanol successfully gets a proton, the Lewis Base turns into Conjugate Acid.  The first 2 equations each had 1 mole of O2 on their reactants side. In the overall system they combine and make a total of 2 moles of O2 on the reactant side. However, the last equation has 2 moles of O2 on its products side (mole meaning a coefficient of 2). Now the overall system has 2 O2's both in the reactants and the products side. They cancel each other out. So, the oxygens in the same side don't cancel each other out. They combine with each other and later cross out because there is an equal amount of oxygen on the opposite side as well.

text: In sulfate the sulfur atom does not have a charge of -2, elements deviate from their ideal oxidation states when bonded to more electronegative atoms like oxygen or fluorine. In this case we would say that sulfur has an oxidation state of +6 and the four oxygen atoms have oxidation states of -2 +6 + -8 = -2 (which is the overall charge of sulfate) In general the formulas and charges of polyatomic ions are something you will need to memorise. Genes are found on strands of DNA, they are not themselves a strand of DNA. A gene is a sequence of base pairs that code for a specific protein, not a specific phenotypic trait as such. The various proteins interact in very complex ways to form traits. So, genes do not, strictly speaking, code for phenotypic traits. However, a specific trait might be reliant on the protein produced by one gene for some key aspect of its nature. So, while we might often say the gene for this or that trait, what is more accurate is saying the gene for the protein is involved in this or that trait. Genes, in fact, tend to be involved in multiple phenotypic traits because the protein they code for can be used in a variety of ways. Alleles are variations of genes, but they may or may not produce observable differences in some phenotypic trait. The reason is that proteins tend to be very large molecules and so a few minor changes here or there in their structure may or may not have much of an effect on their functions. So, some alleles produce proteins that produce pretty much identical phenotypic traits. Also, remember that some amino acids can be coded for by more than one codon, so some alleles merely contain different ways of coding for the same protein. But, obviously, some alleles, even with minor changes, can produce proteins that lead to significantly different traits. Eye color is not a good example because there are many genes involved in that (perhaps as many as 16 genes)

The states of matter depend on two things, pressure, and temperature. If the temperate increases than the general energy increases and the molecules break away from each other thus causing the element to change to a higher state of matter, such as from liquid to gas. But the same is true with pressure except in a different way. If the pressure exerted on water is increased the molecules are squished together and it changes to a solid, but if the pressure is decreased the molecules are "pulled apart" and the state changes to a gas without the temperature having to change at all.

text: Water is very common in the universe. At this time, we do not know how common liquid water might be in the universe but it is more likely that we would find it in either the solid or vapor form. This situation is nothing special about water, because the liquid phase of any chemical requires just the right ranges of both pressure and temperature. So, the liquid phase of mater is not all that common, relatively speaking. Just think about it, apart from liquid water, how many other naturally-occurring liquids do you encounter in your daily life? However, water does have a fairly wide range of temperatures and pressures it can be a liquid in, so it does have a better chance of being a liquid than many other substances. Hydrogen itself exists as a liquid in only the most extreme conditions, so it is extremely rare. Solid hydrogen is even more rare. Pure hydrogen mostly exists as a plasma in stars or elsewhere as a gas. text: the tryptophan repressor is itself a protein produced from transcription of another gene, let's call it "repressor gene". If that gene mutated, the product of transcription of that gene (the repressor protein) could be nonfunctional. If that were the case the e.coli cell would continually transcribe Tryptophan Enzyme. What happens to a rigid object depends on the atomic and molecular forces. If these forces allow the object to undergo elastic deformation then they will deform and then go back to their original shape once the force is removed. If the forces between the atoms and molecules shift without breaking then the object undergoes plastic deformation and stays in the new shape. If the forces do not stretch or shift then the object cracks. Most objects that we conciser rigid will react to a force on them with a combination of all three responses

text: Resistance not only depends on length, area, and type of the conductor, it also changes with temperature for some devices. In a light bulb, because the temperature increases when it is illuminated, its resistance changes. People then have three variables and the relation between the current and the potential difference no longer gives a straight line (since its gradient, the resistance, is no longer a constant). Devices whose temperature changes affect the resistance are called non-ohmic devices. There is two type force inside atom. Researcher Dr. David Johnson looked closely at plants' symbiotic relationship with soil fungus, piggybacking off a 2010 study that seemed to suggest that a tomato plant infected with leaf blight would be able to warn nearby plants of the problem. In turn, those plants would activate genes that would prevent them from catching the disease, too. Essentially, fungi deliver messages of danger from plant to plant, and as a result, the group can grow stronger. text: 'Atomic weight' is an older term and should not be used. 'Atomic mass' is the correct term if you are talking about amu/atom. 'Molecular mass' is the correct term if you are talking about amu/molecule. If you are talking about grams of the element or molecules, the term is 'molar mass' (has units of g/mol). The sodium and chlorine in salt are present as ions. When they are separated, they are separated as Na+ and Cl-. They are not particularly reactive in these forms. What makes sodium metal so reactive with water is that it can get rid of its extra electron.

text: In an acidic medium, H+ will be present (as H3O+, hydronium, in water; the H+ joins H2O to create H3O+, an equivalent form) in solution; this is the definition of an acid. The acid will release H+, leaving behind its conjugate base (the anion of the acid); how much H+ released depends on the acid's dissociation constant- strong acids will effectively dissociate completely and not be present as combined ions afterwards, but weak acids will mostly remain non-dissociated, and little H+ will be produced. For bases, the Arrhenius and Bronsted-Lowry definitions are different; Arrhenius bases release OH-, while Bronsted-Lowry bases remove H+ from water (or another solvent, as the Bronsted-Lowry model works in non-aqueous solutions) to leave OH-, along with the base's conjugate acid (the base with an added H+ ion). Most common Arrhenius bases are strong bases which dissociate completely; many Bronsted-Lowry bases are weak bases, in which much of the base remains whole in solution. The end result is that an acidic solution will have remaining H+ (or H3O+) in solution (concentration determines pH), and a basic solution will have remaining OH- in solution (concentration determines pOH) Electrons and quarks interact through fields, and it is based on these interactions that determines the size of protons, neutrons, and atoms. What we define as touching at the macroscopic level is basically when the attractive van Der Waals forces are offset by the repulsive Pauli exclusion forces on the electrons, there is no physical touching like people normally think of it.
question: Why do you use oh- in a basic medium?
context1: In an acidic medium, H+ will be present (as H3O+, hydronium, in water; the H+ joins H2O to create H3O+, an equivalent form) in solution; this is the definition of an acid. The acid will release H+, leaving behind its conjugate base (the anion of the acid); how much H+ released depends on the acid's dissociation constant- strong acids will effectively dissociate completely and not be present as combined ions afterwards, but weak acids will mostly remain non-dissociated, and little H+ will be produced. For bases, the Arrhenius and Bronsted-Lowry definitions are different; Arrhenius bases release OH-, while Bronsted-Lowry bases remove H+ from water (or another solvent, as the Bronsted-Lowry model works in non-aqueous solutions) to leave OH-, along with the base's conjugate acid (the base with an added H+ ion). Most common Arrhenius bases are strong bases which dissociate completely; many Bronsted-Lowry bases are weak bases, in which much of the base remains whole in solution. The end result is that an acidic solution will have remaining H+ (or H3O+) in solution (concentration determines pH), and a basic solution will have remaining OH- in solution (concentration determines pOH)
context2: Electrons and quarks interact through fields, and it is based on these interactions that determines the size of protons, neutrons, and atoms. What we define as touching at the macroscopic level is basically when the attractive van Der Waals forces are offset by the repulsive Pauli exclusion forces on the electrons, there is no physical touching like people normally think of it.

text: The activation energy just describes how much energy the reactants must have to get the reaction started. That energy is needed to help break and form bonds, but in the end it is still present. You could think of this as being similar to an amusement park where you might have to be at least 1.2 m high to get on a ride - your height isn't affected by the ride! for an 'endergonic' reaction some of the starting kinetic energy may have been converted into chemical potential energy. The net inflow of water when the cell is placed in a hypotonic solution does not require energy. However, net inflow is not because there is room to move around. Individual water molecules move around randomly. They enter the cell because that was the direction they were traveling in. The number of water molecules is so high, that their individual random paths average out. This is why diffusion tends to keep the quantities of water on both sides equal. When there is more water on one side, there is a greater chance that more of it will leave the area of high concentration then enter it, balancing it out. However, in a hypotonic solution, there is more solute inside the cell than outside. The probability for each individual water molecule to leave the cell is greatly decreased. Therefore, there needs to be much more water inside the cell than outside, for the amount of water leaving the cell to be equal to the amount of water entering it. Until that point is reached however, the amount o f water inside the cell will increase until the cell lyses or the amount of water entering and exiting the cell equalizes.

Therefore, there needs to be much more water inside the cell than outside, for the amount of water leaving the cell to be equal to the amount of water entering it. Until that point is reached however, the amount o f water inside the cell will increase until the cell lyses or the amount of water entering and exiting the cell equalizes.

text: If the 2s orbital bonds with a hydrogen the bond will be shorter than the bonds formed by 3 2p orbitals with hydrogen. If this was the case, ammonia would have 3 long bonds and a short bond. text: from both a technical and practical point of view: Technically, lets say that maybe once upon a time, there were only brown-eyed humans. Then, one day, while a baby was being created in the mother's body, the genetics made a mistake while creating the baby, creating a little oopsie in the genetic material. We usually think of mutants as horrible half-humans with disfigurations, but originally, things like blue eyes were mutations in the human genome reflected in their phenotype (appearance). Practically, variation is really great for all living things. Say there's a whole field of purple and white flowers, and one day a disease comes along that, because the two flower colors are slightly genetically different, can only kill the purple flowers. If the species had no variation, they would have all died, but the white flowers were saved due to their differences. If there is no chance for the fluid to get beneath the cone, the cone might stay in place. But I've seen a video on which a screwdriver floats in mid air just because the air pressure is decreased at the right spot above the screwdriver. Of course things are a bit different with gasses and fluids.

text: plants also do cellular respiration - taking in oxygen and giving out CO2. Cellular respiration occurs in the mitochondria. Now since photosynthesis creates glucose, why do we need mitochondria? the biological 'currency' is ATP. So we need to convert the glucose into ATP. This is done in the mitochondria and is called cellular respiration. We humans only do cellular respiration since we are heterotrophs - we don't make our own glucose. In the ClF3 molecule the F-Cl-F angle is about 87A*40ac2. To minimize the repulsion, people have to consider that the amount of repulsion between 2 lone pairs of electrons is greater than that between a lone pair and a bond pair, and finally the repulsion between 2 bond pairs of electrons is the least. The spatial arrangement of atoms and electrons which gives the least amount of repulsion and hence the least energy for the whole molecule is said to be the geometry of the molecule. The angle between the molecules is then determined from this geometry

text: At a very basic level, in a peroxide, the oxygen has an oxidation number of -1, where in a superoxide, the oxidation number of oxygen is -1/2. To determine whether the anion is a superoxide or peroxide, use the total oxidation number of a compound and the known oxidation numbers of other elements. For example, in KO2, we know that the oxidation number is 0, and K is +1; So we can do 1 + 2O = 0, simple algebra tells us that the oxidation number of the Oxygens is -1/2, which means it is the superoxide anion. Because in Bohr's model for hydrogen atom we consider only Coulombic interactions between one proton and one electron. It cannot be extended for other atomic species containing more than one electron. Because in this case in addition to the interaction between nucleus and electron there arises the interactions between electron and electron of the same species. Bohr couldn't solve this problem and this problems are successfully explained on the basis of later developed quantum mechanics.o But Bohr's model can be applied successfully for hydro genic species like He+, Li2+ etc.

text: The furthest spot can only go as high as the solvent front of the mobile phase. the spots have to be somewhat soluble in the mobile phase. And the only reason the spots move is because they are dissolved and are pulled along as the mobile phase climbs. So the spots cannot travel faster than the mobile phase. Hydrogen bonds and London dispersion forces are both examples of van der Waals forces, a general term for intermolecular interactions that do not involve covalent bonds or ions. In a water molecule, the bond connecting the oxygen to each hydrogen is a polar bond. In a polar covalent bond containing hydrogen (e.g., an O-H bond in a water molecule). The hydrogen-oxygen bond in water is not a hydrogen bond, but only a polar covalent bond. However, after hydrogen and oxygen have formed a water molecule and hydrogen has become partially positive, then the hydrogen atoms become attracted to nearby negative charges and are 'available' for hydrogen bonding. The hydrogen bond between these hydrogen atoms and the nearby negatively charged atoms is weak and doesn't involve the covalent bond between hydrogen and oxygen. Thus, hydrogen bonding is a van der Waals force.

text: SN1 is a possible reaction which will form a tertiary halide. Elimination is possible but generally if elimination is required, heat is added. If heat is not shown, the major product can be assumed to be substitution product (SN1)  The atoms in the mirror absorb the photons that come in and re-emit identical photons. In a way, this question is almost philosophical - how can we really tell the difference between absorbing and re-emitting an identical thing, versus if the thing just bounced off? The answer really just depends on the theory that we are using to describe what happened. In this case, quantum mechanics mathematics describing an absorption/re-emission mechanism match empirical results. And since that same theory has such wide application, we say that's what really happened. But classical physics can also describe the reflection in a way that equally matches empirical results, and classical physics says the light just bounced. If not for the fact that we know that quantum physics is more accurate across a wider range of reality than classical physics is, we could just as well say that the light bounced.

text: Water is needed for multiple processes: Building up molecules, transport, stability of the cell and some even for reproduction... They need it for the same reasons as we need it. Decay is primarily due to the actions of prokaryotes and fungi. oxidation and high-energy particles (e.g cosmic rays) will gradually break down molecules in a corpse (or anything else), but this is a *very* slow process. Even without removing microbes an embalmed corpse in a sealed coffin can remain intact for centuries - Individual cells can (and do) self-destruct - this is known as apoptosis, but this doesn't seem to have a significant effect on whole organisms; it ceases soon after the organism dies since it requires energy.

text: he O does act as a nucleophile in competition with N, but it's a dead-end process. Reaction with O gives the reversible formation of a hemiketal. Reaction with N forms the oxime in an essentially irreversible process as the adduct dehydrates. As the ketone gets used up, the hemiketal decomposes in an attempt to maintain the concentration of the ketone (Le Chtelier's Principle) Osmosis is the movement of water via a semipermeable membrane from a less concentrated solution to a more concentrated solution. A less concentrated solution has more water than a more concentrated solution. In essence, the water is moving down its concentration gradient from the less concentrated to the more concentrated solution to equalize the concentration on both sides of the semipermeable membrane.

text: *Oncogene* are mutated genes that switch from G1 to S phase, (even when there is no need for cell division). So, they are accelerators of the process. You know that is a checkpoint of a cell. However, there are also *tumor suppressor* genes and they act a brake. So, whilst the tumor suppressor is sitting there in the cell, it's stopping the cell from going around the cell cycle. If we, again, trigger the cell cycle or attempt to by instructing the cell with a signal initiating the relay, one of the jobs of that relay is to remove that block, that brake. As long as a tumor suppressor is _working_, cancer will not arise. If you remove tumor suppressor (mutation) the cell is free to move from G1 to S phase. If they are both in mutant form, cancer arises. For a *strong acid-strong base* titration, the equivalence point is at pH 7. The pH range of phenolphthalein is about 8.3 to 10.0, but the titration curve is so steep at the equivalence point that phenolphthalein makes a good indicator. For a *strong base-weak acid* titration, the equivalence point is probably near pH 9. Phenolphthalein is great for this titration. For a *strong acid-weak base* titration, the equivalence point is probably near pH 5. Here you could use an indicator like methyl red (pH 4.4 to 6.2).
question: Can cancer happen in this case?
context1: *Oncogene* are mutated genes that switch from G1 to S phase, (even when there is no need for cell division). So, they are accelerators of the process. You know that is a checkpoint of a cell. However, there are also *tumor suppressor* genes and they act a brake. So, whilst the tumor suppressor is sitting there in the cell, it's stopping the cell from going around the cell cycle. If we, again, trigger the cell cycle or attempt to by instructing the cell with a signal initiating the relay, one of the jobs of that relay is to remove that block, that brake. As long as a tumor suppressor is _working_, cancer will not arise. If you remove tumor suppressor (mutation) the cell is free to move from G1 to S phase. If they are both in mutant form, cancer arises.
context2: For a *strong acid-strong base* titration, the equivalence point is at pH 7. The pH range of phenolphthalein is about 8.3 to 10.0, but the titration curve is so steep at the equivalence point that phenolphthalein makes a good indicator. For a *strong base-weak acid* titration, the equivalence point is probably near pH 9. Phenolphthalein is great for this titration. For a *strong acid-weak base* titration, the equivalence point is probably near pH 5. Here you could use an indicator like methyl red (pH 4.4 to 6.2).

text: Through transpiration water forms droplets on the surface of the leaves. Those droplets transform into water vapor and leave the plant surface and become part of humidity in the atmosphere. That way water is back to the water cycle. A cross between a female fly that is heterozygous for white eyes and a male that is white-eyed could produce female progeny with white eyes, because the mother makes two kinds of gametes: one X chromosome that encodes red eyes, and one X chromosome that encodes white eyes. If the gamete encoding for white eyes is fertilized by the X chromosome from the father, then female white-eyed flies result.

text: Tennessine is a halogen, so it should form the following acid (probably called hydrotennessic acid): HTs. The conjugate base of HTs is Ts-. A small Styrofoam ball can represent hydrogen, a large Styrofoam ball can represent tennessine, and a straw can represent the covalent bond between them. In some environments HCl does behave like an ionic compound, but as a gas it forms molecules (i.e. shows covalent bonding). Note that it is better to think of covalent and ionic bonding as being on a continuum rather than as distinctly different types of bonding. Most bonds have both ionic and covalent character and in many cases it is actually quite arbitrary to call something one or the other. HCl is a great example of this, it has a polar covalent bond as a gas - this can be expressed as the bond having a mixture of covalent and ionic character. However, when dissolved in water, HCl almost completely dissociates with the protons binding to water molecules - and so the behavior of HCl in water is best described as being ionic. One way of thinking of this is that the nature of bonding in some compounds changes depending on the environment.

text: Each species takes up an ecological niche. They perform certain roles, they have their own set of predators and prey, and they each perform their roles at different times. Remove a niche, and the ecosystem is disturbed. Predators may begin to starve, prey may begin to overpopulate, dead bodies may begin to pile up, populations cannot be controlled, species cannot benefit from each other, etc. While it may be possible for a niche to be completely removed and be beneficial to the ecosystem, this is very unlikely. Besides: another organism may just re-make the niche and any benefits an extinction may have had will be gone. As for humans going extinct, while it may result in more nature, less carbon, and less species being threatened to death, consider the other systems humans manage. For instance, how about the hundreds of running nuclear power plants all over the world? Nuclear plants have to be constantly monitored and be controlled with precision. Nobody is going to do that if humans just suddenly disappeared from Earth. Sure, the animals recovered from Chernobyl and Fukushima, but how about if all of them detonated for weeks on end? What about all of the urban land and desertification? Where are the animals going to go now? Plus, animals like foxes and dolphins are being domesticated more thanks to interactions with humans. What about them? What about animals in captivity? I have no idea if such a planet would be better or worse for animals, but our disappearance would change it drastically. Alkynes generated from vicinal dihalides will be formed between the two halogens. Alkynes formed from germinal dihalides could be formed on either side of the geminal dihalides (unless you had no protons on one side of the geminal dihalides). This means that you would get a mix of products (which is bad) when forming an alkyne from a geminal dihalide. One other exception is if you have a symmetrical molecule, in which case it doesn't matter which side you deprotonate because you'll still form the same alkyne in the end due to symmetry.
question: Is it possible for there to be a positive outcome?
context1: Each species takes up an ecological niche. They perform certain roles, they have their own set of predators and prey, and they each perform their roles at different times. Remove a niche, and the ecosystem is disturbed. Predators may begin to starve, prey may begin to overpopulate, dead bodies may begin to pile up, populations cannot be controlled, species cannot benefit from each other, etc. While it may be possible for a niche to be completely removed and be beneficial to the ecosystem, this is very unlikely. Besides: another organism may just re-make the niche and any benefits an extinction may have had will be gone. As for humans going extinct, while it may result in more nature, less carbon, and less species being threatened to death, consider the other systems humans manage. For instance, how about the hundreds of running nuclear power plants all over the world? Nuclear plants have to be constantly monitored and be controlled with precision. Nobody is going to do that if humans just suddenly disappeared from Earth. Sure, the animals recovered from Chernobyl and Fukushima, but how about if all of them detonated for weeks on end? What about all of the urban land and desertification? Where are the animals going to go now? Plus, animals like foxes and dolphins are being domesticated more thanks to interactions with humans. What about them? What about animals in captivity? I have no idea if such a planet would be better or worse for animals, but our disappearance would change it drastically.
context2: Alkynes generated from vicinal dihalides will be formed between the two halogens. Alkynes formed from germinal dihalides could be formed on either side of the geminal dihalides (unless you had no protons on one side of the geminal dihalides). This means that you would get a mix of products (which is bad) when forming an alkyne from a geminal dihalide. One other exception is if you have a symmetrical molecule, in which case it doesn't matter which side you deprotonate because you'll still form the same alkyne in the end due to symmetry.

text: The seasons in the equator are near non-existent. The tilt of the earth's axis maintains nearly equal amounts of sunshine around this area all year round. There are, however, dry/rainy seasons, but this is caused more by the heating of the oceans and air currents carrying moisture than anything else. Typically the equatorial zone (area near the equator) is estimated at 20 degrees north and 20 degrees south of the equator. Beyond that boundary, seasons become more and more pronounced, with the poles having some of the most dramatic. Since ultrabithorax is inactivated, no halteres are present. text: Speciation has occurred a lot, and is responsible for all the different species we see on the Earth today, but it is a gradual, slow process. It is constantly happening as organisms evolve, and we have seen a couple new species develop. Speciation isn't a spontaneous process; rather, it is just a step in evolution where the individuals become so different that they can no longer interbreed and a new species is created. Speciation can be accelerated through factors like isolation and ample resources for reproduction, to give a few examples. If placing a red blood cell in a hypotonic solution, it will burst. A hypotonic solution has a low solute concentration than the inside of the cells (solute concentration in the cell is high). Osmotic forces then cause water from a solution to enter the cells. The cell eventually stretches and bursts in the process becoming lysis.

text: When we are buried in the ground... the bacteria and other de-composers break down our body into simpler chemical forms. which are then taken up by plants and then the cycle continues. Energy is also returned as the organism secretes or excretes during it's life. Exchanges are during all the organism life: Pooh, pee, sweat and respirations (secretions & excretions = give back to the ecosystem), and to eat (to lend energy and materials to the ecosystem). And death is only the final give back. The N-terminus of a protein is synthesized first. Each new amino acid is added by making a bond between the carboxyl group at the end of the growing polypeptide and the amino group of the amino acid that is being added.

text: Lithium is a stronger reducing agent than all other alkali metals. This is because Lithium (do note that all this is happening in water) has a large hydration energy (because of its small size and high charge density), and this favours the formation of the Li+ cation significantly, making Li the best reducing agent in the periodic table (and amongst alkali metals). The main principle is that when you neutralise an acid and base, moles acid = moles base You should also have the volume of base that was titrated because that will have been in the burette so was measured. concentration = moles / volume Or rearranged: moles = concentration x volume So calculate moles of base If the stoichiometry from the balanced equation is 1:1 then this is equal to the moles of acid. If it isn't then you'll need to account for that. Now you have moles of acid, and the initial volume so just use the previous equation: concentration = moles / volume Now I've explained the method, there is a shortcut you can use here. C1V1/n1 = C2V2/n2 where n1 and n2 are the coefficients of the acid and base in the balanced equation. You will always know 5/6 of the values in that.

text: electronegativity can be associated with ionic bonds. The reason ionic bonds occur is because of the difference in electronegativity. There is a rule which states that if the difference in electronegativity is greater than 2, then the atom with a higher electronegativity will get the electron. This is why you see non-metal tend to have a higher electronegativity, thus getting the metal's electron(s). It is this feature which allows non-metals to become anions Increase the voltage (which means using a more powerful battery) while increasing the resistance (using a resistor made of a more insulant material. text: Bromine has a negative charge when it has a full octet; this makes it an negative anion so it wants to bond with a positive carbocation.(Unlike charges attract), a bromine atom is neutral when it has 7 valence electrons. If it has 8 v.e then it will have a charge of 1-. You're right that it is 'stable' with a full octet, but as it has a charge, it will still bond with another oppositely charged ion.  Water has a high surface tension because the water molecules on the surface are pulled together by strong hydrogen bonds. That means a drop of water will "Want" to have the smallest possible surface area. The shape that has the smallest possible area for a given volume is a *sphere*. Water droplets tend to be somewhat flattened on Earth, but in space they are perfectly spherical.

text: You are citing the Sign Convention for Passive Components. In the circuit above there are two mesh currents iI and iII. The oddball one is iII because it is flowing UP through the middle resistor. The Sign Convention is not saying you _can't_ have that; what its telling you is you better be careful when applying Ohm's Law to that resistor and iII. Because iII is flowing backwards through the resistor (coming in the - voltage terminal), the Ohm's Law equation has to include a negative sign in the product of (iII R). HCl gas is very soluble in water. If an ordinary delivery tube were dipped into water, the water would rapidly rise up the tube as the gas dissolves and soon water would enter the flask containing the reaction mixture. As hot concentrated sulfuric acid is often used in this preparation, the admission of cold water to the flask would be dangerous. If people use an inverted funnel that dips into the water, as hydrogen chloride reaches the funnel, water rises up inside the funnel. However, the water cannot go very far, as the liquid seal is broken, thus causing the water to fall back.

Further apart orbitals are associated with higher energy levels. If an element is more electronegative than it attracts other atoms and makes electrons scroll down to the lower energy states. text: Intermolecular bonds break easier, but that does not mean first. Statistically, intermolecular bonds will break more often than covalent or ionic bonds. They can both break at the same time, it is just a matter of probability. Water, for example is always evaporating, even if not boiling. But, then, why no hydrogen or oxygen is observed as a product of pure water? Because water decomposes into H+ and OH- when the covalent bond breaks. The concentration of each of these ions in pure water, at 25 degree Celsius, and pressure of 1atm, is 1.010e7mol/L... that is: covalent bonds are breaking all the time (self-ionization), just like intermolecular bonds (evaporation). By the way, that is what makes both pH and pOH of water equal 7. Note that even though H+ and OH- are naturally produced in water, they also recombine back into H2O. The speed of bonds breaking and the speed of recombination fight one another, until they are in chemical equilibrium, that is when both speeds are the same. For instance, this kind of fight also happens with evaporation inside a closed recipient. The equilibrium is reached when the number of molecules escaping from the liquid phase is the same as the number of molecules entering it. An electron is defined by a wave function and the square of the wave function informs us of the probability of finding the electron in particular places, and this gives rise to the concept of an "electron cloud" which is the familiar picture of an orbital. When a bond is formed, atomic orbitals are replaced by molecular orbitals, but the "rules" stay the same, in that we can only refer to the probability of finding an electron at a certain position.

context1: Intermolecular bonds break easier, but that does not mean first. Statistically, intermolecular bonds will break more often than covalent or ionic bonds. They can both break at the same time, it is just a matter of probability. Water, for example is always evaporating, even if not boiling. But, then, why no hydrogen or oxygen is observed as a product of pure water? Because water decomposes into H+ and OH- when the covalent bond breaks. The concentration of each of these ions in pure water, at 25 degree Celsius, and pressure of 1atm, is 1.010e7mol/L... that is: covalent bonds are breaking all the time (self-ionization), just like intermolecular bonds (evaporation). By the way, that is what makes both pH and pOH of water equal 7. Note that even though H+ and OH- are naturally produced in water, they also recombine back into H2O. The speed of bonds breaking and the speed of recombination fight one another, until they are in chemical equilibrium, that is when both speeds are the same. For instance, this kind of fight also happens with evaporation inside a closed recipient. The equilibrium is reached when the number of molecules escaping from the liquid phase is the same as the number of molecules entering it.

text: the nucleotide sequences will be different. However, since we're normally considering genes within the same species it's normally quite easy to determine that two genes are 'the same' (by which we mean the genes were the same in a common ancestor, but one or both have mutated since then). Often the gene will be thousands of nucleotides long, so a few base pair differences means they are still 99% identical. It could be that one gene has a large deletion or insertion, but it's still possible to find identical regions. There are various alignment tools that give you a measure of how similar two sequences are. It's possible that two alleles could have completely different sequences, but you can still see that they are the 'same' gene based on the function of the protein they encode or by their position on the genome. But remember that allele is just a human invention to make it easy to compare different genomes. It just refers to the different sequences that an organism can inherit. It could be that one allele is a single copy of a gene whereas another allele is having three copies of the gene, or no copies of that gene. As with a lot of biology there are no hard and fast rules and definitions get blurry at the edges. The way to identify nucleophiles and electrophiles is by differences in electronegativity. Often, when an electronegative atom is bonded to a less electronegative one, the less electronegative atom becomes an electrophile as it has a partial positive charge. Lone pairs of electrons on some atoms can sometimes act as nucleophiles.
question: What makes the two different alleles the same gene?

There are various alignment tools that give you a measure of how similar two sequences are. It's possible that two alleles could have completely different sequences, but you can still see that they are the 'same' gene based on the function of the protein they encode or by their position on the genome. But remember that allele is just a human invention to make it easy to compare different genomes. It just refers to the different sequences that an organism can inherit. It could be that one allele is a single copy of a gene whereas another allele is having three copies of the gene, or no copies of that gene. As with a lot of biology there are no hard and fast rules and definitions get blurry at the edges.

text: That could happen, but it is unlikely. Remember that there are only a few free Cl atoms at any one time, but there are lots of CH4 molecules. The chances of a Cl atom hitting a CH4 molecule are much greater than of its hitting anything else, so you are going to get mostly CH3Cl. If you have lots of Cl2, then towards the end of the reaction, when you have more CH3Cl, the Cl atom will start hitting the CH3Cl molecules and forming CHCl2.  A nucleophile is a Lewis base (an electron pair donor). Let's represent it as Nu:-. An electrophile is a Lewis acid (an electron pair acceptor). Let's represent it as E+. Now, let's compare chloride ion, Cl-, and a chlorine molecule, Cl2. Cl- is a pretty good *nucleophile*, because it has four lone pairs and a negative charge. It can react with some electrophile, E+ Cl:- + E+  Cl-E Now let's look at Cl2 as a nucleophile. It has six lone pairs, so it should be a good nucleophile, right? *Wrong*. Cl2 acting as a nucleophile with E+ would give: Cl-Cl: + E+  Cl+ + Cl-E The reaction would form Cl+, but this won't happen because Cl is the second most electronegative atom in the Periodic Table. It won't easily give up its electrons to form a positive ion. Rather, Cl2 will act as an *electrophile* in a reaction like Nu:- + Cl-Cl  Nu-Cl + :Cl- This generates a nice, stable chloride ion, so everybody is happy. Summary, chloride ion is a nucleophile but chlorine is an electrophile.

text: Think of voltage as elevation on a mountain. Suppose people take a hike starting at some elevation (typically the bottom of the mountain where elevation = 0). As people hike up, their elevation (voltage) increases. When people reach a high point and walk down, their elevation (voltage) decreases. People walk all day, up and down and all around the mountainside. At the end of their hike them return to their starting point. If people come back to their starting point, all the ups and downs their total change of elevation is 0. That is the essence of Kirchhoff's Voltage Law. Through transpiration water forms droplets on the surface of the leaves. Those droplets transform into water vapor and leave the plant surface and become part of humidity in the atmosphere. That way water is back to the water cycle.
question: Why do the voltages have to add to zero when we end up back at the same voltage?
context1: Think of voltage as elevation on a mountain. Suppose people take a hike starting at some elevation (typically the bottom of the mountain where elevation = 0). (which can be termed as medium of the reaction: acidic medium if an acid is used and similarly, basic medium) Now, an acid provides H+ ions(more appropriately it donates H30+ ions since H+ combines with water to from H30+ ions or hydronium ions). Similarly, a base donates hydroxyl ions. We decide the quantity and concentration of the acid or base used depending on the number of H+ or OH- ions we may need. As long as the reaction is taking place in an acidic medium, there should be enough protons for the reaction to happen.

text: Only the valence electrons in a conductor metal atom usually are involved in the flow of current (1 to 3 out of the many electrons a metal atom has. Copper has 29). These valence electrons too are loosely bound to the nucleus and can be used for current flow easily, this is because on losing a certain number of electrons these metal atoms actually gain stability in some ways. Also, even when they participate in current flow the electrons are still there near every metal atom (a bit like water flowing in a pipe). So as a combination of all these factors it doesn't lead to instability. But yes, if you tried to extract say 10, or even 5 electrons from copper atom got them away then the copper atom would be quite unstable. Propanal and acetone have the same molecular mass and about the same intermolecular forces, so they should have about the same boiling point. question: Would not the atoms become unstable?
context1: Only the valence electrons in a conductor metal atom usually are involved in the flow of current (1 to 3 out of the many electrons a metal atom has. Copper has 29). These valence electrons too are loosely bound to the nucleus and can be used for current flow easily, this is because on losing a certain number of electrons these metal atoms actually gain stability in some ways. Also, even when they participate in current flow the electrons are still there near every metal atom (a bit like water flowing in a pipe). So as a combination of all these factors it doesn't lead to instability. But yes, if you tried to extract say 10, or even 5 electrons from copper atom got them away then the copper atom would be quite unstable.
context2: Propanal molecules can form H bonds to protic solvents, but not to other propanal molecules. Propanal and acetone have the same molecular mass and about the same intermolecular forces, so they should have about the same boiling point. The boiling point of acetone is 56  degree Celsius, and the boiling point of propanal is 49  degree Celsius. They are close enough

text: The enzyme would have no specificity and would create reactions indiscriminately. The enzyme can flex, but if you try to stretch it too far it breaks. The most common way for the sequence of nucleotides in DNA to affect as trait is by being transcribed into mRNA and then translated into protein. However, DNA also encodes many other types of RNA, some of which will affect traits. In addition, changes in control sequences in the DNA can affect whether and at what rate RNAs get made (sequences that get transcribed within an RNA can also affect its stability and processing). These changes can affect traits indirectly by influencing how much of an RNA is present in cell.

text: Benzoic acid is a common name.numbering the ring because the substituent was on the benzene base, thus you start numbering the 1 carbon where the carboxylic acid functional group is attached to that benzene ring. In the commonly-named form, that carbonyl carbon is considered to be a part of the substituent and thus doesn't add to the ring numbering. The same reactions occur if we add very little base and a lot of acid to if we add same amounts of acid and base, but only until the dissociation products of either the acid or the base run out. To neutralize you need to add enough acid to a base to turn all HO- into H2O (when neutralizing a base) or enough base to an acid to turn all H+ into H2O (when neutralizing an acid). Keep in mind that some acids produce more H+ per volume than others, and the same goes with HO- for bases. So, you may want to check that before you start mixing, as a little of a powerful base can neutralize a lot of weak acid. the process will change, though this depends on the acid and the base just as much as the ratio in which you mix them. If there is an imbalance in the H+ and OH-, the neutralization will fail.

text: The law of conservation of mass by Antoine Lavoisier states that mass can neither by created or destroyed. Suppose you burn a piece of paper. Ash is created and some fumes are generated. Now, if we add the mass of the ash and the fumes, we will see that the mass of the original paper and the the end product (ash and fumes) is the same. We can see some other examples also. Similarly, if We have one oxygen atom on one side and two oxygen atoms on the other side due to the reaction, this wouldn't be reasonable with the experiment we made by burning the paper. Hence, we balance the equation. Water vapourizes at 100 degrees celsius but evaporates at a lower temperature. Vapourization is the change from liquid to gas at a fixed or definite temperature whereas evaporation is the change from liquid to gas at a variable temperature. the boiling temperature is the temperature at which the vapour pressure of the liquid is equal to the atmospheric pressure. If heat is added, the liquid will start to boil and bubbles of vapour can withstand the atmospheric pressure and escape the liquid. High up in the mountains, atmospheric pressure is low. The boiling temperature of water is only 93  degree Celsius at 2000 metres. the mercury boiling point is around 357 degree C, but evaporation can happen all the time, slowly, on the surface, as the particles get enough energy to separate themselves from the forces of attraction that hold them together.

text: In mitosis, the parent cell is diploid, which means that they will have 46 chromosomes (2n). The resulting 2 daughter cells are identical to each other and the parent cell, so they will also have 46 chromosomes (diploid; 2n). This is different for meiosis [the parent cell has 46 chromosomes and the 4 resulting daughter cells each have 23 chromosomes (haploid)] The most common way for the sequence of nucleotides in DNA to affect as trait is by being transcribed into mRNA and then translated into protein. However, DNA also encodes many other types of RNA, some of which will affect traits. In addition, changes in control sequences in the DNA can affect whether and at what rate RNAs get made (sequences that get transcribed within an RNA can also affect its stability and processing). These changes can affect traits indirectly by influencing how much of an RNA is present in cell.

text: The limiting factor is the wavelength of the light which make it hard to see separate points which are closer together then this distance. There are new methods (superresolution microscopy) which can deal with this, but a everyday microscope will be bound to this borders. Light can have different wavelength, that means it got different energies/colors. Red light has a long wavelength and less energy the short wave violet light or UV-light. Light slows down when it goes from air to glass, and then it speeds up when it goes from glass to air. When it speeds up or slows down like this and it hits the air/glass boundary at an angle, the path of the light gets bent. This is called refraction, and sal has a video that explains it. The angle of refraction is governed by Snell's Law. A prism is shaped so that it bends the light twice, in the same direction both times. The amount that the light gets bent depends a little bit on the frequency of the light. So when you put white light into the prism, the light doesn't all get bent the same amount, which means that it comes out spread out into a spectrum.

text: glucose is a sugar that we consume in our diet, we store it in our body as glycogen... why do we store it? 2 main reasons; 1.) so that we do not become hyperactive and have too much energy used all at once or 2.) so our blood glucose levels will become normal because too much glucose in the blood leads to a serious case of hyperglycemia aka diabetes. Glycogen helps us get energy when we need it by storing excess glucose from our diet CO2 is used in our body. It is used in synthesizing Urea (that's the excretory content of urine) from Ammonia. Our body produces a lot of ammonia from protein metabolism. This ammonia is particularly harmful and requires a large amount of water. So, our super intelligent liver converts it Urea, which is less toxic and requires less amount of water to be excreted. This it does by combining CO2 to ammonia in some sort of cycle (ornithine or urea cycle). Co2 is also used in fatty acid synthesis and gluconeogenesis

text: We know because of the magnetic field. Theoretically, we can't prove the existence of the core of the earth but there is no other way that the magnetic field of the earth and other planets are possible. It even explains the lack of magnetic field for things like the moon or Mars. Everything in science is a theory. We have seismic data that suggests there is something very dense at the center of the earth. We know that the core gives off heat. It makes sense that the heaviest elements would go to the center of the planet as the planet formed. Neither mitosis nor meiosis are cycles. They are both processes involved in two different types of cell division and both are parts of cycles. Mitotic divisions can happen repeatedly as part of the mitotic cell cycle. Meiotic divisions happen as part of a more complex cycle that includes fertilization (fusion of two gametes) to form a zygote. That zygote has the potential to become a new organism that will then have some cells that undergo meiosis to produce new gametes. Multicellular organisms contain many cells and the germ line cells$ in animals undergo both mitosis and meiosis. The mitotic divisions maintain the population of germ cells and the excess cells undergo meiosis to produce gametes. Does that help? $Note: The cells that can undergo meiosis.

text: Gay and bisexual orientations are behavioural variations resulting from the expression of a regular gene set. If your question is really about hermaphroditism then such individuals possess cells with 46 xy and 46 xx sets of chromosomes and exhibit sexual characteristics of both males and females. entire chromosomes are very long (100s of millions of base pairs in humans) and can't be meaningfully compared using gel electrophoresis. The speed of DNA migration during gel electrophoresis mostly depends on the length of the DNA, not the sequence. This means a given piece of DNA from different species (or individuals) might or might not differ in their migration even though they have different sequences. Furthermore, two different alleles within a single organism often result in different lengths of DNA. To do identification of species often requires much more precision that you get with gel electrophoresis (and even more precision is needed to separate individuals within a species).

text: Passive transport basically does not require any form of energy compared to active transport. In the case of osmosis,the water moves from areas of HIGH WATER concentration to areas of LOW WATER concentration, which makes it a form of passive transport. It uses no energy to move, it just drifts into lower concentrations of WATER. WATER not other materials, only WATER. Osmosis deals with water. It is possible to determine the probability that a single atomic nucleus will 'survive' during a given interval. This probability amounts to 50% for one half-life. In an interval twice as long (2 T) the nucleus survives only with a 25% probability (half of 50%), in an interval of three half-life periods (3 T) only with 12.5% (half of 25%), and so on. You can't, however, predict the time at which a given atomic nucleus will decay. For example, even if the probability of a decay within the next second is 99%, it is nevertheless possible (but improbable) that the nucleus will decay only after millions of years. It's like flipping a coin. If you flip 'heads' ten times in a row, what are the chances that the next flip will be 'heads'. You might say, 'I've flipped ten heads in a row. The next one is much more likely to come up 'tails'. Nevertheless, your chances of flipping heads are the same as before: 1 out of 2. Some nuclei are much luckier at flipping the coin than others. They keep flipping until they get 'tails'; then they decay.

text: Equilibrium arrows show that a reaction proceeds significantly in both directions such that it will/can reach equilibrium. This doe snot necessarily mean that the change in Gibbs free energy is 0 though, since the reaction might not be at equilibrium yet. For example, when you first add the reactants, deltaG will not be 0. Once the forward and reverse rates of the reaction are equal though, deltaG will be 0. There are several definitions to acids and bases, all of which were created relatively at the same time. The Arrhenius theory states an acid donates a hydronium ion/proton(H+) and a base donates a hydroxide (OH-) subsequently increasing the concentration of each in a solution. The Bronstead-Lowry definition states an acid and base react to form their conjugate base and conjugate acid conterparts with the exchange of a proton (H+). Finally, the most emcompassing definition comes from Lewis theory. It states an acid is one that accepts electron pair (i.e. an electrophile) and a base is one that donates an electron pair (i.e. a nucleophile).

Finally, the most emcompassing definition comes from Lewis theory. It states an acid is one that accepts electron pair (i.e. an electrophile) and a base is one that donates an electron pair (i.e. a nucleophile).

text: When half the pixels are black and half are white, this is the highest entropy. The reason for this is that, if you consider every different possible arrangement of pixels that would give 50% black and 50% white, there are more possibilities for this 50/50 split than for any other percentage split. This makes the 50/50 split the most probable, and thus it has the highest entropy. some of these possibilities might look 'organized', for example a bunch of black pixels grouped together (though this arrangement is improbable). This would be one of many microstates (i.e. individual possible arrangements of pixels) that contributes to the maximum entropy macrostate (i.e. the big picture that there is a 50/50 split between black and white pixels). If you limited yourself to only having a bunch of black pixels grouped together, however, then the entropy would be lower, since the probability of this happening is lower once you introduce a restriction. In the pixel system, low entropy would be if all of the pixels were black or all of the pixels were white. The frequency range could be determined ed only if you knew what elements and how they are bonded.

text: plants also do cellular respiration - taking in oxygen and giving out CO2. Cellular respiration occurs in the mitochondria. Now since photosynthesis creates glucose, why do we need mitochondria? the biological 'currency' is ATP. So we need to convert the glucose into ATP. This is done in the mitochondria and is called cellular respiration. We humans only do cellular respiration since we are heterotrophs - we don't make our own glucose. The more the substrate, the more the enzymatic activity because an enzyme cannot exhibit catalytic activity on the thin air.

Similarly, a base donates hydroxyl ions. We decide the quantity and concentration of the acid or base used depending on the number of H+ or OH- ions we may need. As long as the reaction is taking place in an acidic medium, there should be enough protons for the reaction to happen. the origin of samples might be the same. text: In water at room temperature, the molecules have a certain *average* kinetic energy. But some of them will be moving faster, and some of them will be slower. Some of the molecules at the surface of the water will have enough kinetic energy to escape into the atmosphere. The water will slowly evaporate, even though it is at room temperature. Homologous chromosomes are two different versions (as in A vs. a) of a chromosome with the same function. These chromosomes that he is pointing to just haven't replicated themselves into sister chromatids yet. Sister chromatids are two identical copies of the same chromosome, linked at the centromere (middle portion) immediately after replication. They're shown as the 'X' shapes in the next cell of the flowchart.

text: (S,S) is a diastereomer of (S,R) and also of (R,S). And (R,R) is a diastereomer of (S,R) and also (R,S). All 4 molecules could be chiral or optically active.  Zeroth law is not really relevant because it's about things that are in thermal equilibrium and we don't have thermal equilibrium here First law says energy of a closed system is conserved. The fridge is surrounded by air and plugged into an electrical socket, so it's not a closed system. Second law says entropy of a closed system won't decrease. Again, we don't have a closed system, but it's also easy to see (assuming you understand what entropy is) that as the soup cools, entropy of the soup/fridge system is increasing, not decreasing, so there's no issue. Third law says there's no fridge that can ever get the soup to absolute zero

text: photon frequency are exact. The precision must be extremely high - within the bounds of the Heisenberg uncertainty principle. You might as well just say it has to be exact. If there's not a precise match, the photon will not be absorbed. The Heisenberg Uncertainty Principle says that the energy levels are not exact unless the uncertainty in the time (lifetime of the excited state) is infinite. Of greater practical importance are two factors which give rise to non-zero line widths (the widths at half-height of the line profiles): (1) the Doppler effect, since atoms moving toward you will appear to emit light of slightly higher frequencies (a blue shift) whereas atoms moving away from you will appear to emit light of slightly lower frequencies (a red shift), and this effect becomes more pronounced at higher temperatures, since the average speeds of the molecules becomes greater, and (2) pressure broadening, since atoms or molecules colliding with each other have electrons with motions perturbed from their state in isolated atoms or molecules. The catalyst creates a new reaction profile. Instead of one step, the reaction now takes place in two steps with lower activation energies (the peaks). The transition state is at the peak. The transition state is at the peak and the intermediate is at the valley in between the two peaks.
question: Does the electron go into an energy level 1/100000 higher, or where does the extra energy go?
context1: photon frequency are exact. The precision must be extremely high - within the bounds of the Heisenberg uncertainty principle. You might as well just say it has to be exact. If there's not a precise match, the photon will not be absorbed. The Heisenberg Uncertainty Principle says that the energy levels are not exact unless the uncertainty in the time (lifetime of the excited state) is infinite. Of greater practical importance are two factors which give rise to non-zero line widths (the widths at half-height of the line profiles): (1) the Doppler effect, since atoms moving toward you will appear to emit light of slightly higher frequencies (a blue shift) whereas atoms moving away from you will appear to emit light of slightly lower frequencies (a red shift), and this effect becomes more pronounced at higher temperatures, since the average speeds of the molecules becomes greater, and (2) pressure broadening, since atoms or molecules colliding with each other have electrons with motions perturbed from their state in isolated atoms or molecules.

The size of an atom does affect both the nuclear charge and the ionization energy. First of all, If an atom has more protons in its nucleus, then the nuclear charge will obviously be greater, so the ionization energy will be higher. But just as Jay said, you also have to take into account the distance between the electrons and the nucleus, as well as electron shielding/screening. A larger atom will have more distance between the nucleus and the farthest electrons, so it will be easier for that atom to lose an electron. Also, a larger atom will have more electrons, which will all repel each other and push the outer electrons away from the nucleus (at least, that's what I would think). Both of these factors will lower the ionization energy.

The substrates no longer fit into the shape of the active site to form an enzyme-substrate complex, so the rate of the enzymatic reaction decreases.

text: Interestingly enough, so-called idiot savants, do not have a greater capacity for computation, music, or art. Instead, the parts of their brains responsible for such tasks dominate the rest of their brain because the parts that would normally compete for attention are either damaged or unable to communicate effectively with the rest of the brain. Researchers have used something called TMS (trans-cranial magnetic stimulation) to induce small currents in parts of the brain, either shutting down or activating specific regions of the brain temporarily. Their research has shown that it is possible to temporarily induce a savant-like state in normally functioning brains. And, of course, some forms of brain damage can induce temporary or permanent savant-like states as well. Certain Plants do grow better around each other and help each other out. Researcher Dr. David Johnson looked closely at plants' symbiotic relationship with soil fungus, piggybacking off a 2010 study that seemed to suggest that a tomato plant infected with leaf blight would be able to warn nearby plants of the problem. In turn, those plants would activate genes that would prevent them from catching the disease, too. Johnson was able to show how plants use fungus in the soil as a network (think of it as a botanical Wi-Fi, if you will). Essentially, fungi deliver messages of danger from plant to plant, and as a result, the group can grow stronger. Even plants get by with a little help from their friends. *Animals* help plants by pollinating them, and be helping to disperse seeds. The droppings of animals also fertilize plants. Plants have three basic responses or reactions to light. They are photosynthesis, phototropism and photoperiodism. As plants react/respond to light the amount of heat wont matter anyway.

text: all the reducing agents undergo oxidation themselves and oxidation is the loss of electrons and that reduction is gain of electrons. Ionistasion potential determines the ease with with an element can lose an electron. Lithium has high ionisation potential ,. i.e it can lose electrons with much ease than any other metal and reducing agents lose electrons( the easier they lose electrosn the stronger reducing agents they are) and that lithium can lose electrons with greater ease. hence it is strong reducing agent. BH3 is violently reactive on its own, so THF is used to stabilize the molecule. The BH3 essentially accepts an electron pair from the THF to complete its octet and form a stable BH3-THF complex. Think of THF as a calming agent. As far as the others are concerned: NaOH serves to remove a proton from H2O2, making it HO2, a better nucleophile (conjugate bases are always stronger nucleophiles). HO2 then attacks the boron to complete the rearrangement reaction, and the O is ultimately protonated with H2O to form a neutral alcohol. Keto-enol tautomerism kicks in here and the (C=O) bond is highly favored.

text: Usually, a carbon needs four different substituents to be a chiral center. It is more sophisticated and accurate to think that carbons must be sp3 hybridized to four different substituents in order to be a chiral center. Allenes are an exception, but since they are so rare you probably do not need to worry about them. In regard to carbanions: Remember that a lone pair of electrons counts as a substituent, so carbanions with three different atomic substituents are chiral centers. Conversely, carbocations are not chiral centers because a plane of symmetry exists down each of its three bonds: The same is true of the three bonds of carbons with a double bond. So, a carbon with only three groups attached to it--but all three groups are different--is not a chiral center, but a 'pro-chiral' center. each of the four dots represent one electron (4 total) but then you also have two lines, which represent covalent bonds, and each line contains two electrons (2*2lines=4electrons). Combined you have your 8 electrons which fulfils the octet rule and oxygen is stable in the compound.

In regard to carbanions: Remember that a lone pair of electrons counts as a substituent, so carbanions with three different atomic substituents are chiral centers. Conversely, carbocations are not chiral centers because a plane of symmetry exists down each of its three bonds: The same is true of the three bonds of carbons with a double bond. Parallel conductance is simply a different viewpoint of parallel resistors. It's the same circuit configuration, but uses a different equation. The "conductance" viewpoint looks at a parallel resistor and instead of seeing a 1/R term in the parallel resistor formula, it sees a G = 1/R term. When you use the conductance viewpoint, the formula (G1 + G2 + G3... = Gequiv) strongly resembles the formula for series resistors. That doesn't mean its the same, its just a strong resemblance. Relationships like the one between parallel conductance and series resistance are common in electrical engineering. They are called "Duals" of each other.

text: The nucleophile is not reacting with the solvent. It is being surrounded by a shell of solvent molecules. The F- ion is small, so it has a high charge density, and the water molecules are held tightly to it. The I- ion is large, so it has a low charge density, and the water molecules are held loosely to it. A nucleophile has to push the solvent molecules out of the way in order to attack the substrate, so F- is a poorer nucleophile in a polar protic solvent.  The area under the velocity/time curve is the total displacement. If you divide that by the change in time, you will get the average velocity. Velocity is the vector form of speed. If velocity is always non-negative, then average velocity and average speed are the same.
question: Why is I- a better nucleophile in a polar protic solvent?
context1: The nucleophile is not reacting with the solvent. It is being surrounded by a shell of solvent molecules. The F- ion is small, so it has a high charge density, and the water molecules are held tightly to it. The I- ion is large, so it has a low charge density, and the water molecules are held loosely to it. A nucleophile has to push the solvent molecules out of the way in order to attack the substrate, so F- is a poorer nucleophile in a polar protic solvent.
context2: The area under the velocity/time curve is the total displacement. If you divide that by the change in time, you will get the average velocity. Velocity is the vector form of speed. If velocity is always non-negative, then average velocity and average speed are the same.

text: We can't 'see' the electrons with our instruments, but we can see the atoms and measure their bond lengths and bond angles. That's why we ignore the lone pair electrons in determining *molecular geometry*. We must, however, consider the lone pairs in determining the *electron geometry* about an atom. Neurons are the most unique cells in our body. Some are extremely small, while others are very large. In general, neurons do not repair well. If several neurons were damaged, such as in a spinal cord injury, you already know the individual would be paralyzed and it is unlikely the individual would ever walk again. If a portion of a neuron is damaged, it may or may not be able to find and re-connect with itself. If the axon is damaged, the myelin cells such as Schwann cells form a tunnel to help direct the axon to the other portion. Never-the-less, even after several years, if you touch an area of your body that has a scar, you will realize that touch or feeling over that scar has changed and it is not as sensitive as it once was because the receptors and axons were damaged when the skin was damaged. Now, even though the skin is well healed, the nervous tissue has not healed and therefore the sense of touch is poor over that scar. Epithelial tissue and connective tissue heal well, but nervous tissue does not have the ability to divide and replace neurons that have been damaged so it does not heal well.

context1: We can't 'see' the electrons with our instruments, but we can see the atoms and measure their bond lengths and bond angles. In biology, you are typically shown one gene, one repressor, one co-repressor. But you have to imagine the vast majority of biological processes involve 100,000 e.coli cells, each with hundreds or thousands of tryptophan repressor molecules. The more tryptophan present, the more likely it is to bind to one of those repressors and inhibit (reduce) transcription of the gene. The less tryptophan present, the less likely it will bind to the repressor.

text: Osmosis is the movement of water via a semipermeable membrane from a less concentrated solution to a more concentrated solution. A less concentrated solution has more water than a more concentrated solution. In essence, the water is moving down its concentration gradient from the less concentrated to the more concentrated solution to equalize the concentration on both sides of the semipermeable membrane. The air is forced in and out of our lungs via the diaphragm. The diaphragm is an involuntary muscle but can be controlled. Lungs are controlled by involuntary muscles, but can also be controlled via voluntary muscles. So under 'normal' conditions they are controlled via the involuntary muscles, i.e subconscious/with-out thinking, and voluntary when we try to control the rate we are breathing, so we use our abdomen muscles to 'mold' the lungs into a smaller shape, thus slowing down the breathing rate, or holding your breath while swimming, etc. As to your second question, either way you are still getting air in, however by breathing via your 'stomach' it allows for more air to be breathed in, compared to breathing via your 'chest', thus allowing for more gas exchange, due to the increase in surface area : volume ratio, other than that, I don't believe there is anything 'better'. Apparently it also allows you to 'sing' and speak better, and for longer bursts before having to breath again

text: the thing that determines which element it is, is the number of protons not electrons. The conservation of energy formula goes Ki+Ui=Kf+Uf. U is potential energy and K is kinetic energy. In this case the golf ball at the start has zero potential energy. We are considering the surface of the moon to be the height h. The height is zero therefore, we have no initial potential energy(mgh). We are left with Ki=Kf+Uf=>1/2m(vi)^2=1/2m(vf)^2+mgh. text: Sound is a compression, not physical matter or energy (which is why sound needs a medium to travel through). An air particle moving faster than sound would not cause a sonic boom because an air particle is a medium, not an actual sound wave. It's the compression that causes the boom, regardless of how fast the actual particles are moving. Homology is defined as the property of being descended from a common ancestor. This can apply to structures, DNA sequences, or even behaviors that can be traced back to an ancestor shared by two (or more) species. As one example, the fore limbs of all mammals (including: bat wings, whale flippers, primate arms, and the front legs of quadrupeds) are homologous - they all are variations on the front limbs of the first shrew-like mammals. Relative position within an organism is one very important piece of evidence for a structure being homologous. Another type of evidence is developmental - do the structures develop in the same way.

text: ll bare protons absorb at the same frequency and field strength. Let's call them v0 and B0. But protons in molecules are shielded by the electrons around them. That means that a higher external field will be needed to achieve resonance. Protons that are less shielded will require a lower external/frequency. Protons that are more shielded will require a higher external/frequency.  Water's high specific heat _is_ do to its hydrogen bonds. Water coheres to itself because of the slightly positive and slightly negative charges of the hydrogen and oxygen, respectively. To break these bonds (there are more than one could possibly count just in a drop of water), it takes a lot of energy. This is why an iron pot heats up so much while the water inside is only slightly warm (because the iron has a lower specific heat than water!).

text: The 2V source is just another battery. The circuit analysis methods (Node Voltage, Mesh Current) are intended to be by-the-book algorithms (recipes) for solving any circuit. If you trust the steps you don't have to think about anything else. You don't have to worry that If the 2V source points this way then I have to make sure its mesh current flows a certain direction. We started out curling both mesh currents in the clock-wise direction. When we got to the solution it turned out i2 had a negative value, indicating that the current flows out of the top of the 2V source, just like you would expect. There is no crime if you have a mesh current with a negative value. The reason we curl all the mesh currents in the same direction is to encourage correct writing of mesh equations, especially when two mesh currents flow through one resistor (the 1kohm resistor in this circuit). You get accustomed to writing that terms with a +meshcurrent and a -meshcurrent. This habit helps reduce careless sign errors. That feature is more important than trying to eliminate a negative sign from the final answer. It is analogous to all the acyl substitutions you are learning and will learn. The sulfur must change geometry, to tetrahedral, before it collapses back down to eject the chlorocalcite leaving group.
