text: Life is an emergent property -- that means a property held by the whole that is not held by the parts. The chemicals of which life is composed are neither alive nor dead, but collectively they can have the properties we call life. Emergent properties are not at all unusual. For example, cotton fibers are quite easily pulled apart, but twisted together and woven into cloth they take on an emergent property of being quite strong. Individual drops of water do not have the property of 'storm' but a lot of water can. And so it is with life. Life is an emergent property that a vast number of chemicals can sometimes take on, though the individual chemicals do not have this property. There could be something behind a black hole like an infinite randomness. Because according to Stephen Hawking universe originates in white holes and ends in black holes. So the laws of universe may not apply there.

text: Semipermeable and selectively permeable can be slightly different in meaning, though this usage is not consistent. Semipermeable is typically used as an overall term for membranes that only allow some molecules to pass through - in some cases this is used exclusively for selection based on molecule (or ion) size. Selectively permeable just means that some molecules can pass through the membrane based on their properties, but most molecules or ions can not pass through the membrane. Different semipermeable membranes may let different size molecules pass through - an example of this is dialysis membranes (or tubing), which can be made with pore sizes that will allow small macromolecules (e.g. proteins) to pass through while restricting larger macromolecules. Decay is primarily due to the actions of prokaryotes and fungi. oxidation and high-energy particles (e.g cosmic rays) will gradually break down molecules in a corpse (or anything else), but this is a *very* slow process. Even without removing microbes an embalmed corpse in a sealed coffin can remain intact for centuries - Individual cells can (and do) self-destruct - this is known as apoptosis, but this doesn't seem to have a significant effect on whole organisms; it ceases soon after the organism dies since it requires energy.

text: This is an essential cycle that never stops until you die: ADP gets phosphorylated in the mitochondria, storing energy in ATP, and the ATP gets used to perform cellular work, releasing its energy in coupled reactions, and transforming back to ADP. Hydrogen bonds and London dispersion forces are both examples of van der Waals forces, a general term for intermolecular interactions that do not involve covalent bonds or ions. In a water molecule, the bond connecting the oxygen to each hydrogen is a polar bond. In a polar covalent bond containing hydrogen (e.g., an O-H bond in a water molecule). The hydrogen-oxygen bond in water is not a hydrogen bond, but only a polar covalent bond. However, after hydrogen and oxygen have formed a water molecule and hydrogen has become partially positive, then the hydrogen atoms become attracted to nearby negative charges and are 'available' for hydrogen bonding. The hydrogen bond between these hydrogen atoms and the nearby negatively charged atoms is weak and doesn't involve the covalent bond between hydrogen and oxygen. Thus, hydrogen bonding is a van der Waals force.

The hydrogen-oxygen bond in water is not a hydrogen bond, but only a polar covalent bond. However, after hydrogen and oxygen have formed a water molecule and hydrogen has become partially positive, then the hydrogen atoms become attracted to nearby negative charges and are 'available' for hydrogen bonding. The hydrogen bond between these hydrogen atoms and the nearby negatively charged atoms is weak and doesn't involve the covalent bond between hydrogen and oxygen. Thus, hydrogen bonding is a van der Waals force.

text: Symporters and antiporters use the energy stored in the electrochemical gradient. Depending on which membrane is being discussed, the electrochemical gradient may created by either metabolic processes (e.g. the electron transport chain in mitochondria) and/or by using ATP to pump ions "uphill" (against their electrochemical gradient). Secondary active transport means that, rather than directly using ATP to power the movement of compounds across the membrane, proteins like symporters and antiporters use the energy stored in the electrochemical gradient. The electrochemical gradient is the combined "push" due to concentration and charge differences across the membrane. It is highly regulated and dynamic. While it is not literally like line in factiry producing your car, it is highly regulated and there is no time for 'wandering0 around. IT has to be that way to ensure homeostasis, especially during mitosis when Golgi disassembles. So Phosphoinositide lipids are important regulators of Golgi function. Reversible phosphorylation of the inositol headgroup of phosphatidylinositol creates seven distinct phosphoinositide species. These molecules serve as signal transducers at virtually every cellular membrane but have a particularly important role in controlling membrane traffic. Golgi serves as an important signaling platform for numerous signaling cascades that originate at the plasma membrane. There is also PKC PKD signaling, RAS MAP Kinases etc.

text: there is one enzyme which is crucial for translation and that is "aminoacyl tRNA synthetase". This enzyme attaches an amino acid to the tRNA. There is a different version of this for every different amino acid (so 20 of these in human bodies). The enzyme is a "synthetase" because it creates a new structure called "aminoacyl-tRNA", which is the tRNA which has an amino acid linked to it. The word "aminoacyl" means that an amino acid is linked to something, in this case tRNA. This process happens BEFORE the tRNA enters the ribosome and it takes place in the cytosol. ATP is required for that reaction. To make it easier to follow electron movement, we usually draw all the free electron pairs and electrons on atoms. In the case of a homolytic bond breakage, the atom is left with a single electron. Thats why we show a dot on each atom. A radical is usually very reactive and likes to bond quickly. So most of the time a radical won't stay radical for a long time.

text: It was the sequence which told the polymerase to bind to the DNA. The polymerase starts at any point of the DNA and slides alongside it until it comes to a sequence which tells it to bind more to the DNA. Such sequences are called promotors. At -10 there is usually an other promotor, which causes the polymerase to bind very firm to the DNA, so that it can start its work. If it weren't there, the area of the DNA downstream the -35 DNA sequence wouldn't be transcripted. But the transcription is a requirement for the translation, which in its turn is important for the production of polypeptides Symporters and antiporters use the energy stored in the electrochemical gradient. Depending on which membrane is being discussed, the electrochemical gradient may created by either metabolic processes (e.g. the electron transport chain in mitochondria) and/or by using ATP to pump ions "uphill" (against their electrochemical gradient). Secondary active transport means that, rather than directly using ATP to power the movement of compounds across the membrane, proteins like symporters and antiporters use the energy stored in the electrochemical gradient. The electrochemical gradient is the combined "push" due to concentration and charge differences across the membrane.
question: What will be the problem during transcription?

The polymerase starts at any point of the DNA and slides alongside it until it comes to a sequence which tells it to bind more to the DNA. Such sequences are called promotors. At -10 there is usually an other promotor, which causes the polymerase to bind very firm to the DNA, so that it can start its work. If it weren't there, the area of the DNA downstream the -35 DNA sequence wouldn't be transcripted. But the transcription is a requirement for the translation, which in its turn is important for the production of polypeptides

text: Water has a high surface tension because the water molecules on the surface are pulled together by strong hydrogen bonds. That means a drop of water will "Want" to have the smallest possible surface area. The shape that has the smallest possible area for a given volume is a *sphere*. Water droplets tend to be somewhat flattened on Earth, but in space they are perfectly spherical.  Decay is primarily due to the actions of prokaryotes and fungi. oxidation and high-energy particles (e.g cosmic rays) will gradually break down molecules in a corpse (or anything else), but this is a *very* slow process. Even without removing microbes an embalmed corpse in a sealed coffin can remain intact for centuries - Individual cells can (and do) self-destruct - this is known as apoptosis, but this doesn't seem to have a significant effect on whole organisms; it ceases soon after the organism dies since it requires energy

text: There are 4 types of binary fission in bacteria. Also, not all bacteria undergo binary fission, while E.coli and Salmonella do, many bacteria undergo genetical recombination such as transduction, conjugation, transformation. Binary fission as a mechanism is the same in principle. Conceptually this is a simple process; a cell just needs to grow to twice its starting size and then split in two. Genes are found on strands of DNA, they are not themselves a strand of DNA. A gene is a sequence of base pairs that code for a specific protein, not a specific phenotypic trait as such. The various proteins interact in very complex ways to form traits. So, genes do not, strictly speaking, code for phenotypic traits. However, a specific trait might be reliant on the protein produced by one gene for some key aspect of its nature. So, while we might often say the gene for this or that trait, what is more accurate is saying the gene for the protein is involved in this or that trait. Genes, in fact, tend to be involved in multiple phenotypic traits because the protein they code for can be used in a variety of ways. Alleles are variations of genes, but they may or may not produce observable differences in some phenotypic trait. The reason is that proteins tend to be very large molecules and so a few minor changes here or there in their structure may or may not have much of an effect on their functions. So, some alleles produce proteins that produce pretty much identical phenotypic traits. Also, remember that some amino acids can be coded for by more than one codon, so some alleles merely contain different ways of coding for the same protein. But, obviously, some alleles, even with minor changes, can produce proteins that lead to significantly different traits. Eye color is not a good example because there are many genes involved in that (perhaps as many as 16 genes)

text: That is an ionic bond because it includes a metal (Sodium). In ionic bonds, instead of sharing electrons, the atoms gain/lose electrons and become ions. In NaCl, Sodium loses one electron to achieve a full shell, and Chlorine sucks that electron in to get a full shell. Now, they both have full shells, but their charges are different. Sodium lost an electron, so it is now a Sodium 1+ ion, and Chlorine gained an electron, so it is now a Chloride 1- ion. The opposite charges attract, so then it becomes NaCl with a charge of zero. text: An allele is a version of a gene. Like it can be either dominant, recessive or *co-dominant*. If we speak about classic dominance patterns, a gene could be either dominant or recessive. You just observe phenotype and occurrence at which gene is displayed. If an allele is *visible* in phenotype in most cases (homozygous and heterozygous) then it is dominant. If an allele is masked by another one (dominant) and is visible only in homozygous situation, then it is recessive. The main source of motivation for baby birds is food. The baby bird knows nothing more than that at regular intervals their mother will come and drop some food off in their mouth. Slowly the mother bird will stand farther and farther away from the nest, forcing the baby bird to come out of the nest to get food. The bird realizes it needs this food to survive and this is the motivation for them to venture out onto a branch.

text: Nonpolar molecules that repel the water molecules are said to be hydrophobic; molecules forming ionic or a hydrogen bond with the water molecule is said to be hydrophilic. This property of water was important for the evolution of life. Hydrophobic interaction plays the most critical role in the formation of the lipid bilayer of the cell membrane and the folding of proteins and nucleic acids; therefore, hydrophobic interaction is the foundation for the existence of life. A self-assembled monolayer (SAM) is a layer of organic molecules formed spontaneously on a solid substrate. One end of the organic molecule binds to the solid surface via a covalent bond while the other endpoints outwards. Because the exposed end of the SAM determines the surface properties of the SAM modified substrate, we can alter a hydrophobic surface (a surface that expels water) into a hydrophilic surface (a surface that attracts water) by carefully selecting the SAM forming molecules. Snow forms when water vapor in the air turns directly into ice because it's so cold. The ice crystals grow from additional water vapor until they fall down as snow. Hail, on the other hand, is created when existing liquid rain is carried into colder areas by updrafts and freezes into a ball of ice. Because the water in many clouds is supercooled (brought past the freezing point but still in liquid form), it is easily frozen and the hail gradually grows. This continues until the hailstone becomes too heavy to stay in the clouds and falls.

text: One of the big unsolved problems in fundamental physics. in the very beginning of the universe - near what we call the Big Bang - the universe was extremely hot and extremely dense, too hot and dense for matter to exist. There was a _lot_ of energy around. But since space was also expanding very quickly, this energy was rapidly cooling down and spreading out. Eventually (after less than a few seconds) it became cold enough to condense into normal matter, in a process we have called _baryogenesis_. The problem is that our current best theories of particle physics predict that all processes that create matter must also create an equal amount of anti-matter, which would then annihilate each other leaving only light. Since we see a lot of matter all around us, this clearly is not the case. For some unknown reason, there was a lot more matter than anti-matter created in the beginning, when the universe was cooling down. Finding a better theory of particle physics which can tell us why this is is currently the job of many of the worlds physicists. To form ionic bonds, Carbon molecules must either gain or lose 4 electrons &This is highly unfavorable. therefore, carbon molecules share their 4 valence electrons through single, double, and triple bonds so that each atom can achieve noble gas configurations

text: fusion is not a chemical reaction, it is a nuclear reaction. The main difference is that in chemical reactions nuclei do not change but in nuclear reactions do. It does not appear to come from anywhere, it just exists. An electrical charge can be defined as the natural property of certain kinds of matter that cause their paths of motion to be deflected when exposed to a magnetic field. When electrical charges were first discovered, one of type of charge was arbitrarily called "negative" and the other type was arbitrarily called positive. Since the two types of charge tend to cancel each other out, picking one to call negative and the other to call positive is a reasonable convention.

text: Lithium is a stronger reducing agent than all other alkali metals. This is because Lithium (do note that all this is happening in water) has a large hydration energy (because of its small size and high charge density), and this favours the formation of the Li+ cation significantly, making Li the best reducing agent in the periodic table (and amongst alkali metals). Carbon has 4 valence electrons, and its electron configuration is 1s^2 2s^2 2p^2. Now, in order for carbon to bond appropriately 4 times you could promote an electron from the 2s orbital to the 2p orbital (thus giving you 2s^1 and 2p^3). However, these orbitals still exist at different energy levels, and thus we use hybridization. In the case of C2H4, each carbon is bonded to 3 different molecules, and thus, we only need to have 3 hybrid orbitals; we use the 2s orbital and 2 of the 2p orbitals and the sp2 hybrid orbital is created. Under this configuration, 3 of the valence electrons are in the sp2 orbitals (the ones that bond with other atoms) while the last valence electron is in the p2 shell that was not hybridized

text: An electron is defined by a wave function and the square of the wave function informs us of the probability of finding the electron in particular places, and this gives rise to the concept of an "electron cloud" which is the familiar picture of an orbital. When a bond is formed, atomic orbitals are replaced by molecular orbitals, but the "rules" stay the same, in that we can only refer to the probability of finding an electron at a certain position. Entropy is not exactly disorder it is the sum of all possible states of the given system.

text: The Earth is billions of years old. It still has a lot of residual heat left over from its formation, and additional heat is being added from radioactive decay of unstable isotopes. Also, Earth's crust and atmosphere acts as a thermal barrier, holding in heat. Add into that the radiation Earth gets from the Sun, and the net heat loss/gain varies. there is one enzyme which is crucial for translation and that is "aminoacyl tRNA synthetase". This enzyme attaches an amino acid to the tRNA. There is a different version of this for every different amino acid (so 20 of these in human bodies). The enzyme is a "synthetase" because it creates a new structure called "aminoacyl-tRNA", which is the tRNA which has an amino acid linked to it. The word "aminoacyl" means that an amino acid is linked to something, in this case tRNA. This process happens BEFORE the tRNA enters the ribosome and it takes place in the cytosol. ATP is required for that reaction.

For this, Lysosomes are sometimes called 'suicide bags'. Lysosomes are responsible for a group of genetically inherited disorders called lysosomal storage diseases (LSD). They are a type of inborn errors of metabolism caused by malfunction of one of the enzymes. The rate of incidence is estimated to be 1 in 5,000 live births, and the true figure expected to be higher as many cases are likely to be undiagnosed or misdiagnosed. The primary cause is deficiency of an acidic hydrolase (a hydrolase which functions best in acidic environments). Other conditions are due to defects in lysosomal membrane proteins that fail to transport the enzyme, non-enzymatic soluble lysosomal proteins. The initial effect of such disorders is accumulation of specific macromolecules or monomeric compounds inside the endosomal-autophagic-lysosomal system. This results in abnormal signaling pathways, calcium homeostasis, lipid biosynthesis and degradation and intracellular trafficking, ultimately leading to pathogenetic disorders. The organs most affected are brain, viscera, bone and cartilage.

text: the only way a solution can act as a buffer if it has some way of soaking up both added acid (H+) and added base (OH-). That is why a buffer needs to have significant amounts of both a weak acid AND its conjugate base. The weak acid can react with any added base to neutralize the base, and the conjugate base (which is a weak base) can react with any added acid to neutralize the acid. These reactions are how a buffer keeps the pH from changing too much when acids or bases are added. The reason why a weak acid alone is usually not a very good buffer is that by definition, weak acids don't dissociate very much in solution. So that means a weak acid solution (let's call it HA) contains mostly undissociated weak acid HA, and not much of the conjugate base, A-. So it won't be very good at soaking up added acid, and it won't make a good buffer. We can fix that by increasing the amount of A- in the solution, either by adding an external source of A- (usually by adding some salt that contains A-, perhaps NaA), or by adding some strong base like NaOH. The strong base reacts with HA to make water and A-, the conjugate base! So that's another way to increase the A- concentration, by neutralizing some of the weak acid HA (but not all of the HA, since we still need both HA and A- around to make a good buffer). text: Passive transport basically does not require any form of energy compared to active transport. In the case of osmosis,the water moves from areas of HIGH WATER concentration to areas of LOW WATER concentration, which makes it a form of passive transport. It uses no energy to move, it just drifts into lower concentrations of WATER. WATER not other materials, only WATER. Osmosis deals with water. Polysaccharides are part of the cell membrane. They function in cell adhesion (holding cells together). They also form what is called the glycocalyx, which is like the cell's fingerprint. It allows other cells to recognize the cell as a similar cell or a different, invasive cell. Carbohydrates also have some other functions when attached to proteins and lipids, but these are the two major functions.

In a way, this question is almost philosophical - how can we really tell the difference between absorbing and re-emitting an identical thing, versus if the thing just bounced off? The answer really just depends on the theory that we are using to describe what happened. In this case, quantum mechanics mathematics describing an absorption/re-emission mechanism match empirical results. And since that same theory has such wide application, we say that's what really happened. But classical physics can also describe the reflection in a way that equally matches empirical results, and classical physics says the light just bounced. If not for the fact that we know that quantum physics is more accurate across a wider range of reality than classical physics is, we could just as well say that the light bounced.

text: Mosses mostly reproduce by spores. As for gametogenesis, there are archegonia and antheridia, not ovum and spermatozoid. Bryophyte sperm is called antherozoid. When an element is bonded to another atom of itself, that contribute 0 to its oxidation state. So, in other words, you just ignore the bond an atom makes to another atom of itself. So, in hydrogen peroxide we have: H-O-O-H. The O-O bond doesn't count. So each O is bonded to one H. Since H has an oxidation state of +1, O must cancel that out, so its oxidation number is 1.

text: To make it easier to follow electron movement, we usually draw all the free electron pairs and electrons on atoms. In the case of a homolytic bond breakage, the atom is left with a single electron. Thats why we show a dot on each atom. A radical is usually very reactive and likes to bond quickly. So most of the time a radical won't stay radical for a long time. Active transport is a process that uses energy from respiration. Diffusion and osmosis don't require the cell to expend any of its own energy, as they are passive processes. Diffusion is the spreading out of particles in a *gas or solution* resulting in the *net* movement of these particles from an area of *higher* concentration to an area of *lower* concentration Osmosis is the movement of *water* particles from a *dilute* solution to a *more* concentrated solution through a *selectively permeable membrane* As we know both are passive processes and yet (in basic, short terms) diffusion is higher to lower and osmosis is lower to higher, so movement to concentration doesn't determine whether it is active or passive.

text: A small change in the DNA code, e.g. a point mutation , could result in a small or a big change, or no change at all, depending on the changes in the proteins it codes. The change can be good or bad, or both. For example, sickle cell anemia is quite a severe disease, but carrying the mutation protects against malaria. Implicit in this question is a view that light is a wave, because waves need mediums. If light were a particle, you would not need to ask this question, right? And that puzzled physicists for about 300 years, because light does things that seem particle-like (it travels without needing a medium, for example) and it does things that seem wave-like (it diffracts, refracts, polarizes). So which is it, a particle or a wave? It is neither. Light does not care that we would like to put it in one of two categories that are familiar to us. It is its own thing. It is a thing that happens to sometimes behave in ways that seem particle-like to us, and sometimes behave in ways that seem wave-like to us, but that does not mean it is one or the other or both of those things. Newton thought light was a particle, but then for a long time the prevailing view was that it was a wave, a perspective that was reinforced by Maxwell's discovery of the equations that govern electromagnetism. Embedded in his equations was the notion that electromagnetic waves travel at a speed of 3*10^8 m/s. It was known that this was also the speed of light, so physicists concluded that light is an electromagnetic wave. This wave view, though, started to get in trouble in the late 1800's as physicists struggled and failed to find the medium that this wave was traveling through. It was not until the early 1900's that physicists, largely thanks to Einstein, finally realized that we have to accept light on its own terms rather than force it into a category that is more familiar to us.

It is a thing that happens to sometimes behave in ways that seem particle-like to us, and sometimes behave in ways that seem wave-like to us, but that does not mean it is one or the other or both of those things. Newton thought light was a particle, but then for a long time the prevailing view was that it was a wave, a perspective that was reinforced by Maxwell's discovery of the equations that govern electromagnetism. Embedded in his equations was the notion that electromagnetic waves travel at a speed of 3*10^8 m/s. It was known that this was also the speed of light, so physicists concluded that light is an electromagnetic wave. This wave view, though, started to get in trouble in the late 1800's as physicists struggled and failed to find the medium that this wave was traveling through. text: The limiting factor is the wavelength of the light which make it hard to see separate points which are closer together then this distance. There are new methods (superresolution microscopy) which can deal with this, but a everyday microscope will be bound to this borders. Light can have different wavelength, that means it got different energies/colors. Red light has a long wavelength and less energy the short wave violet light or UV-light. Take honey for example, it is very viscous, but when it is heated it flows better. it's properties change. The heat from the fire or wherever it was heated from increased it's energy. When it was able to flow better, there is an increase in kinetic energy, making it less viscous than it usually is. Same goes for freezing. Since there is little, or almost no movement there is less kinetic energy and more potential. making it very viscous, and would almost not leave it's container

text: :If people increase the initial height of the projectile, it will take longer to fall to the ground, so the impact time will be larger. If the projectile is in the air longer, it will have more time to travel horizontally. The horizontal displacement will be larger. Natural selection is based upon the premise that the most fit organism for an environment (so the organism which has the best traits for a given set of circumstances) will inevitably produce the most offspring due to it being the most fit. As such it will pass on more of its genetic information to the next generation. Those organisms who are less fit for an environment, will not produce as many offspring, and their genetic information won't be as prevalent in the next generation of their species. As time progresses, the most fit organism's preferred genetic traits (the traits that made the organism fit) will become more and more prevalent in the species. That is nature selecting for the most fit organism's traits, hence the name Natural Selection.

text: First, it's important to realize that mitochondria are able to create ATP because the electron transport chain creates a H+ gradient across their membrane. At the end of the chain, ATP synthase is embedded in the membrane and it allows H+ back through creating ATP in the process. This process depends hugely on the presence of that membrane. Now for a bacterium, the only membrane available is its cell membrane. So the H+ gradient is created across the cell membrane, and the enzymes involved (electron transport chain and ATP synthase) are embedded in the same cell membrane. The entropy of a macro-system is proportional to the number of micro-states the system can be in that are compatible with the macro-state of the system. To make this notion precise, one has to specify the definition of macro-states and micro-states and how the micro-states will be counted. Sal is not providing those details here, but is speaking more qualitatively. Still, the entropy increase with either volume increase or temperature increase can be understood at this qualitative level. The micro-state of a gas is given by the location and velocity of each molecule in the gas. If the volume increases, the molecules have more locations they can be at, hence more micro-states. If the temperature increases, the molecules have more velocities with which they can move, hence more micro-states. Remember that absolute temperature is proportional to the average kinetic energy of the molecules, so increasing temperature increases the range of velocities the molecules are likely to have. This is an increase in the number of micro-states.

text: That would depend on the species that was collapsing. If it was a minor organism, as in one that affected an organism with many other options for energy, the chance of that happening is very low. However, if it was a crucial organism that played a large part in energy sharing for that ecosystem, there could be a possibility of collapse. Once an ecosystem collapses, it is very hard, if not impossible, for it to recover. There might be some ways of restoring the ecosystem, but most ideas, like bringing in invasive species, either don't work or do the opposite of what was planned. The *vapor pressure* is a property of the substance and is constant at a given temperature. It increases when temperature increases. The *boiling point* of a substance is the temperature at which the vapor pressure of the liquid equals the pressure surrounding the liquid. -If you create a vacuum over the liquid you decrease the pressure surrounding the liquid. As soon as it falls below the vapor pressure the liquid will start to boil (you do not have to increase the temperature)! -If you seal the container, the pressure over the liquid will always be the same as the vapor pressure. Thus no matter how much you heat your liquid in order to increase the vapor pressure it will never boil (provided you have a perfect seal and your container can withstand the pressure i.e. it doesn't blow up!). boiling point will increase if you seal the container.

text: The pressure exerted by cell contents on cell wall is called turgor pressure .. The pressure exerted by cell wall on cell contents is called wall pressure . Water enters the cell as long as there is a concentration gradient between surrounding medium and cell . If the surrounding solution is hypotonic , water enters the cell . When water enters the cell , cell swells up , becomes turgid and exerts turgor pressure on cell wall . cell wall also exerts wall pressure on cell contents . so in plant cells , due to the presence of cell walls , bursting of cell is prevented to some extent . while in case of animal cells , as there is no cell wall , there is no pressure on cell contents and so after a certain extent , plasma membrane bursts . Further apart orbitals are associated with higher energy levels. If an element is more electronegative than it attracts other atoms and makes electrons scroll down to the lower energy states. More electronegative element hogs electrons stronger than a less electronegative element.

text: Because in Bohr's model for hydrogen atom we consider only Coulombic interactions between one proton and one electron. It cannot be extended for other atomic species containing more than one electron. Because in this case in addition to the interaction between nucleus and electron there arises the interactions between electron and electron of the same species. Bohr couldn't solve this problem and this problems are successfully explained on the basis of later developed quantum mechanics.o But Bohr's model can be applied successfully for hydro genic species like He+, Li2+ etc. Atom have 4 electrons in the outermost shell can actually choose either or even stay neutral. One interesting thing about these types of subshells, is that they are actually somewhat stable. Because of the relative stability, these atoms often form covalent bonds rather than ionic bonds that need a charge. One example is Carbon. It has 4 valence electrons, so it can make a 4+ or a 4- charge. But because of its relatively stable half filled orbital, most of the time it takes part in covalent bonding like in organic molecules. On occasion, Carbon can ionize, most commonly 4+.

text: Most chiral molecules have chiral centers, but there are some exceptions. The best known are members of a class of compounds known as allenes, which have two double bonds in a row. So some compounds can have enantiomers without having a chiral center. Males still do get these since they have one X chromosome, having no X chromosome is lethal. text: Are all motor proteins found in living creatures? The answer is yes because motor proteins are found in living cells and function them properly. they have varied specific and important roles and they are found in all living cells doing all the things inside the cells. motor proteins are essential proteins for all organisms - they have lots of important roles such as muscle contraction, transporting cargo around the cell and cell motility Electrons are not made up of anything smaller. They are just electrons. Protons and neutrons are made up of smaller particles called quarks. Protons and neutrons are made up of different mixtures of quarks, so they have different properties. Yes, all protons, electrons and neutrons are the same. Except for mass (how much something 'weighs'), most of the physical and chemical properties of atoms are caused by the very complicated ways in which their electromagnetic fields interact at a microscopic level. Thus, when you mix different kinds of atoms together, you get complicated changes in their electromagnetic fields. Sometimes these are major changes, sometimes these are minor changes. When oxygen and hydrogen mix together to make water, they release a tremendous amount of energy, and you wind up with two atoms of hydrogen being held (we call that 'bonded') to one atom of oxygen. You have the same atoms, but the amount of energy they have now is much, much less and their electrical fields have radically changed. Thus, water is not much like hydrogen or oxygen, but has its own properties. A better analogy than mixing paint is mixing wheat, water, and oil (and a few minor ingredients). Think of all the things you can make with just these three things depending on how much of each you use and how you put them together. You can get dough, biscuits, noodles, pudding, breakfast cereal, glue, gravy, sauces, a variety of wheat beers, farina, etc. It all depends on how much of the components you use and just how you go about putting them together. Much the same thing happens at the microscopic level -- what you get depends on how much you have of a few basic 'ingredients' and how you go about putting them together.
question: Do motor proteins all serve a similar function or can they have many varied or specific roles?
context1: Are all motor proteins found in living creatures? The answer is yes because motor proteins are found in living cells and function them properly. they have varied specific and important roles and they are found in all living cells doing all the things inside the cells. motor proteins are essential proteins for all organisms - they have lots of important roles such as muscle contraction, transporting cargo around the cell and cell motility

text: A resistor has a well-behaved action (Ohm's Law) and a clear and constant value of R. A spark is a rather violent and ever-changing current path. People can think of a spark as a wire made of torn-apart air molecules. Half life is how long it takes for half of the material to decay. Take for example C-14. If we started with 10 grams of C-14, after 5730 years, we would expect to find half of that amount to remain, or 5 grams. Then, after another 5730 years (11,460 years total) half of that 5 grams would decay, leaving us with 2.5 grams, a quarter of the original 10 grams. This method works only so far back though as C-14 is rare to begin with so, as it decays, it becomes more difficult to detect and measure accurately. But for older objects where C-14 isn't reliable, we have other radiometric dating methods using other isotopes.

text: Multiple sclerosis (MS) is the most common demyelinating and an autoimmune disease of the central nervous system characterized by immune-mediated myelin and axonal damage, and chronic axonal loss attributable to the absence of myelin sheaths. with concomitant degradation of myelin, oligodendrocytes and axons, along with reactive astrogliosis and activated microglia - meaning that there is no only the problem of demzeliniyation but of hzperactive microglia. additional T-cell subsets play a prominent role in MS immunopathology: Th17 cells, CD8+ effector T cells and CD4+CD25+ regulatory T cells. There are different mechanisms for lipid antigen uptake depending upon the antigen source and its structure such that endogenous lipids are differentially distributed in subcellular compartments and internalized lipids are transported to different endocytotic vesicles. Lipids containing alkyl chains that have multiple unsaturation sites or shorter saturated tails are trafficked to early or recycling endosomes [62]; compartments surveyed by CD1c and CD1a that present these types of lipids. Demyelinated plaques and associated astrocytic activation (gliosis) are the results of local inflammation and the major pathological characteristics of the disease. In order for a virus to infect a cell, it must bring its DNA or RNA into contact with the host cell. Infection requires that the virus get through the cellular membrane. Some viruses remain outside the cell. They attach to the membrane at specific receptor sites. Once attached the virus injects its DNA or RNA into the cell. Enveloped viruses are enclosed in a membrane similar to that of the host cell. The virus and the envelope fuse and the virus enters the cell through endocytosis.

text: The lone pair electrons on the Cl are in a different shell than O (n=3 and n=2) this leads to poor interaction of the valence electrons and reduces the stability. BH3 is violently reactive on its own, so THF is used to stabilize the molecule. The BH3 essentially accepts an electron pair from the THF to complete its octet and form a stable BH3-THF complex. Think of THF as a calming agent. As far as the others are concerned: NaOH serves to remove a proton from H2O2, making it HO2, a better nucleophile (conjugate bases are always stronger nucleophiles). HO2 then attacks the boron to complete the rearrangement reaction, and the O is ultimately protonated with H2O to form a neutral alcohol. Keto-enol tautomerism kicks in here and the (C=O) bond is highly favored.
question: How is this explanation valid for not having a resonance?
context1: The lone pair electrons on the Cl are in a different shell than O (n=3 and n=2) this leads to poor interaction of the valence electrons and reduces the stability.
context2: BH3 is violently reactive on its own, so THF is used to stabilize the molecule. The BH3 essentially accepts an electron pair from the THF to complete its octet and form a stable BH3-THF complex. Think of THF as a calming agent. As far as the others are concerned: NaOH serves to remove a proton from H2O2, making it HO2, a better nucleophile (conjugate bases are always stronger nucleophiles). HO2 then attacks the boron to complete the rearrangement reaction, and the O is ultimately protonated with H2O to form a neutral alcohol. Keto-enol tautomerism kicks in here and the (C=O) bond is highly favored.

text: a mutation is a mistake in the DNA, compared to what it should be. It is rare for it to happen, but there is also a lot of DNA in your cells. In a diploid human cell, there are over 6000 million basepairs of DNA. And when that is copied for cell division, mistakes can happen. this may be only one in a billion, but with billions of bases, you get some mistakes. As well as copying into the wrong base, maybe the polymerase doing the copying will slip and skip a base or so. Another way that mutations can happen if the DNA gets damaged and isn't repaired properly. This damage could be from x-rays, UV radiation, or mutagenic chemicals. They tend to cause different types of damage, which is repaired in different ways. Sometimes DNA is damaged in a way that both strands break, and the cell will try to glue them back together. However, this is not always perfect and mistakes can be introduced. There may be bases missing, especially if the nucleotides at the DNA ends were damaged so they couldn't be stuck straight onto each other. If the mirror image of a molecule is just the molecule itself, but rotated, then that mirror image is NOT an enantiomer: it is the same molecule. the molecule is not chiral (it is achiral)

text: Entropy is not energy; entropy is how the energy in the universe is distributed. There is a constant amount of energy in the universe, but the way it is distributed is always changing. When the way the energy is distributed changes from a less probable distribution (e.g. one particle has all the energy in the universe and the rest have none!) to a more probable distribution (e.g. most particles have an amount of energy close to the average) Photons are, by nature, massless. That is why they are able to travel at the speed of light (C) and not just below it. Anything with mass cannot move at the speed of light. @kokocipher In answer to your question where does gravity ultimately come from, according to the General Theory of Relativity, the most widely accepted and most accurate theory used to explain our observations of gravity, gravity is the result of objects with mass bending space time. All objects bend spacetime, and more massive/dense objects bend it more steeply. That is they have a stronger gravitational pull. Since mass == energy (E=MC2)energy will indeed bend space time, if there is enough energy in a small enough space. However, consider the following. It requires the mass of an entire moon or planet to have an effect strong enough for you to feel. Since E=MC2 the amount of energy required to bend space the same amount (that is to have a gravitational influence that humans could detect without instruments) is unfathomable. If there's energy that dense it tends to collapse into matter. Indeed, this is what happens in our particle accelerators such as the LHC. As for black holes, they are locations in space where there is mass dense enough to bend spacetime so steeply that it would require movement faster than the speed of light to escape. Due to the nature of our Universe it is impossible to exceed the speed of light (I'm aware that sounds vague, but it would take a good hour to explain in more detail). Therefore, nothing, not even light, can escape.
question: Then how does the entropy of the universe increase over time?
context1: Entropy is not energy; entropy is how the energy in the universe is distributed. There is a constant amount of energy in the universe, but the way it is distributed is always changing. When the way the energy is distributed changes from a less probable distribution (e.g. one particle has all the energy in the universe and the rest have none!) to a more probable distribution (e.g. most particles have an amount of energy close to the average)

It requires the mass of an entire moon or planet to have an effect strong enough for you to feel. Since E=MC2 the amount of energy required to bend space the same amount (that is to have a gravitational influence that humans could detect without instruments) is unfathomable. If there's energy that dense it tends to collapse into matter. Indeed, this is what happens in our particle accelerators such as the LHC. As for black holes, they are locations in space where there is mass dense enough to bend spacetime so steeply that it would require movement faster than the speed of light to escape. text: The currently accepted definition of species says that only individuals of the same species may leave fertile offspring. While interspecies breeding is possible (liger, zebroid, etc) they cannot further reproduce and pass down 'new traits'. From the evolutionary point of view, that way of speciation is not possible (that fast, and dramatic change overnight). It _can_ affect biodiversity, but again on the shorter scale and just temporarily (following the lifetime of that individual). However, that is not likely to happen, because different species have a variety of mechanisms to stop and prevent cross-breeding or pollinating (either they reproduce at different parts of the year, or are physically incompatible, etc). Researchers may do the experiment and force starfishes in an aquarium to breed but that would not make much sense and effect on whole biodiversity Carbon will be in the middle to that 3 oxygen will be attached and to one of the oxygen a hydrogen grp will be attached .between carbon and oxygen their will be a partial double bond present(a single bond present for the one attached to hydrogen) 2.Carbon will be in the middle to that 3 oxygen will be attached and to 2 of the oxygen a hydrogen grp will be attached . there will be a double bond between one of the oxygen and carbon atom.

text: you cannot heat steam 'forever'. Like all molecules, when sufficiently hot it will decompose. There is not a set temperature at which it decomposes, it is more of a gradual process as the temperature increases. You start getting significant quantities of water decomposing at around 2500 K. At about 3000 K you get around 50% of water molecules decomposing. Of course, this is a rather hot temperature and it is rather impractical to generate, much less create a container to house the reaction. Breaking apart a double sugar into its two simple sugars is accomplished by hydrolysis with the help of a type of enzyme called a disaccharidase. Hydrolysis in water. It does not happen spontaneously. While it juts oxygen molecule, that is still an N glycosidic bond. And it cannot proceed spontaneously.

text: Oxidation originally referred to reactions with oxygen. So compounds like FeO and Fe2O3 were called ferrous and ferric oxides, while SnO and SnO2 were called stannous and stannic oxides. In 1919 Alfred Stock suggested that the names should use Roman numerals in parentheses, to make the names iron(II), iron(III), tin(II), and tin(IV) oxides. In 1940 the IUPAC recommended that the term 'Stock number' (I, II, III, IV, etc.) be replaced by the term 'oxidation number' with Arabic numerals (1, 2, 3, 4, etc.). In 1990 it adopted the current 'rule-based' system (H = +1, O = -2, etc.) for determining oxidation numbers.  the second law only applies to the universe as a whole, so some reactions can have decreasing entropy as long as the entire sum is positive. Spontaneous reactions occur when change in G (free energy, or delthaH - Tx deltaS) is less than zero across a reaction.

context1: Oxidation originally referred to reactions with oxygen. So compounds like FeO and Fe2O3 were called ferrous and ferric oxides, while SnO and SnO2 were called stannous and stannic oxides. In 1919 Alfred Stock suggested that the names should use Roman numerals in parentheses, to make the names iron(II), iron(III), tin(II), and tin(IV) oxides. In 1940 the IUPAC recommended that the term 'Stock number' (I, II, III, IV, etc.) be replaced by the term 'oxidation number' with Arabic numerals (1, 2, 3, 4, etc.). In 1990 it adopted the current 'rule-based' system (H = +1, O = -2, etc.) for determining oxidation numbers.

text: A dipole is like a temporary polarity of a non polar molecule, but only last for nano seconds (hence why it can be called a dipole moment). It can happen because e-'s positions are represented by probability functions around the nucleus; at any given time, there can be more e- around one of the bonding atoms that the other because that's just the way it worked out. London Dispersion forces apply to all molecules always, so a dipole moment is not like it. It is as if it was a polar molecule, which it was, for a few nanoseconds before it becomes its usual non polar self The same reactions occur if we add very little base and a lot of acid to if we add same amounts of acid and base, but only until the dissociation products of either the acid or the base run out. To neutralize you need to add enough acid to a base to turn all HO- into H2O (when neutralizing a base) or enough base to an acid to turn all H+ into H2O (when neutralizing an acid). Keep in mind that some acids produce more H+ per volume than others, and the same goes with HO- for bases. So, you may want to check that before you start mixing, as a little of a powerful base can neutralize a lot of weak acid. the process will change, though this depends on the acid and the base just as much as the ratio in which you mix them. If there is an imbalance in the H+ and OH-, the neutralization will fail.

text: Semipermeable and selectively permeable can be slightly different in meaning, though this usage is not consistent. Semipermeable is typically used as an overall term for membranes that only allow some molecules to pass through - in some cases this is used exclusively for selection based on molecule (or ion) size. Selectively permeable just means that some molecules can pass through the membrane based on their properties, but most molecules or ions can not pass through the membrane. Different semipermeable membranes may let different size molecules pass through - an example of this is dialysis membranes (or tubing), which can be made with pore sizes that will allow small macromolecules (e.g. proteins) to pass through while restricting larger macromolecules. Since ultrabithorax is inactivated, no halteres are present. Fly apart from being unable to fly also cannot balance off. That mutation is lethal.

Slowly the mother bird will stand farther and farther away from the nest, forcing the baby bird to come out of the nest to get food. The bird realizes it needs this food to survive and this is the motivation for them to venture out onto a branch. Certain Plants do grow better around each other and help each other out. Researcher Dr. David Johnson looked closely at plants' symbiotic relationship with soil fungus, piggybacking off a 2010 study that seemed to suggest that a tomato plant infected with leaf blight would be able to warn nearby plants of the problem. In turn, those plants would activate genes that would prevent them from catching the disease, too. Johnson was able to show how plants use fungus in the soil as a network (think of it as a botanical Wi-Fi, if you will). Essentially, fungi deliver messages of danger from plant to plant, and as a result, the group can grow stronger. Even plants get by with a little help from their friends. *Animals* help plants by pollinating them, and be helping to disperse seeds. The droppings of animals also fertilize plants. Plants have three basic responses or reactions to light. They are photosynthesis, phototropism and photoperiodism. As plants react/respond to light the amount of heat wont matter anyway.

text: There are some enzymes, which work in many pathways. They have relatively poor substrate specificity and this is important, because it's function requires it to do transform so many chemically different substrates into metabolites. Eg: The cytochrome p450 in liver, alcohol dehydrogenase. The former is a very important enzyme system, which plays a role in metabolising (a fancy term for acting upon) a wide variety of foreign substances, which include drugs and toxins. These reactions are the main mechanism of our body to fight drugs, and competitive inhibition is important here when we want to design drug therapies, because if we give two drugs both of which are acted upon by this enzyme, then they shall compete for its binding, and a result both will be metabolised slowly (in relation to if each was given independently). Alcohol dehydrogenase metabolises alcohols, and hence is the reason why methanol is poisonous. IT converts it into the more poisonous methanoic acid. For a patient of methanol poisoning, the main therapy includes giving ethanol, so that it acts as a competitive inhibitor, preventing methanol from forming the harmful metabolite. The more substrate-specific enzymes, do not usually have complications pertaining to competitive inhibitors. Don't confuse formal charge and oxidation numbers, the previous video goes over the differences between these. With oxidation numbers, the more electronegative atom in each bond gets the 2 electrons, but with formal charge both atoms get 1 electron each regardless of electronegativity So for methane, carbon has an oxidation number of -4 but a formal charge of 0
question: Would be there to compete with the substrate or only limited amount of reactions suffer through this phenomenon?

These reactions are the main mechanism of our body to fight drugs, and competitive inhibition is important here when we want to design drug therapies, because if we give two drugs both of which are acted upon by this enzyme, then they shall compete for its binding, and a result both will be metabolised slowly (in relation to if each was given independently). Alcohol dehydrogenase metabolises alcohols, and hence is the reason why methanol is poisonous. IT converts it into the more poisonous methanoic acid. For a patient of methanol poisoning, the main therapy includes giving ethanol, so that it acts as a competitive inhibitor, preventing methanol from forming the harmful metabolite. The more substrate-specific enzymes, do not usually have complications pertaining to competitive inhibitors.

text: there is no another pump, actually depends on what cell we are speaking of, but there are voltage-gated ion channels which open and let Na ions inside and that's how Na circulates. There are no ionic bonds in these. There is a charge due to having 1 more electron than it has protons, but every bond in these molecules is covalent. The reason the charge is that if you draw the structures you will end up with one oxygen only having 7 electrons and not following the octet rule, unless you add an extra electron to the molecule. Hence why the chlorine polyatomic ions have a -1 charge. You could also think of them all being protonated as acids: HClO, HClO2, HClO3 and HClO4. Once they lose the H+ a -1 charge is left.

text: What position humans really hold in the food chain is a topic that has recently come under debate. we don't really have natural predators, and we can easily hunt and eat even the largest of animals. However, studies concerning the trophic level of humans have shown that humans are similar to pigs and anchovies when it comes to overall diet, and are nowhere near the meat-only diets of the apex predators (this rank may change in the near future, as veganism and vegetarianism are gaining popularity). As for trophic levels, because of the fact that humans are omnivorous, they do not fall under a set, 'clear' trophic level. They can fall under level 2 (a human eats seaweed), level 3 (a human eats a lobster), or level 4 (a human eats an octopus). This can also happen if a human eats an omnivorous animal, who also does not have a set trophic level (a human eats bear meat). The reactants have more energy, but this energy is not free energy. It is in the form of potential energy stored in the bonds. This energy is released into the environment in an exergonic reaction, bond breaking subsequently occurs. The products therefore have less energy because less bonds the equivalent of less energy.

text: What happens to a rigid object depends on the atomic and molecular forces. If the forces between the atoms and molecules shift without breaking then the object undergoes plastic deformation and stays in the new shape. If the forces do not stretch or shift then the object cracks. Most objects that we conciser rigid will react to a force on them with a combination of all three responses It is just the fact that Earth temperature (the timestamp when life began and persists) is not as high as 100 ^C. text: The formula gmh applies for small distances. For ridiculously large distances, the further away an object gets, the smaller the gravitational potential energy it has. The further away the object gets, the less influence it will feel gravitationally. Light is refracted at a very specific angle. I won't go into the mechanics here, but in a raindrop, light in fact undergoes so much refraction it bounces back in the direction the original ray came from, which is why rainbows always appear on the opposite side of the sky as the sun. This means that if you stand with the sun directly behind you, the rays of light form a triangle between you, the observer, the raindrop the light is refracted from and a point on the ground directly ahead of you. Since raindrops will be scattered all across the sky, and you can only observe light refracted at the specific angle, the line along which the light rays travels describes an arc across the sky, and this arc is the rainbow you see. Incidentally, the angle of refraction is also the reason why you can never catch up with a rainbow. The angle, and hence the bow's apparent distance must remain constant with respect to your position.

text: If there is a group that changes the suffix (eg how -OH changes the suffix from -ane to -anol) then that will automatically be on carbon 1 so you need to number around that. If there isn't one of those groups, and there are only two groups on the ring then the alphabetically first group will be on carbon 1. If there are three or more groups then you have to number the ring in such a way that uses the lowest numbers. Only if there is a tie between two numberings would you go for the alphabetically first group. there are exceptions to many rules in chemistry. Furthermore while we often say something is covalent or ionic, the truth is that bonding in molecules is on more of a spectrum than being absolutely one or the other.

text: he O does act as a nucleophile in competition with N, but it's a dead-end process. Reaction with O gives the reversible formation of a hemiketal. Reaction with N forms the oxime in an essentially irreversible process as the adduct dehydrates. As the ketone gets used up, the hemiketal decomposes in an attempt to maintain the concentration of the ketone (Le Chtelier's Principle) For these it's probably best to go back to first principles and work it out. Draw the structure, then break every bond. Assign both electrons in each bond to the more electronegative atom of that bond. If the atoms are the same (eg a C-C bond) then assign 1 electron to each. Then subtract how many electrons have been given to each atom from the valence electrons their neutral atom would have, that's the oxidation state.

text: Reduction = gain in electrons. K would find it harder to gain electrons than Li because there are more electron shells around K. This means that atomic radius has increased, so the e- are held with less attraction to the nucleus. Increased sheilding also contributes. This is why K is so reactive - it's electrons are held so losely they easily break away. In reduction you want to opposite to happen, a gain in electrons, so a strong force of attraction on your valency electrons is needed. Li has the smallest radius (and all of group one has the same nuclear charge) so Li has the strongest force of attraction and thus most easily atracts more electrons. There are often multiple ribosomes at the same tRNA at the same time! But after a while it will be disassembled by restriction enzymes and out of the nucleotides a new tRNA will be made. There will probably come the next ribosome.

text: Snow forms when water vapor in the air turns directly into ice because it's so cold. The ice crystals grow from additional water vapor until they fall down as snow. Hail, on the other hand, is created when existing liquid rain is carried into colder areas by updrafts and freezes into a ball of ice. Because the water in many clouds is supercooled (brought past the freezing point but still in liquid form), it is easily frozen and the hail gradually grows. This continues until the hailstone becomes too heavy to stay in the clouds and falls.  Genes are found on strands of DNA, they are not themselves a strand of DNA. A gene is a sequence of base pairs that code for a specific protein, not a specific phenotypic trait as such. The various proteins interact in very complex ways to form traits. So, genes do not, strictly speaking, code for phenotypic traits. However, a specific trait might be reliant on the protein produced by one gene for some key aspect of its nature. So, while we might often say the gene for this or that trait, what is more accurate is saying the gene for the protein is involved in this or that trait. Genes, in fact, tend to be involved in multiple phenotypic traits because the protein they code for can be used in a variety of ways. Alleles are variations of genes, but they may or may not produce observable differences in some phenotypic trait. The reason is that proteins tend to be very large molecules and so a few minor changes here or there in their structure may or may not have much of an effect on their functions. So, some alleles produce proteins that produce pretty much identical phenotypic traits. Also, remember that some amino acids can be coded for by more than one codon, so some alleles merely contain different ways of coding for the same protein. But, obviously, some alleles, even with minor changes, can produce proteins that lead to significantly different traits. Eye color is not a good example because there are many genes involved in that (perhaps as many as 16 genes)
question: What is the difference in the formation of snow and hailstones?
context1: Snow forms when water vapor in the air turns directly into ice because it's so cold. The ice crystals grow from additional water vapor until they fall down as snow. Hail, on the other hand, is created when existing liquid rain is carried into colder areas by updrafts and freezes into a ball of ice. Because the water in many clouds is supercooled (brought past the freezing point but still in liquid form), it is easily frozen and the hail gradually grows. This continues until the hailstone becomes too heavy to stay in the clouds and falls.

The various proteins interact in very complex ways to form traits. So, genes do not, strictly speaking, code for phenotypic traits. However, a specific trait might be reliant on the protein produced by one gene for some key aspect of its nature. So, while we might often say the gene for this or that trait, what is more accurate is saying the gene for the protein is involved in this or that trait. Genes, in fact, tend to be involved in multiple phenotypic traits because the protein they code for can be used in a variety of ways. Alleles are variations of genes, but they may or may not produce observable differences in some phenotypic trait. The reason is that proteins tend to be very large molecules and so a few minor changes here or there in their structure may or may not have much of an effect on their functions. So, some alleles produce proteins that produce pretty much identical phenotypic traits. Also, remember that some amino acids can be coded for by more than one codon, so some alleles merely contain different ways of coding for the same protein. But, obviously, some alleles, even with minor changes, can produce proteins that lead to significantly different traits. Eye color is not a good example because there are many genes involved in that (perhaps as many as 16 genes)

text: When seeing 'weight' used like this is chemistry, it is not using the meaning of the word that has to do with force due to gravity. Instead, it is using the mathematical sense of the word for WEIGHTed average. To put it another way: the word weight is there to remind you that this is a weighted average. It has nothing to do with the force of gravity on your reactants. In fact, it would make sense to add "Weight" (or even better "Weighted" for weighted average) to the units for everything based off the atomic weight(ed average). So you would have units like "atomic mass (weighted)", "grams (weighted)", "amu (weighted)". While these units may sound funny to say, they make sense -- anything measured in them assume you have the same distribution of isotopes as is on earth. If you don't have that normal distribution of isotopes, than anything measured in those weighted units would be off, because the weighting assumes a normal distrubution of isotopes. the Ruminococcus is in the cow's food, or is somehow enhaled by the cow. I think that's how it works.

text: The empirical formula has the smallest whole number subscripts between atoms Molecular formula is the actual formula of the molecule The most likely molecular formula of something with an empirical formula of CH3 is ethane, C2H6.  paleontologists look first to see whether the fossil in questions has any teeth. this is a big help in determining the foods a dinosaur ate. In general, a meat-eating dinosaur will have long, serrated teeth like steak knives, or small but sharper teeth. Basically, the canines and other teeth used for cutting are more prominent. In omnivores, the canines and back teeth (molars) will both show wear, as both are being used. Plant-eaters would have less canines and more molars; several hadrosaurs had hundreds of molars in the backs of their mouths, to better grind of the tons of plant matter they ate every day (I think most of a brachiosaur's life was spent eating). If there are no teeth available, I believe paleontologists look for other signs, like rocks in the stomach, usually found in plant-eaters (these stones help to grind up plant material) , or other things in the stomach, like that dinosaur's last meal. Claws, teeth, girth size, and other such characteristics can help determine whether a dinosaur was a carnivore/herbivore.

text: Noble gases are elements that are at the last period of the periodic table. They are normally found as a gas at STP (273.15K or 0degree Celsius and 1 atm), which explains the gas part. Of course, noble gases can become solids and liquids at low temperatures. But not during normal conditions. For example, Mercury is the only liquid metal in the periodic table at normal conditions, however, other metals can melt and become liquids at higher temperatures. The noble part comes because the noble gases have full outer electron shells of eight electrons each. So they are satisfied with their electron configuration and do not want to share electrons with other elements including other noble gases. Which means that they are extremely nonreactive, hence the noble part of their name. So in short, noble gases are called so as they are extremely nonreactive and are gases at normal temperatures. Krypton is a noble gas, so it's outer most electron shell is full, and therefore it also has a valency of zero. Its outer most shell has 8 electrons and fulfils the octet rule.
question: Is it because they are naturally found as gases (if that's actually true), or is there some other reason?

text: There is two type force inside atom. Repulsive force between protons and attractive force between electron and nucleus. If atom is stable than atom should overcome the repulsive force in other way talk about this more attractive force than repulsive force. Semipermeable and selectively permeable can be slightly different in meaning, though this usage is not consistent. Semipermeable is typically used as an overall term for membranes that only allow some molecules to pass through - in some cases this is used exclusively for selection based on molecule (or ion) size. Selectively permeable just means that some molecules can pass through the membrane based on their properties, but most molecules or ions can not pass through the membrane. Different semipermeable membranes may let different size molecules pass through - an example of this is dialysis membranes (or tubing), which can be made with pore sizes that will allow small macromolecules (e.g. proteins) to pass through while restricting larger macromolecules.

text: chemical and electrical synapses? Yes, very fast, the matter of milliseconds. Especially in teh case of electrical synapses. As for chemical synapses, what accelerates and propagates amplified action potential are Ranvier's nodes on neurons - by creating saltatory propagation. the nucleotide sequences will be different. However, since we're normally considering genes within the same species it's normally quite easy to determine that two genes are 'the same' (by which we mean the genes were the same in a common ancestor, but one or both have mutated since then). Often the gene will be thousands of nucleotides long, so a few base pair differences means they are still 99% identical. It could be that one gene has a large deletion or insertion, but it's still possible to find identical regions. There are various alignment tools that give you a measure of how similar two sequences are. It's possible that two alleles could have completely different sequences, but you can still see that they are the 'same' gene based on the function of the protein they encode or by their position on the genome. But remember that allele is just a human invention to make it easy to compare different genomes. It just refers to the different sequences that an organism can inherit. It could be that one allele is a single copy of a gene whereas another allele is having three copies of the gene, or no copies of that gene. As with a lot of biology there are no hard and fast rules and definitions get blurry at the edges.

text: Evolution is the change in which traits appear how often in a population, which can eventually cause one species to give rise to another. Natural selection is the major,mechanism by which evolution takes place. Given the environmental conditions and the competition for resources and mates that occur in a population, there is a filtering process called natural selection that takes place. The difference between 'log' and 'ln' is: If you just have 'log' (without a base underneath) it means it is base 10, it is implied. On the other hand if you have 'ln', it is implied that you have a base of 'e' (Euler's constant). Logarithms are largely used in a lot of different fields of study, and their base depends on the phenomenon that you are referring to (basically, you use the one that helps you the best to explain that certain phenomenon), that's why sometimes you might even find bases even different than e or 10, although these are the ones that are used the most.

text: there is one enzyme which is crucial for translation and that is "aminoacyl tRNA synthetase". This enzyme attaches an amino acid to the tRNA. There is a different version of this for every different amino acid (so 20 of these in human bodies). The enzyme is a "synthetase" because it creates a new structure called "aminoacyl-tRNA", which is the tRNA which has an amino acid linked to it. The word "aminoacyl" means that an amino acid is linked to something, in this case tRNA. This process happens BEFORE the tRNA enters the ribosome and it takes place in the cytosol. ATP is required for that reaction. sulfur does not follow the octet rule. In Sulfur dichloride , the octet rule is obeyed. only elements in the second period follow the octet rule, and there are exceptions. C, N, O, and F always follow the octet rule, while B, Mg, and Na can deviate. boron can have 6 sometimes.

text: strong acid and bases giving 100% ionization in water has to do with equilibrium and reversible reactions. When an acid or base dissociates (or ionizes) in water, there's always the possibility of the reverse reaction, were the ions react to reform the not-dissociated acid or base. The amount an acid or base dissociates in water has to do with how much more one of these reactions is favored the forward reaction (the dissociation into ions), or the backward reaction (the ions reacting to form the original acid or base). Strong acids and bases almost overwhelmingly favor the forward reaction, because the resulting ions are relatively unreactive in aqueous solution. If there is no gravity then it will do exactly what the sugar particles did in the video (this is because in the video there was no gravity). But if there is gravity then... The containers are like scales: it always has to equal up (number of sand and water molecules added together) but because there is gravity, the sand would float down to the bottom of the containers, and because there gazillions of these sand molecules there is an extremely small change that both tanks will have the same amount of sand resting at the bottom of it. That means that the scales have got their first weights (the sand molecules). Now the water molecules flow around until the side with less sand molecules (the lighter side) has enough water molecules added to its weight that it eventually evens out with the side with more sand molecules (the heavier side).

text: Straight-chain alkanes are able to pack and layer each other better than their branched counterparts. This allows greater intermolecular forces, which raises the melting point since it will take more energy to disperse the molecules into a liquid. Similarly, even-numbered alkanes stack better than odd-numbered alkanes, and will therefore have higher melting points. When both the carbon atoms have R,R or S,S configuration they will be chiral. But when they are R,S or S,R they would be achiral since one part of molecule is the mirror image of other

text: entire chromosomes are very long (100s of millions of base pairs in humans) and can't be meaningfully compared using gel electrophoresis. The speed of DNA migration during gel electrophoresis mostly depends on the length of the DNA, not the sequence. This means a given piece of DNA from different species (or individuals) might or might not differ in their migration even though they have different sequences. Furthermore, two different alleles within a single organism often result in different lengths of DNA. To do identification of species often requires much more precision that you get with gel electrophoresis (and even more precision is needed to separate individuals within a species). Most chiral molecules have chiral centers, but there are some exceptions. The best known are members of a class of compounds known as allenes, which have two double bonds in a row. So some compounds can have enantiomers without having a chiral center.

text: Equilibrium must occur in a closed system (with a reversible reaction), you cannot have equilibrium in an open system, as small particles, especially gasses, can easily escape. It is just a calculation done on some other values. It is relative to hydrogen which was assigned a value of 2.20 on the Pauling scale. There are other electronegativity scales than Pauling, which use different means. But Pauling it the most commonly used value and is what most people mean by electronegativity unless they specify one of the other scales.

text: The reason sodium and chlorine are so volatile is because they are extremely unstable. Chlorine's last shell has one too few electrons, and is therefore searching anywhere it can for that last electron. Sodium, on the other hand, has only one electron in its last shell, ergo it searches everywhere for something to give up that extra electron to. When sodium meets chlorine, the sodium gives its extra electron to chlorine (which has the one missing electron), which effectively creates a stable compound, NaCl, or halite (common table salt) that single electron has greater chance of forming a bond (pi bond) if the orbital he is in isn't hybridized. paired electrons don't have to bond so their orbital gets hybridized (it lowers the total energy of the molecule)

A subspecies is a group of organisms that are in the species but are different in some way (like a bengal tiger vs a siberian tiger). text: the species may die off if it doesnt find food fast enough. In that case, carnivores cannot become frugivores or something else. The digestive system is already developed and specialized for a certain type of food. Symporters and antiporters use the energy stored in the electrochemical gradient. Depending on which membrane is being discussed, the electrochemical gradient may created by either metabolic processes (e.g. the electron transport chain in mitochondria) and/or by using ATP to pump ions "uphill" (against their electrochemical gradient). Secondary active transport means that, rather than directly using ATP to power the movement of compounds across the membrane, proteins like symporters and antiporters use the energy stored in the electrochemical gradient. The electrochemical gradient is the combined "push" due to concentration and charge differences across the membrane.
