text: In eukaryotes, free ribosome's actually assemble around the mRNA then will begin reading the code. Fairly early on a certain sequence in the RNA may be recognised which causes the whole translation process to halt while the mRNA-ribosome complex is all transferred to the endoplasmic reticulum, translation will then begin again with the growing polypeptide chain entering the ER lumen. The process is known as cotranslational localisation. Generally speaking, proteins that are destined for lysosomes, membranes or to be secreted from the cell are made on the RER. Once the mRNA molecule is exported from the nucleus and is recognized by a ribosome, it will be translated initially in the cytosol. However, if the protein needs to be targeted to the ER, the first 5 to 30 amino acids will encode what's called 'Signal Peptide', which is a structure recognized by a protein called 'Signal Recognition Particle' (SRP). SRP binds signal peptide and pauses translation. SRP then facilitates docking of the ribosome to the Rough ER, after which signal peptide is cleaved off of the protein and translation continues into the lumen of the Rough ER. A gay person does not have more chromosomes than the person who prefers partners of the opposite gender. It's more of a hormonal/environmentally-influenced trait. If you do get an extra chromosome, it's called trisomy, and depending on the extra chromosome or extra sex chromosome you get, you could have Down syndrome (trisomy 21), Klinefelter's Syndrome (XXY syndrome), etc.

text: Meta attack occurs is because the first nitro group is electron withdrawing (deactivating) so probably the reaction will occur but much slower. The entropy of a macro-system is proportional to the number of micro-states the system can be in that are compatible with the macro-state of the system. To make this notion precise, one has to specify the definition of macro-states and micro-states and how the micro-states will be counted. Sal is not providing those details here, but is speaking more qualitatively. Still, the entropy increase with either volume increase or temperature increase can be understood at this qualitative level. The micro-state of a gas is given by the location and velocity of each molecule in the gas. If the volume increases, the molecules have more locations they can be at, hence more micro-states. If the temperature increases, the molecules have more velocities with which they can move, hence more micro-states. Remember that absolute temperature is proportional to the average kinetic energy of the molecules, so increasing temperature increases the range of velocities the molecules are likely to have. This is an increase in the number of micro-states.

text: Polysaccharides are part of the cell membrane. They function in cell adhesion (holding cells together). They also form what is called the glycocalyx, which is like the cell's fingerprint. It allows other cells to recognize the cell as a similar cell or a different, invasive cell. Carbohydrates also have some other functions when attached to proteins and lipids, but these are the two major functions. Hydrogen bonds do not take very much energy to break. The hydrogen bond is a weak attraction between molecules, or parts of larger molecules to each other caused by regional polarization resulting from hydrogen's very small diameter and relatively low electronegativity.

text: We are explicitly calculating *bond* enthalpy - to me this suggests that we are focusing on the potential energy. However, when we calculate an enthalpy of a reaction, we are often$ talking about how much 'heat' has been released (or absorbed) and this must be due to changes in the motion of the individual molecules. So, I think we could view these calculations as describing the interconversion between potential and kinetic energies of the molecules. $note: Clearly there are many exceptions such as: Chemiluminescence, where the energy is given off as light; and ATP powering molecular motors such as kinesins. However, in these cases we just replacing heat with other forms of light and (non-heat) kinetic energy, respectively (or more likely a mix of heat and these other forms of energy). If you look at the periodic table, you can see Cadmium (Cd) belongs to the 12th group. The periodic table is organized so that the 2 in '12' is equivalent to the amount of electrons the element has in its valence shell. That means Cadmium has 2 electrons in its valence shell. An atom of Cadmium has an oxidation of 2+ because it tends to lose those 2 electrons in its valence shell in order to stabilize, therefore having a positive charge of 2

text: It is indeed POSSIBLE for matter to return to an ordered state WITHOUT the input of energy, but the probability of such an occurrence is extremely low, just as billiard balls happening to collect back at the center of the pool table is extremely low. Being in an ordered state would likely have HIGHER energy, especially potential energy. If you look at the example of the molecules all crammed into one side of the box rather than being diffused throughout, the probability that they would bounce into each other is much greater, and therefore they exhibit a greater potential for increasing the kinetic energy of each molecule. Usually it TAKES energy to create an ordered state, such as the energy needed by organisms to create ordered systems of life. A water molecule would be produced, but the monomers were dehydrated. This is why it is called dehydration. When we add water, it is called hydration, because we 'hydrate' the monomers and they break apart.

text: The experiment needs the Pd catalyst. Without it, the required heat and pressure would probably be so high that either you would need special (and expensive!) equipment or your reactant or product might decompose. For example, the product alcohol would probably dehydrate at the high temperatures required. The reaction with water is explosive. However, in the LAH reduction of a carboxylic acid, a solution of the acid in an ether solvent is slowly added to a solution or stirred suspension of LAH in the same solvent. The solutions can be cooled and the rate of addition controlled to keep the reaction slow enough that the hydrogen does not explode.

text: the first stage would be the 'activation of amino acids'. Basically this step is before the initiation stage. During this activation of amino acids a specific amino acid and an ATP will bind to an enzyme called "aminoacyl-tRNA synthesas". The specific amino acid will bind the aminoacyl-tRNA synthesas where it will be activated by covalently binding with the ATP turning it into AMP during the process (releasing pyrophosphate). Then a tRNA will bind the aminoacyl-tRNA synthesas and it will covalently bind with the activated amino acid (releasing AMP). When the amino acid and the tRNA bind they will be released from the aminoacyl-tRNA synthesas and can then bind with the corresponding mRNA codon. So, when the tRNA leaves the E site is basically starts over the above process. In Uniform Circular Motion, Magnitude of velocity doesn't vary with time, but direction does. It is only possible when Force applied is perpendicular to the displacement vector (or velocity vector). A centripetal force is required to move a particle in such circular motion, which will be provided by magnetic force in this case.

text: the force exerted when the object lands depends on the object's mass as well as its velocity. All objects will have the same velocity when they hit the ground. More massive one's will exert greater force on the ground. The force also will depend on how hard the ground is. More force will be exerted when the ground is very hard and the velocity of the object drops more quickly to 0. If the ground is softer, the velocity change is slower, and the force is lower. text: The electrons kicked back to the oxygen because when you protonated the molecule, the oxygen picked up a hydrogen, giving it a +1 charge. While silicon is okay with five bonds, oxygen is very electronegative, so it wants its electrons back. That's also why it wouldn't be the tertbutyl bond that leaves, because the bonds to silicon aren't the issue, the bonds to oxygen are. With the F added to the Si, the Si has a negative charge. It can return to neutral by kicking off bonding electrons. It happens to be the Si-O bond because oxygen is more electronegative than t-butyl.  While the steps vary depending on the problem, the general strategy is to think about what compounds you start with and what you end with overall. All of the other compounds are intermediate states and will be used to cancel one way or another. As to which reactions to reverse, it is fair play to reverse any of the reactions--just to swap the sign for the enthalpy when you do so

text: The states of matter depend on two things, pressure, and temperature. If the temperate increases than the general energy increases and the molecules break away from each other thus causing the element to change to a higher state of matter, such as from liquid to gas. But the same is true with pressure except in a different way. If the pressure exerted on water is increased the molecules are squished together and it changes to a solid, but if the pressure is decreased the molecules are "pulled apart" and the state changes to a gas without the temperature having to change at all. It takes a lot of time to destroy it (for the whole system to collapse), because the systems constantly try to adapt themselves, but we already killed so many micro and miso-ecosystems, than the macro ones are wounded and very ill now (our body is an ecosystem too) Balances are always fragile, because they are balances, too much weigh and the whole is ruined. A chance they are 'clever' balance and have adaptation faculties, but if you upset the balance faster than it repairs itself, the collapse is inevitable.

text: There are often multiple ribosomes at the same tRNA at the same time! But after a while it will be disassembled by restriction enzymes and out of the nucleotides a new tRNA will be made. There will probably come the next ribosome. Photons are, by nature, massless. That is why they are able to travel at the speed of light (C) and not just below it. Anything with mass cannot move at the speed of light. @kokocipher In answer to your question where does gravity ultimately come from, according to the General Theory of Relativity, the most widely accepted and most accurate theory used to explain our observations of gravity, gravity is the result of objects with mass bending space time. All objects bend spacetime, and more massive/dense objects bend it more steeply. That is they have a stronger gravitational pull. Since mass == energy (E=MC2)energy will indeed bend space time, if there is enough energy in a small enough space. However, consider the following. It requires the mass of an entire moon or planet to have an effect strong enough for you to feel. Since E=MC2 the amount of energy required to bend space the same amount (that is to have a gravitational influence that humans could detect without instruments) is unfathomable. If there's energy that dense it tends to collapse into matter. Indeed, this is what happens in our particle accelerators such as the LHC. As for black holes, they are locations in space where there is mass dense enough to bend spacetime so steeply that it would require movement faster than the speed of light to escape. Due to the nature of our Universe it is impossible to exceed the speed of light (I'm aware that sounds vague, but it would take a good hour to explain in more detail). Therefore, nothing, not even light, can escape.

Due to the nature of our Universe it is impossible to exceed the speed of light (I'm aware that sounds vague, but it would take a good hour to explain in more detail). Therefore, nothing, not even light, can escape.
question2: Do masses naturally have gravitational forces associated with them?

text: For example water has polar bonds and oil is made of nonpolar bonds. Like dissolves like and opposites oppose so they do not dissolve in eachother. This can be useful since solvents can be used to dissolve certain compounds and not others making it possible to extract them or just put in a solvent and have it boil off leaving a dry material behind (eg paint). Certain Plants do grow better around each other and help each other out. Researcher Dr. David Johnson looked closely at plants' symbiotic relationship with soil fungus, piggybacking off a 2010 study that seemed to suggest that a tomato plant infected with leaf blight would be able to warn nearby plants of the problem. In turn, those plants would activate genes that would prevent them from catching the disease, too. Johnson was able to show how plants use fungus in the soil as a network (think of it as a botanical Wi-Fi, if you will). Essentially, fungi deliver messages of danger from plant to plant, and as a result, the group can grow stronger. Even plants get by with a little help from their friends. *Animals* help plants by pollinating them, and be helping to disperse seeds. The droppings of animals also fertilize plants. Plants have three basic responses or reactions to light. They are photosynthesis, phototropism and photoperiodism. As plants react/respond to light the amount of heat wont matter anyway.

Noble gases are elements that are at the last period of the periodic table. They are normally found as a gas at STP (273.15K or 0degree Celsius and 1 atm), which explains the gas part. Of course, noble gases can become solids and liquids at low temperatures. But not during normal conditions. For example, Mercury is the only liquid metal in the periodic table at normal conditions, however, other metals can melt and become liquids at higher temperatures. The noble part comes because the noble gases have full outer electron shells of eight electrons each. So they are satisfied with their electron configuration and do not want to share electrons with other elements including other noble gases. Which means that they are extremely nonreactive, hence the noble part of their name. So in short, noble gases are called so as they are extremely nonreactive and are gases at normal temperatures.

text: Once one molecule gets a slightly positive side and a slightly negative side, it will induce polarisation in it's neighbours. So the positive end will attract the electron density from the neighbouring molecule, which in turn then gets a negative end and a positive end, etc. Repulsive forces don't induce each other, so you just get attraction. Reduction = gain in electrons. K would find it harder to gain electrons than Li because there are more electron shells around K. This means that atomic radius has increased, so the e- are held with less attraction to the nucleus. Increased sheilding also contributes. This is why K is so reactive - it's electrons are held so losely they easily break away. In reduction you want to opposite to happen, a gain in electrons, so a strong force of attraction on your valency electrons is needed. Li has the smallest radius (and all of group one has the same nuclear charge) so Li has the strongest force of attraction and thus most easily atracts more electrons.
question: Why aren't repulsive forces just as likely as attractive ones?
context1: Once one molecule gets a slightly positive side and a slightly negative side, it will induce polarisation in it's neighbours. So the positive end will attract the electron density from the neighbouring molecule, which in turn then gets a negative end and a positive end, etc. Repulsive forces don't induce each other, so you just get attraction.
context2: Reduction = gain in electrons. K would find it harder to gain electrons than Li because there are more electron shells around K. This means that atomic radius has increased, so the e- are held with less attraction to the nucleus. Increased sheilding also contributes. This is why K is so reactive - it's electrons are held so losely they easily break away. In reduction you want to opposite to happen, a gain in electrons, so a strong force of attraction on your valency electrons is needed. Li has the smallest radius (and all of group one has the same nuclear charge) so Li has the strongest force of attraction and thus most easily atracts more electrons.

text: Decay is primarily due to the actions of prokaryotes and fungi. oxidation and high-energy particles (e.g cosmic rays) will gradually break down molecules in a corpse (or anything else), but this is a *very* slow process. Even without removing microbes an embalmed corpse in a sealed coffin can remain intact for centuries - Individual cells can (and do) self-destruct - this is known as apoptosis, but this doesn't seem to have a significant effect on whole organisms; it ceases soon after the organism dies since it requires energy. There are systematic ways to go about balancing chemical equations. The reason for balancing chemical equations is to know how much of each reactant we must add and to be able to predict how much product we will get. For example, say you work for a pharmaceutical company and are in charge of synthesizing ibuprofen (trade name: Advil). the balanced chemical reaction could be uesd to determine what ratio to add your reactants together in. For example, if the balanced equation was A + 2B ---> ibuprofen, then you'd need to add 1 mole of A for each 2 moles of B to make ibuprofen. If you added A and B (your reactants) together in a different ratio, some of these chemicals would be wasted. You could also use the balanced chemical equation to know exactly how much of A and B you need to add to make a particular mass of ibuprofen. For example, if you need to make 10 grams of ibuprofen, then the balanced chemical equation can help you calculate exactly how many grams of each reactant you must mix together.

text: there is a time limit on how long Carbon 14 can exist. However, new supplies of it are created in the upper atmosphere when nitrogen gas absorbs high-energy neutrons which are released due to the atmosphere interacting in complex ways with cosmic rays. Eventually algae and plants photosynthesize the newly created C-14 and introduce it to the food chain. Thus, while carbon 14 is constantly decaying, it is also constantly being created. Neurons are the most unique cells in our body. Some are extremely small, while others are very large. In general, neurons do not repair well. If several neurons were damaged, such as in a spinal cord injury, you already know the individual would be paralyzed and it is unlikely the individual would ever walk again. If a portion of a neuron is damaged, it may or may not be able to find and re-connect with itself. If the axon is damaged, the myelin cells such as Schwann cells form a tunnel to help direct the axon to the other portion. Never-the-less, even after several years, if you touch an area of your body that has a scar, you will realize that touch or feeling over that scar has changed and it is not as sensitive as it once was because the receptors and axons were damaged when the skin was damaged. Now, even though the skin is well healed, the nervous tissue has not healed and therefore the sense of touch is poor over that scar. Epithelial tissue and connective tissue heal well, but nervous tissue does not have the ability to divide and replace neurons that have been damaged so it does not heal well.
question: Why is there C-14 at the first place? and why does it still exist?
context1: there is a time limit on how long Carbon 14 can exist. However, new supplies of it are created in the upper atmosphere when nitrogen gas absorbs high-energy neutrons which are released due to the atmosphere interacting in complex ways with cosmic rays. Eventually algae and plants photosynthesize the newly created C-14 and introduce it to the food chain. Thus, while carbon 14 is constantly decaying, it is also constantly being created.
context2: Neurons are the most unique cells in our body. Some are extremely small, while others are very large. In general, neurons do not repair well. If several neurons were damaged, such as in a spinal cord injury, you already know the individual would be paralyzed and it is unlikely the individual would ever walk again. If a portion of a neuron is damaged, it may or may not be able to find and re-connect with itself. If the axon is damaged, the myelin cells such as Schwann cells form a tunnel to help direct the axon to the other portion. Never-the-less, even after several years, if you touch an area of your body that has a scar, you will realize that touch or feeling over that scar has changed and it is not as sensitive as it once was because the receptors and axons were damaged when the skin was damaged. Now, even though the skin is well healed, the nervous tissue has not healed and therefore the sense of touch is poor over that scar. Epithelial tissue and connective tissue heal well, but nervous tissue does not have the ability to divide and replace neurons that have been damaged so it does not heal well.

text: Using concentrations in the Nernst equation is a simplification. In reality, what we care about is the activity. For solutions, the activity is equal to the concentration, which is why we can get away with just writing concentrations for these species. Pure solids and liquids have an activity of 1, so we can ignore them (since multiplying by 1 doesn't change the value). Some bacteria can survive days without oxygen, most bacteria are single celled organisms that dont have lung or gills. Other bacteria find alternate air sources. If you eliminate Aerobic bacteria than you are left off with Anaerobic and Facultative aerobic (both adapted to the anaerobic environment). It is super hard to put Bacteria into the context of the ecosystem and 'population'. Bacteria operate on a much smaller scale and are single-celled. they produce colonies. Almost impossible to follow their population since the growth rate is super fast. Even if PLanet Earth becomes a completely anaerobic place, Bacteria will thrive.

However, homologous chromosomes are two chromosomes with different versions of genes. One homologous pair contain two chromosomes. 2. For example, if you are a male, then your sex chromosome would be XY so during interphase your X chromosome and Y chromosome would be doubled. So when the somatic cell goes in to the mitosis stage, the X and Y sister chromatids would be separated, resulting in each one X and Y chromosome again in each daughter cell. That's why your cells in your body all have XY chromosomes. In meiosis, crossing over also happens at sex chromosomes but the region where the crossing over would happen is limited and it is called pseudoautosomal region. But overall the crossing over would not harm the function of sex chromosomes. One thing meiosis is different from mitosis is that if you are a male, your four haploid daughter cells would have two each contain one X chromosome and the other two each contain one Y chromosome, meaning none of your gamete has a complete pair of sex determine chromosome like XX or XY.

text: Well the main type of cell that does not contain 46 chromosomes is our sperm or egg cells. These cells are only Haploid (n), meaning that they have half of the chromosomes that a regular somatic (body) cell has, which is know as Diploid (2n). The main reason it has half of the chromosomes is because the sperm cell of the father will have to merge with the egg cell of the mother and if both cells had 46 chromosomes then 46 + 46 would equal 92, twice as many chromosomes than we actually have! Therefore these gamete cells have only 23 chromosomes to allow for half the genes of the mother and half the genes of the father to merge and create a baby with the genes of both parents. text: The net inflow of water when the cell is placed in a hypotonic solution does not require energy. However, net inflow is not because there is room to move around. Individual water molecules move around randomly. They enter the cell because that was the direction they were traveling in. The number of water molecules is so high, that their individual random paths average out. This is why diffusion tends to keep the quantities of water on both sides equal. When there is more water on one side, there is a greater chance that more of it will leave the area of high concentration then enter it, balancing it out. However, in a hypotonic solution, there is more solute inside the cell than outside. The probability for each individual water molecule to leave the cell is greatly decreased. Therefore, there needs to be much more water inside the cell than outside, for the amount of water leaving the cell to be equal to the amount of water entering it. Until that point is reached however, the amount o f water inside the cell will increase until the cell lyses or the amount of water entering and exiting the cell equalizes. text: The main source of motivation for baby birds is food. The baby bird knows nothing more than that at regular intervals their mother will come and drop some food off in their mouth. Slowly the mother bird will stand farther and farther away from the nest, forcing the baby bird to come out of the nest to get food. The bird realizes it needs this food to survive and this is the motivation for them to venture out onto a branch. Allosteric - means change of shape. The term allosteric inhibition speaks itself - inhibition caused by change of shape of an enzyme. So, once allosteric inhibitor bind to passive site, it provokes change of shape of a protein (enzyme). Substrate cannot bind to active site because it does not exist anymore. Even though allosteric inhibitor hasn't touched active site at all. Prior active site now became something deformed which is unable to bind substrate.

text: Reduction = gain in electrons. K would find it harder to gain electrons than Li because there are more electron shells around K. This means that atomic radius has increased, so the e- are held with less attraction to the nucleus. Increased sheilding also contributes. This is why K is so reactive - it's electrons are held so losely they easily break away. In reduction you want to opposite to happen, a gain in electrons, so a strong force of attraction on your valency electrons is needed. Li has the smallest radius (and all of group one has the same nuclear charge) so Li has the strongest force of attraction and thus most easily atracts more electrons. The molarity you use to measure the equilibrium constant is the molarity at equilibrium.

text: Anabolic reactions are defined as biological reactions that create more complex (larger) molecules. Anabolic reactions are endergonic (store energy). Anabolic reactions do use energy harvested from catabolic processes, but that is not typically part of the definition of anabolism. Usually, a carbon needs four different substituents to be a chiral center. It is more sophisticated and accurate to think that carbons must be sp3 hybridized to four different substituents in order to be a chiral center. Allenes are an exception, but since they are so rare you probably do not need to worry about them. In regard to carbanions: Remember that a lone pair of electrons counts as a substituent, so carbanions with three different atomic substituents are chiral centers. Conversely, carbocations are not chiral centers because a plane of symmetry exists down each of its three bonds: The same is true of the three bonds of carbons with a double bond. So, a carbon with only three groups attached to it--but all three groups are different--is not a chiral center, but a 'pro-chiral' center.
question: Does anabolism and catabolism is a cyclic process?
context1: Anabolic reactions are defined as biological reactions that create more complex (larger) molecules. Anabolic reactions are endergonic (store energy). Anabolic reactions do use energy harvested from catabolic processes, but that is not typically part of the definition of anabolism.
context2: Usually, a carbon needs four different substituents to be a chiral center. It is more sophisticated and accurate to think that carbons must be sp3 hybridized to four different substituents in order to be a chiral center. Allenes are an exception, but since they are so rare you probably do not need to worry about them. In regard to carbanions: Remember that a lone pair of electrons counts as a substituent, so carbanions with three different atomic substituents are chiral centers. Conversely, carbocations are not chiral centers because a plane of symmetry exists down each of its three bonds: The same is true of the three bonds of carbons with a double bond. So, a carbon with only three groups attached to it--but all three groups are different--is not a chiral center, but a 'pro-chiral' center.

text: If placing a red blood cell in a hypotonic solution, it will burst. A hypotonic solution has a low solute concentration than the inside of the cells (solute concentration in the cell is high). Osmotic forces then cause water from a solution to enter the cells. The cell eventually stretches and bursts in the process becoming lysis. phase changes are as converting the incoming thermal energy (when you're heating something up) to potential/phase energy. In a certain phase, such a solid, the particles can only move so much because its IMF is holding them together. At a certain point, the incoming thermal energy can't make the particles move any faster/KE can't increase because of the phase it's in. Instead, the energy is converted to phase energy and allows the particles to break free of their IMF. When the energy is converted to phase energy, you're right in that there is a tiny drop in temperature but it's replaced almost immediately when you're continuously adding energy into a substance

At a certain point, the incoming thermal energy can't make the particles move any faster/KE can't increase because of the phase it's in. Instead, the energy is converted to phase energy and allows the particles to break free of their IMF. When the energy is converted to phase energy, you're right in that there is a tiny drop in temperature but it's replaced almost immediately when you're continuously adding energy into a substance

text: The DNA fragments move through the agarose gel so they are experiencing viscous drag as they move through the gel. This viscous drag is proportional to the mass of the DNA fragment. The mass of the DNA fragment depends on the length of the DNA fragment. The longer the DNA fragment, the more atoms it contains so the more electrons it contains. The more electrons in the DNA fragment, the stronger the intermolecular london forces of attraction between the DNA fragment and the gel molecules so the greater the viscous drag experienced by the DNA fragment. They travel at the same acceleration but it's the viscous drag through the gel that causes heavier DNA fragments to move slower than the lighter DNA fragments. You would have two half reactions; an oxidation half reaction and a reduction half reaction. Remember: oxidation is losing electrons, reduction is gaining electrons. So the half reaction that has some element or compound plus electrons on the REACTANTS side would be the reduction reaction. The half reaction with some element or compound plus electrons on the PRODUCTS side is the oxidation reaction.

The more electrons in the DNA fragment, the stronger the intermolecular london forces of attraction between the DNA fragment and the gel molecules so the greater the viscous drag experienced by the DNA fragment. They travel at the same acceleration but it's the viscous drag through the gel that causes heavier DNA fragments to move slower than the lighter DNA fragments.

text: Sodium chloride ionic compounds form a gigantic lattice structure due to the electrostatic attractions between the individual ions. In this case, each sodium ion is surrounded by 4 chloride ions and each chloride ion is surrounded by 4 sodium ions and so on and so on, so that the result is a massive crystal. This particular ratio of Na ions to Cl ions is due to the ratio of electrons interchanged between the 2 atoms Photons are, by nature, massless. That is why they are able to travel at the speed of light (C) and not just below it. Anything with mass cannot move at the speed of light. @kokocipher In answer to your question where does gravity ultimately come from, according to the General Theory of Relativity, the most widely accepted and most accurate theory used to explain our observations of gravity, gravity is the result of objects with mass bending space time. All objects bend spacetime, and more massive/dense objects bend it more steeply. That is they have a stronger gravitational pull. Since mass == energy (E=MC2)energy will indeed bend space time, if there is enough energy in a small enough space. However, consider the following. It requires the mass of an entire moon or planet to have an effect strong enough for you to feel. Since E=MC2 the amount of energy required to bend space the same amount (that is to have a gravitational influence that humans could detect without instruments) is unfathomable. If there's energy that dense it tends to collapse into matter. Indeed, this is what happens in our particle accelerators such as the LHC. As for black holes, they are locations in space where there is mass dense enough to bend spacetime so steeply that it would require movement faster than the speed of light to escape. Due to the nature of our Universe it is impossible to exceed the speed of light (I'm aware that sounds vague, but it would take a good hour to explain in more detail). Therefore, nothing, not even light, can escape.

If you look at the example of the molecules all crammed into one side of the box rather than being diffused throughout, the probability that they would bounce into each other is much greater, and therefore they exhibit a greater potential for increasing the kinetic energy of each molecule. text: Straight-chain alkanes are able to pack and layer each other better than their branched counterparts. This allows greater intermolecular forces, which raises the melting point since it will take more energy to disperse the molecules into a liquid. Similarly, even-numbered alkanes stack better than odd-numbered alkanes, and will therefore have higher melting points. Hydrogen bonds do not take very much energy to break. The hydrogen bond is a weak attraction between molecules, or parts of larger molecules to each other caused by regional polarization resulting from hydrogen's very small diameter and relatively low electronegativity.

text: Certain Plants do grow better around each other and help each other out. Researcher Dr. David Johnson looked closely at plants' symbiotic relationship with soil fungus, piggybacking off a 2010 study that seemed to suggest that a tomato plant infected with leaf blight would be able to warn nearby plants of the problem. In turn, those plants would activate genes that would prevent them from catching the disease, too. Johnson was able to show how plants use fungus in the soil as a network (think of it as a botanical Wi-Fi, if you will). Essentially, fungi deliver messages of danger from plant to plant, and as a result, the group can grow stronger. Even plants get by with a little help from their friends. *Animals* help plants by pollinating them, and be helping to disperse seeds. The droppings of animals also fertilize plants. Plants have three basic responses or reactions to light. They are photosynthesis, phototropism and photoperiodism. As plants react/respond to light the amount of heat wont matter anyway. Certain genes responsible for hairiness are present on the X chromosome but are expressed only when that X chromosome is in a male because the activation and expression of these genes require several inputs, like certain hormones at certain specific developmental stages all of which are different for males and females due to the presence of Y chromosome in males. Have a look at a SRY region in the chromosome for more details on sexual dimorphism. Even some genes for male reproductive organs are on the X chromosome. Similarly, the presence of female hormones, or the absence of male hormones might be required for certain genes to be expressed, making them X linked and still only expressed in women.

text: Osmosis is the movement of water via a semipermeable membrane from a less concentrated solution to a more concentrated solution. A less concentrated solution has more water than a more concentrated solution. In essence, the water is moving down its concentration gradient from the less concentrated to the more concentrated solution to equalize the concentration on both sides of the semipermeable membrane. The reaction with water is explosive. However, in the LAH reduction of a carboxylic acid, a solution of the acid in an ether solvent is slowly added to a solution or stirred suspension of LAH in the same solvent. The solutions can be cooled and the rate of addition controlled to keep the reaction slow enough that the hydrogen does not explode.

text: If the mass of the molecule or compound is not given and you just have the mass percentages, you can assume it is out of ANY weight. That said, using 100 grams to calculate masses is a common method because it simplifies the math, since any percent mass times 100 grams will have a mass (in grams) that is the same as the percent mass. There are two double bonds between C and O, and two lone pairs of electrons on each Oxygen. During the formation of CO, what happens is the absence of the second oxygen is solved by the donation of one of those lone pairs of electrons from the oxygen to the carbon. So two of the bonds are simple covalent bonds, in which each atom supplies one electron to the bond, and the third bond is a co-ordinate covalent bond (i.e. both electrons provided only by O). Count the electrons and notice that both have 8 in their outer shell. That's is all molecules want

text: Voltage and current sources generate both voltage and current. The difference between them lies in which parameter (voltage or current) is being controlled. A constant voltage source (like a battery) is designed to generate a controlled voltage. When you put a constant voltage source in a circuit, the voltage across its terminals is always a constant value. Depending on what it is connected to, a voltage source provides (generates) whatever current is needed to keep the voltage on its terminals constant. Example: a 1.5 V battery connected to a 100 ohm resistor will generate a current of 1.5/100 = 15 mA. If you change the resistor to 10 ohms, the voltage will still be 1.5 V but the voltage source will now generate a current of 1.5/10 = 150 mA. Current sources may seem a little strange, but they behave exactly like a voltage source, but with current being controlled. A constant current source is designed to generate a controlled current. When you put a current source in a circuit, the current through the source is always a constant value. Depending on what it is connected to, a current source provides whatever voltage is needed to keep the current on its terminals constant. Example: suppose you have a constant current source set to current = 1 mA. If you connect a 100 ohm resistor across the current source, the voltage will be V = 1 mA x 100 ohms = 0.1 V. If you change the resistor to 1000 ohms, the current will still be 1 mA and the voltage generated by the current source will rise to V = 1 mA x 1000 ohms = 1 V. Most transistors (MOSFET, Bipolar) and the old vacuum tubes have a region of operation where they act just like a current source. Biological molecules are chiral; they can detect the different isomers. If people put the stereoisomers in a reaction mix of (non-biological) chiral molecules, they would react differently too.

If you change the resistor to 10 ohms, the voltage will still be 1.5 V but the voltage source will now generate a current of 1.5/10 = 150 mA. Current sources may seem a little strange, but they behave exactly like a voltage source, but with current being controlled. A constant current source is designed to generate a controlled current. When you put a current source in a circuit, the current through the source is always a constant value. Depending on what it is connected to, a current source provides whatever voltage is needed to keep the current on its terminals constant. Example: suppose you have a constant current source set to current = 1 mA. If you connect a 100 ohm resistor across the current source, the voltage will be V = 1 mA x 100 ohms = 0.1 V. If you change the resistor to 1000 ohms, the current will still be 1 mA and the voltage generated by the current source will rise to V = 1 mA x 1000 ohms = 1 V. Most transistors (MOSFET, Bipolar) and the old vacuum tubes have a region of operation where they act just like a current source.

text: there is a time limit on how long Carbon 14 can exist. However, new supplies of it are created in the upper atmosphere when nitrogen gas absorbs high-energy neutrons which are released due to the atmosphere interacting in complex ways with cosmic rays. Eventually algae and plants photosynthesize the newly created C-14 and introduce it to the food chain. Thus, while carbon 14 is constantly decaying, it is also constantly being created. text: The half-life of a radioactive element is the time it takes before half of the atoms in a sample of the element have decayed. If you know how many atoms you have in a sample, and you measure how many of them decay per second, it is easy to figure out how long you would have to wait before half of all the atoms have decayed. You do not have to measure until half the atoms actually have decayed, but the tradition is that we use the half-life as a measure of how quickly a radioactive element decays. Light slows down when it goes from air to glass, and then it speeds up when it goes from glass to air. When it speeds up or slows down like this and it hits the air/glass boundary at an angle, the path of the light gets bent. This is called refraction, and sal has a video that explains it. The angle of refraction is governed by Snell's Law. A prism is shaped so that it bends the light twice, in the same direction both times. The amount that the light gets bent depends a little bit on the frequency of the light. So when you put white light into the prism, the light doesn't all get bent the same amount, which means that it comes out spread out into a spectrum.
question: What is the technique that actually establishes the half-life time duration?
context1: The half-life of a radioactive element is the time it takes before half of the atoms in a sample of the element have decayed. You do not have to measure until half the atoms actually have decayed, but the tradition is that we use the half-life as a measure of how quickly a radioactive element decays.

The amount that the light gets bent depends a little bit on the frequency of the light. text: Semipermeable and selectively permeable can be slightly different in meaning, though this usage is not consistent. Semipermeable is typically used as an overall term for membranes that only allow some molecules to pass through - in some cases this is used exclusively for selection based on molecule (or ion) size. Selectively permeable just means that some molecules can pass through the membrane based on their properties, but most molecules or ions can not pass through the membrane. Different semipermeable membranes may let different size molecules pass through - an example of this is dialysis membranes (or tubing), which can be made with pore sizes that will allow small macromolecules (e.g. proteins) to pass through while restricting larger macromolecules. You can use that total time to find the average velocity if you divide displacement/time lapsed.

text: The immune cells in the blood can escape from the blood vessel that they are in, and travel through tissue. Once in the tissue, the immune cells can attack the cartilage. Metabolism definitely varies between people. Metabolism can be defined as the sum of all of the chemical reactions occurring inside of a living organism. Metabolism varies depending on the conditions present inside of the organism. The human body can speed up and slow down the rates of different chemical processes simultaneously in an attempt to maintain homeostasis. So weight can affect metabolism, but it certainly isn't the only factor that does so. A person's activity level, hormone levels, age, energy intake, and overall health can also impact metabolism.

Metabolism varies depending on the conditions present inside of the organism. The human body can speed up and slow down the rates of different chemical processes simultaneously in an attempt to maintain homeostasis. So weight can affect metabolism, but it certainly isn't the only factor that does so. A person's activity level, hormone levels, age, energy intake, and overall health can also impact metabolism.

text: The deep sea plants would be relying on chemical energy, which can be created by Chemoautotrophs (Chemosynthesis) bacteria living in there area to convert inorganic matter in the area into organic compounds. Chemosynthesis is effectively the process of using CO2 as an carbon source, and by oxidizing inorganic compounds to make energy.  In the camera, as well in many machines you don't use the electron energy, but only the energy that pushes the electrons on the pathway. The electrons are only the carriers of the energy. But the internal energies of the electrons are not used (yet). Many persons don't fit on this: electric energy is not the energy of the electron: is the kinetic energy that is transformed from waterfalls (hydrelectric), thermoelectric generators, etc, that put potential energy and the potential energy difference (Volt) to electron movements. So, the machines uses that energy transforming into its uses (mechanical movement of the obturator, the digital LCD that guide you to take a best picture, etc. But the image reception occur with other source: the photossensitivity of many microLEDs with special features of transform photonic energy into voltage (potential energy diference), and that send to the microprocessor to calculate the spatial position of each microreceptiveLED, its voltage intensity to bright.

text: Nonpolar molecules that repel the water molecules are said to be hydrophobic; molecules forming ionic or a hydrogen bond with the water molecule is said to be hydrophilic. This property of water was important for the evolution of life. Hydrophobic interaction plays the most critical role in the formation of the lipid bilayer of the cell membrane and the folding of proteins and nucleic acids; therefore, hydrophobic interaction is the foundation for the existence of life. A self-assembled monolayer (SAM) is a layer of organic molecules formed spontaneously on a solid substrate. One end of the organic molecule binds to the solid surface via a covalent bond while the other endpoints outwards. Because the exposed end of the SAM determines the surface properties of the SAM modified substrate, we can alter a hydrophobic surface (a surface that expels water) into a hydrophilic surface (a surface that attracts water) by carefully selecting the SAM forming molecules. It's drawn as a line (vs as a wedge or a dash) it is not defined as either R or S. When a chiral center is drawn with a line instead of wedges/dashes people can usually assume it means people have a racemic mixture. People could specify this by writing R/S before the name or +/- or by not indicating any specific stereochemistry.

text: The DNA fragments move through the agarose gel so they are experiencing viscous drag as they move through the gel. This viscous drag is proportional to the mass of the DNA fragment. The mass of the DNA fragment depends on the length of the DNA fragment. The longer the DNA fragment, the more atoms it contains so the more electrons it contains. The more electrons in the DNA fragment, the stronger the intermolecular london forces of attraction between the DNA fragment and the gel molecules so the greater the viscous drag experienced by the DNA fragment. They travel at the same acceleration but it's the viscous drag through the gel that causes heavier DNA fragments to move slower than the lighter DNA fragments. We cant treat light the same way we treat matter because daily things travel very slowly but when you are travelling at speeds beyond 10^6 ms^-1 the science is different matter and energy are interconvertible (e=mc^2) so it doesn't really store energy it is energy itself.
